TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , as amended, and proposed government amendments 31 to 34 on sheet 11 moved by Senator Minchin. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially I am taking a moment to catch up on where we are. The opposition does not oppose amendments Nos 31 to 34. I am trying to make sure that by voting for these at this stage we do not pre-empt any other amendments that are on the table.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has amendments 108 to 110 to ensure procedural requirements in respect of the validation of future extinguishing acts. We will proceed with those. Amendment 109 applies non-extinguishment principles to the acquisition of native title on offshore places, unless where extinguishment is affected by operation of the common law. Amendment 110 inserts subdivision 10 which identifies the person entitled to the benefit of the procedural rights contained in the previous provision and subsection 11 prescribing minimum standards for those procedural rights.

In essence, it is the regime that we are suggesting should apply offshore. It is a regime of notification and consultation and we believe it is a much fairer one than the government's proposal. It is fairer and definitely more constitutionally sustainable in that it does provide a process of engagement with indigenous Australians, unlike the government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the minister said that this move, which seems very clear to me to trammel indigenous people's ability to be engaged in future offshore developments right around this country, was nothing more than housekeeping in legislative terms and that what the government is doing here is simply reorganising legislation by tidying it up and putting it all into the one section.

SPEECH.PARA: However, when you look at the government's own explanatory memorandum on page 131 the first sentence says:
Item 9 of Schedule 1 inserts Subdivision N of Division 3 to ensure that all future acts affecting native title in offshore places are valid.

Then there are three pages following up on that which are essentially saying that the point of the government's move here is to ensure that the whole range of offshore developments from fisheries through to oil rigs in the future are free of the indigenous people's interest being expressed.

That is what this is about. It is about ensuring that nothing gets in the way of the developmental interest, not least the indigenous interest. If the minister says that is not right, or if the minister has other information for the committee, I would like to hear it. I would like to see where in this the indigenous people's interest is expressed, where they get a go and where they get a say.

We did hear last night in the debate that the indigenous people's interest does not stop at the high water line or even the low water line, and that they are concerned for the whole of the regions they have occupied since time immemorial. They do not have this concept that has been introduced to the country that there is something different or there is some line that separates the seas from the land. It is a continuum as far as they are concerned.

I would like to know from the minister, if this is just housekeeping, why have three pages of explanation as to why it is really ensuring that all future development acts are validated—in brackets but not written here—and native title indigenous interests are ipso facto invalidated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We went through all this last night and, regrettably, I will simply have to repeat myself. This section relating to offshore acts, subdivision N, restates and repackages what is in the current act—no more, no less than the provisions in the current act which are taken out and replaced by subdivision N.

SPEECH.PARA: One of our objectives in our amendment bill is to restructure the act to make it more user friendly. It is one of the most difficult pieces of legislation currently to use. I think it is generally agreed that our restructuring makes it a much more usable piece of legislation, given that it now impacts on at least 79 per cent of Australia. We have simply brought together in subdivision N the current procedures relating to future acts offshore. It sets down clearly the mechanism for ensuring the future validity of acts offshore in exactly the same way as the current act does. It is no different.

In response to what Senator Bolkus said, the act has been found to be constitutional; ipso facto these provisions are constitutional because they restate what is in the current act. They make it clear that native title holders shall have exactly the same procedural rights as other holders of interests in offshore places and that compensation is payable for future acts that are valid because of this subdivision.

We are treating native title holders the same as everybody else. That is what the current act does; that is what we propose to continue in relation to governments authorising future acts offshore. Native title holders are effectively to be treated like everybody else—to have the same procedural rights and to be entitled to compensation if there is any impact on their native title—in exactly the same way as is provided for in the current act. The non‐extinguishment principle will apply unless it is a compulsory acquisition.

We are not aware of any reason why any compulsory acquisition would be needed offshore, but the current act provides for that to occur, if necessary, in a non-discriminatory manner. Our amendments go to that to make sure it is non‐discriminatory and to make sure that other rights and interests are acquired if there is a compulsory acquisition. As I say, I cannot think of circumstances that would give rise to that.

As I said last night, we are restating the current act in all these provisions. There is nothing in this that takes away from what is in the current act in relation to the regime to apply offshore for the doing of future acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a question that flows directly from that. Minister, you say you are restating the current act in respect of offshore, but aren't you redefining offshore waters to include the intertidal zone? Under the current act, the intertidal zone is an area which does attract the right to negotiate. Where in your bill do you protect the right to negotiate in respect of the current intertidal zone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition of `offshore' has not changed—that is, below the extent of the state; anything is offshore that is beyond the limits of the state. We will come to a discussion about the right to negotiate in the intertidal zone under the right to negotiate provisions where, yes, we are changing that. Under the current act, there is no right to negotiate offshore. We are not changing the definition of `offshore'. What we are changing is the application of the right to negotiate in that intertidal zone, but that is not dealt with under these provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: My statement that we are not changing anything in relation to offshore is absolutely correct. There is no right to negotiate now offshore. The procedural rights that attach to native title holders are set out in our bill in exactly the same way as they are set out in the current 23(6)(b) which says:
to the extent that the act is in relation to an offshore place—any corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place that are not native title rights and interests.

Those are the procedural rights. As I say, we are simply repeating what is in the current act in relation to the procedural rights. It is fundamentally based on non‐discrimination, equality and equity that native title holders shall be treated like everybody else in relation to their procedural rights offshore. The right to negotiate does not relate to this section. As I say, we can discuss the right to negotiate in relation to the intertidal zone under the right to negotiate amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth reflecting that the opposition and minor parties have been discussing the intertidal zone in the context of this debate. We do not have to embark upon a session of point scoring with respect to that other than to say we have flagged it here, we have amendment No. 299, and, if the government feels fit to discuss it under the broad umbrella of right to negotiate, then I am happy enough to do that.

BREAK.PARA: The other point we do make is that, in respect of this offshore area, putting aside whatever arguments you might put in respect of the current regime, what we are proposing on the opposition side is a regime of notification and consultation. What the minor parties are proposing is a right to negotiate in respect of those areas. That is where the distinction in policy terms lies on this issue of offshore rights. Our proposal is not as broad and as wide ranging as that of the minor parties.

As I said, we are proposing a system of notification and engagement of indigenous Australians. In a sense, that is where the policy difference is. Maybe what we need to focus on this morning is how to resolve those issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister aware of the situation in many parts of Australia where there has been a great deal of effort—and it may well be something which has come to the attention of the minister for Aboriginal affairs and the minister for health—to encourage communities to continue to teach their younger members how to obtain bush tucker by fishing, collecting yams and other items which are of dietary benefit for the people in those areas? Considering this legislation leaves these issues extremely uncertain for people living in coastal areas who have traditionally fished for the main part of their diet, what does the minister think the implication is going to be for culture, dietary implications and health of indigenous people if they are, as a result of this legislation, left to the regulatory pen of state and territory governments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say, again, is that this does not change the current position. As someone who spends as much of his time as he can fishing, I have every respect and regard for the traditional pursuits of Aboriginal people in relation to the sea. Of course, there is nothing as a matter of law that prevents my going fishing, or anybody else, but I am governed by whatever regulations a state may wish to put in place in relation to offshore areas, as is any body else. To the extent that native title rights are found to exist offshore, as a right exercisable under the common law relating to native title, they can be exercised, as is currently the case. Of course, many of them are exercised now without requiring the sort of fiat of a common law determination. Anybody else can hop in a boat and go fishing as long as they do not catch undersized fish or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing in these provisions that changes the current situation or that goes to extinguishment of native title, or that affects the right of claimants to seek determinations of native title offshore, to the extent that they feel that is required in order to preserve their right to do what they are probably currently doing. They have that full entitlement. All this does is preserve the current situation, which is to confirm the right of governments to authorise acts offshore validly, but on the basis that native title holders shall have the same procedural rights as everybody else, and have a right to compensation for any impact on their native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, can you envisage a time when indigenous Australians may be fined or put into prison for not applying for a fishing licence because they feel strongly that they should not have to apply for a licence for their own rights to fish in their traditional fishing areas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the tricky issues for all Australians to the extent that there are different laws for different people. It is important to observe and pay particular regard to Aboriginal people exercising their traditional rights, but on the ground you run into problems when any other Australian is prevented from doing something that a native title holder can do. That is where you do run into serious problems. However, we have maintained section 211. As I mentioned last night, 211(2) remains.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 211(2) states that, in the circumstances set out in 211:
. . . the law does not prohibit or restrict the native title holders from carrying on the class of activity,—
that is, traditional activities, which are set down as hunting, fishing, gathering, cultural or spiritual activity or `any other kind of activity prescribed for the purpose of this paragraph'—
or from gaining access to the land or waters for the purpose of carrying on the class of activity, where they do so:
(a) for the purpose of satisfying their personal, domestic or non‐commercial communal needs; and
(b) in exercise or enjoyment of their native title rights and interests.
That protection, which I remember we did debate in 1993, is preserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very nice to say `enjoyment of their native title rights and interests', but if they are not able to claim native title rights and interests over water they will not be able to enjoy them, will they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —They can claim native title over offshore water. The Commonwealth's formal position, as a matter of law, is that native title does not exist offshore, but the High Court will ultimately determine that and there is nothing in our amendments which goes to that question. Native title can be claimed. The facilitation of claims for native title offshore is preserved. Native title claims can be made offshore and heard, and are being heard in the Croker Island case. Then we will all know whether native title does exist offshore and, if so, what it consists of. That remains a question for the court and one that will ultimately be determined.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in these provisions prevents the common law developing and determining whether in fact native title does exist offshore and what it consists of. To the extent that it exists offshore, we are providing, as the current act provided and as this parliament provided, the mechanism by which we can ensure the validity of future acts offshore and their relationship with native title. It is a coexisting relationship. It provides for the non‐extinguishment principle to offshore future acts, unless it is a compulsory acquisi tion, which is the same everywhere else. They have the same procedural rights as everybody else. They have a right to just terms compensation and they can pursue their claims. The $40 million that is provided to rep bodies can be used to pursue claims for native title offshore, if that is the wish of the representative body and the claimants. Indeed, that is what is currently going on in the court and ultimately the court will tell us.

If common law is found to be able to survive offshore, then it is preserved by these provisions; the non‐extinguishment principle applies. All this does is continue the current arrangements for the validity of future acts authorised by governments that occur offshore, which could well involve Aboriginal people. If an Aboriginal businessman is seeking a fishing licence or a pearling licence, or anything else, he or she will want to know that they can be validly issued such a right in accordance with these provisions. I hope that Aboriginal people, and I am sure it is happening, will become increasingly involved in commercial fishing, because that is obviously a tremendous opportunity for them in employment. They have every right to seek the assurance that if state governments validly issue them with rights of that kind they will be valid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me summarise what has been said here, including what the minister has said. The Greens‐Democrats position is that, as far as offshore developments are concerned, the indigenous people should have a right to negotiate. The ALP position is that, as far as offshore developments are concerned, the indigenous people should be consulted. The government position is that, as far as offshore developments are concerned, the indigenous people have no rights. The minister has said that is the situation under current legislation. But we are well aware of the fact that current legislation in 1993 did not really foresee that the courts might be in a position to give native title claim to offshore areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Times have moved on and we are now very much in that position. That is why I think it is very important that this opportunity be there to not derogate the ability of indigenous people when it comes to offshore areas to have a say when development comes their way—particularly development which might be inimical to their interests, including their fishing and cultural interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to two statements made there. The common law is in exactly the same position as it was in 1993 in relation to this issue. We yet do not know whether native title can exist offshore and, if so, what it consists of. We are in exactly the same position until a court makes a ruling and, whatever ruling there is, the decision will no doubt be appealed to the High Court. To say they have no rights is absolutely wrong. The bill sets down what is already in the Native Title Act, and that is:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of any future act to which this Subdivision applies, the native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act on the assumption that they instead held any corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place that are not native title rights and interests.

That is exactly what is in the current act. We believe that is fair and equitable and anything else, frankly, amounts to racial discrimination. What we are providing there is absolute equality in relation to procedural rights. They have those procedural rights, the same as everybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow up here. Senator Brown has tried to explain the ALP position. As we said last night, the ALP position is threefold. We expect to move an amendment later in the debate in respect of the right to negotiate on the intertidal zone. We want to maintain that. We will wait for the decision of the Croker Island case. We expect that case in particular will determine to what extent native title will apply offshore. We do not want to pre-empt the development of the common law in respect of those offshore rights. In the meantime, we think there should be at least a platform level of engagement of indigenous Australians pending the outcome of that case. That was something that was said last night. It was not repeated in full this morning, but I did not feel the need to repeat everything this morning that I said last night. For the record, that is the ALP position.

—I was wondering whether, when we come to the vote on these issues in section 11 on offshore places, it would make sense to start from the strongest position and vote in that way. So we would start from the position of asking for the right to negotiate and then go to Labor's proposal.
—Yes, that is a good idea.
—I am quite happy with that. I also think there might be an amendment that Senator Harradine is circulating on this.

—Just before we come to Senator Harradine, for the assistance of the chair, Senator Margetts, could you make exactly clear what it was that you proposed and that both the minister and Senator Bolkus agreed to?

—It might be necessary to hear from Senator Harradine about his amendment No. 21, but my suggestion in this particular case is that we start from the strongest position—the Greens amendment—and go from there.
—If that is the view, let us do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to amendment No. 21, as it has been distributed, I think it would best be dealt with under the heading that I have it before you—that is, under heading No. 10 `Freehold test'. I think I will deal with it then if the committee does not mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I know we are not talking about RTN here. The government does not have to repeat everything it has said—I have heard what it has said—but for the moment, in all events, I am somewhat interested in the proposals put forward by the opposition. They provide for consultations, and I do not know quite why the government should see those as being substantially threatening, pending the outcome of the case that is currently on foot. That is my view at the moment—unless it interferes substantially with the integrity of the government's provisions in N and, as the minister has said, those are actually restating the situation in a different way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, can I just be clear. Were you speaking then to opposition amendments 108 to 110 or to your own amendment 21?
—I was speaking to the opposition's amendments.
—Thank you. The question before the chair is that government amendments 31 to 34 be agreed to.
—I ask that government amendments 31 to 34 be postponed so Senator Margetts can move her amendments and then we can move ours. So we will deal with them in reverse order.
—Is it the wish of the committee that we postpone government amendments 31 to 34 so as to deal with the Greens (WA) amendment 98? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (98) Schedule 1, item 9, page 70 (line 7) to page 72 (line 30), Subdivision N TO BE OPPOSED .

I have just one final point. The right to negotiate has been stated as one of the key linchpin areas in relation to this Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 debate. We are not asking for veto, as was mentioned last night. We are asking that indigenous Australians have the right to negotiate where their native title interests may be involved in offshore development which may affect their lives, their ability to support themselves and many aspects of their existence. That is basically what we are asking for, and it has been stated as the linchpin of this whole Native Title Amendment Bill .

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the committee is that schedule 1, item 9, subdivision N stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be assisted, I think, if there is some quiet in the chamber because the process at the moment has been slightly rearranged. For clarity for everybody, I would like to be sure that we all understand what we are doing. My understanding is, Senator Bolkus, that you will now move opposition amendments Nos. 108 to 110.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:

BREAK.PARA: (108) Schedule 1, item 9, page 70 (line 15) after "future act", insert "and subsections (8), (9) and (10) are complied with".

(109) Schedule 1, item 9, page 71 (lines 3 to 5), omit "then nothing in this Act prevents the acquisition from extinguishing the whole or the part of the native title rights and interests", substitute "then the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition, but nothing in this Act prevents an act that is done in giving effect to the acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests if the extinguishment would occur under the common law".
(110) Schedule 1, item 9, page 72 (after line 30), at the end of section 24NA, add:

PARA.TAB: (10) The procedural rights referred to in subsection (8) apply to a person referred to in paragraph (9)(c) or (d) who is entitled to be notified as mentioned in subsection (9).
(11) The procedural rights of the native title holders referred to in subsection (8) include these rights, or rights at least as favourable as these rights:

TAB.TAB: (a) a right to notice of intention to do the act;
(b) a right to have at least 60 days after receiving the notice of intention in which to make submissions to the person or body having power to do the act as to:
(i) whether or not the act should be done; and
(ii) if the act is to be done, the terms on which it should be done having regard to the likely effect of the act on native title rights and interests;
(c) a right to have that person or body take into account those submissions;
(d) a right to have that person or body give reasons for any decision that is wholly or partly inconsistent with those submissions;
(e) a right to have the heritage protection requirements (see section 238A) complied with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a good look at the ALP amendments and do find them unacceptable. The critical problem is that, in relation to offshore places, effectively dealing with everything from the low‐water mark out to wherever—all the way out to sea, right around Australia—all the offshore sea is claimable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing to prevent 100 per cent of the offshore area of Australia being claimable, so the whole offshore area could be blanketed in native title claims. Any claimant would then be entitled to these procedural rights as set down in amendment No. 110. We are talking about every single fishing licence issued right around Australia every year. Everything to do with exploration or offshore petroleum, anything right down to the most minimal of fishing licences, anything which a government does would be caught up in this process. Thousands of Australians would then be caught up as the recipients of the licences, permits, whatever it is that is involved.
These procedural rights go way beyond, presumably, what would normally be available in terms of the procedural rights laid down in the current act:
(b) a right to have at least 60 days after receiving the notice of intention in which to make submissions to the person or body having power to do the act as to:

TAB.TAB: (i) whether or not the act should be done; and
(ii) if the act is to be done, the terms on which it should be done having regard to the likely effect of the act on native title rights and interests;
(c) a right to have that person or body take into account those submissions;
(d) a right to have that person or body give reasons for any decision that is wholly or partly inconsistent with those submissions;
(e) a right to have the heritage protection requirements (see section 238A) complied with.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not only all that in relation to every licence that is issued in the whole country offshore. If those things are not complied with it is invalid, because in amendment No. 108 they have to be complied with or you have an invalidity problem. So anyone who wants a fishing licence, and we could be talking about Aboriginal people here, will find that unless they go through all the legal consequences—if you do not follow it, you challenge; you go to the Federal Court and all that sort of thing—if the argument is put that just one of these things has not been fully complied with the future act is invalid.

We regard this as completely and utterly unworkable and simply unacceptable. We think the current procedures are right, that is, that the procedural rights attaching offshore shall be equal and equitable and that native title holders shall have the same rights as everybody else. What is proposed here would in practice, we believe, be completely unworkable and, frankly, quite destructive to reconciliation. As I say, you might actually be talking about a lot of Aboriginal people who are seeking permits, licences, leases, et cetera to do things offshore. They themselves would be caught up in this process with potential invalidity hanging over the heads of every one of them. Of course, this could involve considerable investment by the people involved. We regard it as impracticable and unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that we need to start the day with a fear campaign, Senator Minchin. What we are doing here is adding on to your subdivision 24NA in respect of acts affecting offshore places. We are actually adding to that in terms of the right to be notified, a process of notification, for those people in those instances where the right is already provided for in 24NA. We are not saying that every time anyone goes out to fish they need to go through this sort of process. That is over the top and I am sure no‐one really believes that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, this fits very comfortably within the 24NA provisions and applies in those circumstances. We believe this is a platform of rights. It is the base level of rights. We are prepared to wait until Croker Island makes a determination in respect of where native title rights may, in fact, apply offshore. But I do not think it really helps the debate much for you to come in and suggest that just about every time anyone goes out to fish they have to go through this particular process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing in this that protects anyone who seeks a licence to do anything offshore from the application of these provisions. Senator Bolkus can give no such assurance. There is nothing in here that protects anybody seeking a licence, permit or whatever offshore from having to go through all these provisions. We have heard assurances from the ALP over the last four years about this whole issue of native title. Most of those assurances have come to nothing and we are left with an act which leaves us with considerable uncertainty and difficulty. The application of these provisions would put us back in that position. They are unworkable and should not be accepted.

—Nothing would stop anyone now from issuing their proceedings under the common law to try to do what Senator Minchin is concerned may happen under opposition amendment 110. What we provide here, though, is a process which is much faster, more certain and much less expensive than a full, blown‐out common law application. If we are being reasonable in assessing this, we would recognise the alternative rights available to people and recognise that in the interim, whilst Croker Island is being determined, this is a better process. It does not stop people from doing what they are doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What the ALP are asking for is really very cursory procedural rights. The bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) In the case of any future act to which this Subdivision applies, the native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation—
et cetera. The Labor Party's amendment 110 says:
(10) The procedural rights referred to in subsection (8) apply to a person referred to in paragraph (9)(c) or (d) who is entitled to be notified as mentioned in subsection (9).
(11) The procedural rights of the native title holders referred to in subsection (8) include these rights, or rights at least as favourable as these rights:
(a) a right to notice of intention—

That just means copies of applications for things like commercial fishing licences simply get sent on, as a matter of course, to native title holders. This is not an unreasonable thing. I am not sure exactly how many claims will be made or will be successful in relation to offshore places. As we know, it is going to be as difficult as possible from this government's point of view to make, proceed with, register and gain native title rights but, should anybody get through all the traps that you have set, basically what the Labor Party is making available is the right to be consulted. This is bizarre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing in the ALP amendment which restricts this to commercial activity. The application of these provisions would affect any requirement for a licence for amateur fishing. If you need a licence in any particular jurisdiction to fish not for commercial purposes offshore, then all these provisions would apply; that is the whole point. That is why we regard it as utterly impractical and potentially quite damaging to the reconciliation process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it a break, Senator Minchin. Where do these provisions apply? Where do these procedural rights apply? They apply where you have determined that they apply. They apply in accordance with subclause (8), as Senator Margetts quite rightly said. Subclause (8) says that `native title holders have the same procedural rights' and so on. If that means anything, it has to mean something like what we are suggesting those procedural rights will be, if not more. You leave it vague. We put in a platform of rights and give some certainty to people involved. You are the one, in subclause (8) on page 72, who determines that indigenous Australians should have the same procedural rights as others. You are the one who determines where those procedural rights should apply in subdivision N, at 24NA.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that, in satisfying the right to be notified under subclause (9) with respect to offshore waters for indigenous Australians, there should be a platform level of at least notification and engagement. Other people would be notified if someone was to do something in an area in which other people may have a right. In this particular case, indigenous Australians may have a right. As a consequence of that right, then they should have a right to be notified, at least by the issuing authority. For you to suggest that one's Sunday afternoon fishing might be affected by this is akin to the Prime Minister and others running the line on your backyard being in danger. It really does not help the debate at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Bolkus, we have to stick to the facts. The trouble with parliaments passing laws is that invariably—and it is the history of parliaments—they have unbelievable unintended consequences. One of the quite dramatic lessons of history is that parliaments, with every good intention in the world, pass acts without thinking through what the unintended consequences of those acts will be and, if you need a licence to engage in amateur fishing offshore, then this will apply. This is more than just a right to be notified. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) a right to have at least 60 days after receiving the notice of intention in which to make submissions to the person or body having power to do the act as to:
(i) whether or not the act should be done; and
(ii) if the act is to be done, the terms on which it should be done . . .
(c) a right to have that person or body take into account those submissions;

The scope of this is enormous and you must, in examining the application of laws of this kind which are laws of the Commonwealth, think through all the potential unintended consequences of your actions. We have proposed what you said should apply in the Native Title Act and which you put in the Native Title Act. Exactly what is in the current Native Title Act is repeated in the bill; that is, that the procedural rights should apply fairly and equitably. Whatever procedural rights apply for non‐native title rights and interests in any jurisdiction shall apply to the native title holders and, if that involves a right to be notified, then that must be pursued in subclause (9). Nothing could be fairer, more sensible or more equitable. We really do have great concerns about the unintended consequences of what you are proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two points to make here. First of all, is it not a bit much for this parliament to be asking, in circumstances where people are notified of something that may impact on their rights, when they make representations with respect to any effect on their rights, that the body that issues the permit should take these submissions into account? Is what you are suggesting to us that you find this sort of clause offensive? That is exactly what you just said. If a right to be engaged, notified and consulted means anything, it basically means that it is a right to have your views taken into account. There is nothing unintended about that particular clause, nor is there with respect to the previous clauses. If you want uncertainty, if you are really concerned about unintended consequences, tell us what subclause (8) means. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of any future act to which this Subdivision applies, the native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act on the assumption that they instead held any corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place that are not native title rights and interests.
You do not even attempt to define what processes are appropriate here. At least we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been one of the worst cases of scaremongering that I have heard in this debate—the right to notice of intention and the right to have at least 60 days. The reality is that native title holders, native title applicants, can waive that right. I cannot imagine native title holders, who will have the right only to be consulted or to see, will actually want to search through every fishing licence that has ever been applied for. The right is there. It is not a compulsion. It does not say, `The native title holders must actually look at every fishing licence.'

SPEECH.PARA: The rights exist, and I imagine they may be used in areas where there is concern that the issuing of any permits to engage in any kind of activity may in fact impinge on native title rights. It might be that every now and then somebody from the claimant group gets to see how many licences have been applied for so they get an idea of what kind of pressure is on the area, what kind of usage there is within the area, if it is fishing we are talking about. Of course, there are other uses for offshore waters as well.

It is not unreasonable. The rights do not have to be taken by those people to whom those procedural rights are given. I can imagine that, considering the way that Aboriginal claimants have very frequently acted, they will work out a system which works for them and for claimants. Obviously there is the ability for, and there may be, recreational fishing associations or commercial fishing associations that can meet with claimants and discuss processes and how rights can be enjoyed. These things are possible. This legislation does not require every licence to be seen by every native title claimant. It says there is a right, and people have the right to waive their rights if they so desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a classic case of not understanding the consequences of what you are doing. This is a compulsory procedure. If it is not followed, the act is invalid. That is our greatest concern about it. You have to go through all this and talk to all the native title holders. If there are a hundred claims over the area on which the fishing licence is proposed to be issued, you have to go through this procedure with every single one of them. If you do not go through it with any one of them, and if these are not followed to the letter of the law, the act is invalid.

SPEECH.PARA: At any stage, anyone can challenge in the Federal Court, as is currently happening, whether or not these procedures are being complied with. It would become a legal circus of a kind which I really do fear. We are not scaremongering here, as you might say. You have to think through the consequences of what you are doing. It is a compulsory procedure. If it is not followed, the act is invalid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, maybe you should listen to yourself. Maybe you are the one who does not understand what is being applied here. If you look at opposition amendment No. 110, subclause 10, the procedural rights that we are talking about are the rights that are provided for in your subclause 8. Your subclause 8 provides that indigenous people should have the same procedural rights as others.

SPEECH.PARA: If others do not have procedural rights, if, for instance, with respect to the issuing of fishing permits now, other people do not have a right to be notified, indigenous Australians will be treated in the same way and they will not have a right. Where a right exists, they are included in the category of people who would be notified. But, where such right does not exist, they would not be. Do you know where we get the authority for that? It is from your subclause 8 on page 72.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, do you know from where we get subclause 8? It is from your section 23(6)(b) in the current act. That is where we get it from.
—I'm pleased you have picked it up!

—We have picked it up and put it in place. We think that is the appropriate regime. We are continuing with it. You agreed to that in 1993. You never proposed to amend it. That is what is provided for. We think that is the appropriate mechanism, but you are now setting this quite detailed procedure in place and making it compulsory—if you do not comply with this, your act is invalid. This is one of the rare parts of the Native Title Act we are prepared to pick up, agree with and implement in full because it is the current procedure, which you put in place. We just think what you are proposing now will be unworkable.

—You picked up what we had in the 1993 act, and you obviously endorse it. That is great. In essence, we are saying to you what I said a few minutes ago. That is, it will be compulsory in those circumstances where other people have a right to expect to be notified but, where those people do not have a right, in the terms of subclause 8 indigenous Australians have the same rights as those other people.

BREAK.PARA: It is not compulsory in all circumstances; it is compulsory only in those circumstances where other people have a right to be engaged in the process. That is provided for by subclause 8. Subclause 8, as it seems in the last couple of minutes or so, has at least bipartisan support in the Senate. I do not know what you are arguing about, Senator Minchin. We make these rights applicable only in the cases where other people have similar rights, and that is provided for by your endorsement of the 1993 act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It remains the case that, if these procedures are not followed, the act is invalid. It also remains the case that, effectively, it is discriminating against others who have a right to be notified by saying that these rights will apply to people of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander race but not to anybody else. Our whole premise is to treat people equally. Whatever state regime is in place for the procedural rights to apply, it should apply equally to everybody. We think that is fundamental to our approach to the handling of offshore activity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference is that we are now looking at the potential of courts agreeing that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have a valid claim to offshore areas. This part of the debate is about how to handle that situation, which was not envisaged as clearly in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have said is that, when developers come along into these offshore areas, Aboriginal people should have a right to negotiate where they have a valid native title claim. What the ALP is saying is that they should not negotiate but at least be consulted. What the government is saying is that the claim is there but that there are no rights to negotiate or to be notified and consulted on developments.

In this committee we have turned down the right of native title claimants or people who have native title rights to negotiate over offshore areas. That has happened. We are now at the opposition's intermediary position, if you like. It seems to me it leaves indigenous people with very few powers at all, but at least they have the right to be notified and consulted. I think it is very important that at least that much be granted, at least that much not be extinguished in this circumstance.

The reality is that there is much more than fishing involved here. We are looking at the developmental future for the next century of all the offshore areas of Australia, particular northern Australia. You do not have to be the owner of a good crystal ball to know that there are going to be massive developments in offshore areas of Australia in the coming century. As far as indigenous people are concerned, each one of those developments is likely to roll back their existing rights, their existing facility, their existing bond with the offshore areas. They should at least be consulted.

We maintain that they should be able to negotiate as this serial erosion of their existing rights occurs. The government and the opposition have said no to that. The opposition is saying that we should at least have the indigenous people in the position where they are notified and consulted when a development is about to occur—even though, at the end of the day, they have no power to have their point of view pertain. They can be ignored. Surely the government ought not be cavilling with that.

The minister said that thousands of Australians will be caught up—indeed, indigenous Australians will—by the developments of the future. Surely they have a right to have a say. We have already taken away their power to negotiate and have an outcome affected by their interests in offshore areas. Let us at least give them a say, as the opposition is providing under these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Native title rights are special. The ALP's amendments, in a small way, recognise the special nature of native title. I will keep bringing this up during the debate, but the maps that I tabled last night clearly show that there are offshore areas in Australia of up to several hundred kilometres, which can, in fact, be claimed by industries like the mining industry. The actual impact of those is that there is often no negotiation required. Mining is frequently destructive and generally environmentally incompatible with other uses. We do not see the minister jumping up and down in relation to the offshore areas. He continues to promote this spectre of fear and loathing when, in reality, the rights that are being asked for here are minimal—less than what the Greens and the Democrats believe should be the basic premise upon which we should be dealing with the native title rights in offshore places.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not onerous. It is simply the very least recognition of the special nature of native title right—a native title right which, we all know, may be largely ceremonial. Other titles, we know, take precedence over native title. Basically what we have is that, if native title itself is to be exercised, because native title cannot interfere with other titles in relation to the practice of those, it is guaranteed to be benign in the exercise. So there is no problem in relation to the exercise of native title on an offshore basis. I think the position that the ALP is taking is minimal, to say the least.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In the bill, 24NA(8) says that `native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act' and that there are `corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place'. Is there any example that the minister could give to us in respect of that matter?

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this matter is going to be determined, so far as native title holders are concerned, by the Croker Island case. I suppose whatever we do here will be affected by that, including subclause (8). As a matter of fact, I would be interested because this particular section is pretty broad. Subclause (8) says:

In the case of any future act . . . the native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act on the assumption that they instead held any corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place . . .
In other words, it gives them the same rights as others. Can we have an example of what those interests in offshore places might be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether or not the Senate engaged in a long debate about this matter when it passed this act. As I understand it, it was with the support of the then equivalent of the National Indigenous Working Group in 1993, but certainly there was professed indigenous support for the act in its current form then. As I say, we are picking up that form now. But let us say the native title right and interest was a right for traditional fishing: then the equivalent right is a permanent lease, licence or whatever to fish. The procedural rights that attach to that licence—for example, in respect of offshore gas or whatever—to the extent that there were procedural rights in the particular jurisdiction attaching to the right to fish issued by the state government would attach to the native title right.

—In this clause you are saying native title rights and procedural rights should be the same as those for other persons with an interest in relation to the offshore place. I am trying, for the life of me, to think of an example of an interest that another person might have in an offshore place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, the obvious one is the right to fish. That is the principal activity; presumably it is the principal native title activity. Why would you be offshore? Essentially to fish. Therefore, that is the obvious and probably the most prevalent example. That is the sort of activity which we are really talking about in terms of future acts. I would have thought that, primarily in terms of quantity and volume, it is almost certainly the most likely native title right that would exist. Whatever procedural rights attach to a licence to fish offshore would attach to the native title holders.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendments 31 to 34, previously moved by the minister, be agreed to.
—I ask the minister to briefly go through that again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of Senator Harradine I will briefly describe each of these amendments. Amendment 31 proposes to amend section 24NA(3) which provides that native title offshore can be extinguished by non‐discriminatory compulsory acquisition. A requirement of such a non‐discriminatory process is that non-native title interests are also acquired. The amendment removes the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' from this requirement with regard to non‐native title rights and interests. There was some concern—that we do not think was justified—that the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' may in some way be discriminatory or permit compulsory acquisitions that are discriminatory, and it is not our intention so we are happy to remove those words.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 32 is in a similar vein. That is again an amendment to proposed subsection 24NA(3). The amendment requires that the practices and procedures adopted do not cause native title holders to be any more disadvantaged than the holders of other rights and interests are when their rights are acquired. Again, this is to further ensure a non-discriminatory process.

Amendment 33 adjusts the provision which allows the Commonwealth to pass on native title compensation liabilities to third parties. It will make it clear that if a law of the Commonwealth states that a third party is liable for compensation then that third party and not the Commonwealth is liable. That is fairly unexceptional, I would have thought.

Amendment 34 is the same as 33 except that it adjusts the provision which allows a state or territory to pass on native title compensation to third parties to make it clear that if a law of a state or territory states that a third party is liable for compensation then that third party and not the state or territory is liable. That is consequential on amendment 33. So these amendments are unexceptional and should be supported, I would have thought.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we proceed to revised sheet 12, is there anything further on sheet 11? We note that there is an opposition amendment 356. Are you intending to move that now?
—I thought we had handled all the opposition amendments. I am not proceeding with 356.
—We will proceed to revised sheet 12—heritage protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no government amendments in respect of heritage but there are five opposition amendments. People might ask why we are addressing heritage issues in this context. We are doing so because of the fast and loose nature of some of the government provisions when it comes to either validating interests or extinguishing indigenous people's rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's amendments do allow many grants and validations of future interests in land without any regard for the protection of sites of significance to indigenous Australians. We believe that any validation or grant of an interest in land over which indigenous Australians hold native title should be conditional upon compliance with basic standards for the protection of Aboriginal sites of significance. The government's legislation does not do that. In fact, in many circumstances it does not even provide for the notification of indigenous Australians. Sometimes it is probably impractical to do so, but that is the regime which the government is pursuing. It does not even provide for notification in basic circumstances.

In the debate, we have consistently called for such protection. However, the government has taken a view that has led it to ignore the need for adequate notification, adequate heritage protection, in relation to many grants—for instance, grants of rights to third parties on pastoral leasehold land. In those third party grants, we include the rights to cut and remove timber, extract and remove gravel and obtain and remove rocks, sand or other resources. These third party acts may have a real and detrimental impact on heritage requirements. The failure to apply heritage protection to such lands when facing possibly large‐scale commercial activity is, we believe, a major government omission from this bill.

Our position is to ensure that a safety net is placed in the legislation. We believe there should be broad protection for indigenous heritage. This protection will relate to lands where, for instance, state governments grant rights to third parties on pastoral leasehold lands. Labor's amendments will ensure that any major development on these properties that occurs as a result of such a grant will comply with the relevant heritage protection requirements in such states. That is the basic principle that we are pursuing.

Labor's amendments will not hamper reasonable, low impact developments. Our amendments are drafted so as to exclude the low impact future acts which, by their nature, are not likely to affect sites of significance. This exemption is also in accordance with the spirit of existing heritage protection laws.

Our amendment 67 amends proposed section 24GE to ensure that validation of future acts which grant rights to third parties on pastoral leases cannot occur unless the heritage protection requirements in section 23A of the act are complied with. In respect of renewals and extensions, our amendment 79 amends proposed section 24IC to ensure that validation of future acts of pastoral activity cannot occur unless the heritage protection requirements in section 238A are complied with.

In respect of acts passing the freehold test, our amendment 103 amends proposed section 24MB to ensure that acts passing the freehold test cannot be validated unless the heritage requirements in section 238A are complied with as well.

In our amendment 210 we talk about the provision of a consistent heritage protection regime that is applied to those subdivisions I have just mentioned. This provision makes it a condition of validity of the relevant act that there be consultation with native title bodies corporate, representative bodies and registered native title holders. For instance, notice of the proposed acts must be given to these native title holders and representative bodies. We anticipate that this notice will have two effects. Firstly, the notice will encourage authorising agencies to consider the heritage implications of the decisions they are making. Secondly, it will allow the native title holders a capacity to protect any affected site of significance under the relevant heritage protection legislation.

In essence, we are talking here about areas where damage could be done to heritage sites and the prospect of that damage not being notified to title claimants. It is important that they do have notice for the four areas I have mentioned in regard to which they otherwise would not get notice. In terms of the applicable regime, we are ensuring that the government's section 238A and relevant state regimes are abided by in respect of the process. But without such a provision in those four areas I mentioned, we believe there would not be sufficient notification of interested parties. We also believe it should be imperative to ensure that the state authorities in particular that may have the task of validating take into account heritage protection as a relevant and important consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, can we clarify the amendments that are on revised sheet 12? We are not sure whether we are working from the same sheet. Amendments 79, 102, 103 and 212—are those the amendments?
—There is an amendment 67. I have here a revised running sheet dated 2 December at 9.48 p.m. I suspect it is numbered 14 and not 12 because amendment 67 has been added to it.
—Before we continue, the revised sheet 12 that I have before me is dated 3 December 1997 at 10.06 a.m., and there is no reference to your amendment No. 67.
—Or No. 210. I was going to raise that in a moment. You did mention amendment No. 210 as well. Could you clarify the position.

—It looks as though the numbers are going backwards in some respects as well as forward. Last night we had sheet 14 and today we have sheet 12. Let us hear from others in the debate, if we could. In the meantime, I will ascertain what has happened to amendment No. 67. We probably will not be proceeding with No. 210 anyway. Amendment No. 67 is the one that I would like to pick up. The principle of what we are talking about is not affected by the deletion of one of the proposed amendments.

—It might help the committee if I speak to Democrats-Greens (WA) amendment No. 99. I am working off revised running sheet No. 12. Our amendment No. 99 requires adherence to basic heritage protection rights for the validity of future acts covered by subdivisions G, which deals with primary production; H, water and air management; I, renewals; K, facilities for services to the public; and, M, freehold test. It establishes an obligation to consult registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants. That consultation should be about minimising the effect of the act on native title, including the avoidance of sites, the continuing access of native title holders and the way that the act is to be carried out.

—I support what Senator Woodley has said. The benefit of the Greens (WA)-Democrat amendment over the proposed amendments by the Labor Party is that theirs probably assumes that they have managed to remove the section on water and airspace. Of course, that was unsuccessful. I ask that that now be included in the ALP's consideration. It is not unreasonable, considering that those sections have not now been removed from the bill, that heritage protection be extended to those areas which have not been successfully removed by means of amendment. With all of the other rights that have been crunched and stomped on so far, the very least we can allow is that special places for Aboriginal Australians have the means to be protected. That is the very least that we should do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. The government's position is that heritage protection is a matter for heritage protection legislation. The Commonwealth and all states and territories have such legislation. If there is any suggestion that it is inadequate, the appropriate thing to do is to seek to amend existing heritage protection legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a native title act. It deals with native title and land management issues and the respect and protection of native title and native title rights and interests, whatever they may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was a mining, pastoral and land use act.

—Heritage protection should be dealt with under heritage protection legislation. Environmental issues should be dealt with under environmental protection legislation. This is again a case of where good intentions result in, quite often, disastrous unintended consequences. We in the past as liberal governments have sponsored and put in place heritage protection legislation. We acknowledge that it is very important and something that should apply. In a legislative sense, and for the purposes of effective land management in Australia, you should not mix up the two. This native title act should deal with native title and the exercise of native title rights and interests. Heritage protection legislation should deal with heritage protection.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that these provisions will only add to the uncertainty and complexity. The parliament and the Labor government did not put this sort of provision in the current Native Title Act. It was fine then to say, `Heritage protection is a matter for heritage protection legislation. Let us not encumber the Native Title Act with these matters, because where will it end? They should be properly dealt with under heritage protection legislation.' That is what the parliament decided in 1993, and we think it is right. We think it should be dealt with in separate legislation.

The effect of these amendments is again to add to the complexity and difficulty of ensuring whether future acts are valid or not by putting yet another regime in place that has to be gone through to ensure the validity of future acts under the Native Title Act. The validation of future acts which grant rights to third parties on pastoral leases cannot occur unless all these requirements are met with. The validation of future act pastoral activity cannot occur unless all these requirements are met with. Acts passing the freehold test cannot be validated unless all these requirements are met with.

Amendment No. 212 basically makes it a condition of validity of these acts that all these things are complied with and that all the consultation occurs with the relevant native title bodies corporate, representative bodies and registered native title holders. It has occurred. The difficulty is that, if for any reason anything occurs where these are not complied with to the absolute letter of the law, you have the potential invalidity problem again. As I say, it is very broad in terms of what future activity is caught up with this. We therefore think it adds considerably to the uncertainty of the whole regime as to what can and cannot be done and what is valid and invalid. The proper place to deal with heritage issues is in heritage legislation. The proper place to deal with native title issues is in the Native Title Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just quickly, I immediately thought of the strike-out provisions, which have requirements about heritage, spiritual connection and all those things you say are necessary. You are prepared to strike out indigenous people with fewer resources on the basis of technicalities. All that is asked here is that, if you are taking action in this bill which will have a potential major or minor impact on heritage, you take the responsibility of making sure that that is not harmed. Your government is saying that this act is beneficial to Aboriginal people. How can you say that when, as a result of the actions you are taking in this bill, you are saying that you will leave heritage protection to Mr Court or Mr Borbidge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing I hope the Senate is listen ing to is that a later Commonwealth act does override previous state acts. For that reason, if not any other reason, it is important for us to focus in this context on heritage issues. Heritage issues are going to be affected by what the government is doing here, as Senator Margetts has quite clearly spelt out. There will be heritage impact in a number of areas I mentioned earlier. Because we are moving down the road, extinguishing and validating without this legislation paying due recognition to the heritage interests of indigenous Australians, there is a real danger that at best there will be some confusion but at worst this overrides pre‐existing acts.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are doing with our proposals here—and clause 67 is still the relevant one, as is clause 210—is no more than preserving state based regimes. We are saying through this legislation that people need to keep on respecting those regimes. We are not bringing in place here a national regime. That is something the government is considering in another process in terms of heritage rights of indigenous Australians and I am sure that will lead to another long protracted debate in this place as well. We are not embarking upon that. What we are saying here is that the loose and fast nature of your legislation on heritage rights will have some impact necessarily and those rights should be protected by this legislation. That is not too much to ask for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with that. The minister says that this is not legislation that should be dealing with the environment or legislation that should be dealing with Aboriginal heritage rights—that is, cultural rights, spiritual attachment to the land, a concern to protect areas of great and central attachment for Aboriginal people. Read that as: this is a document, as the government sees it, for clearing the way for development without the indigenous right being specifically taken into account. It is to roll back that indigenous right.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is a core matter. We are talking here about Aboriginal heritage. Read for that: areas of most intense spiritual significance for the indigenous people of this nation. It is a very critical matter. As Senator Margetts says, the government would leave that to the states, to the Court government or to the Borbidge government. We are more responsible people than that. If the heritage implications of development are going to be ignored by the government then let that be the case for them.

But the minister talks about certainty. These amendments to ensure that heritage protection is built into this legislation are about giving the indigenous people a measure of certainty, not just about things that might happen in the future but certainty about their spiritual attachment to the land—the core of the matter—to ensure that they are notified if a development is going to trammel or threaten that relationship with special places and to ensure that they have some power to be able to defend their heritage. The word `heritage' here is well short of the mark because we are talking about their being, their attachment with the land.

It is very pertinent indeed that in this document, which is largely about turning back indigenous interests, this core matter as far as indigenous people are concerned—their relationship with not just the land but areas of special spiritual significance and cultural significance—should be protected. That is why these amendments are very important. They explicitly say that indigenous people have a means of having a say under this legislation and uniform legislation throughout the country when it comes to protecting those sites of great significance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat what I have said already. There is a Commonwealth heritage protection act 1984 passed by the Hawke government which applies across Australia. The Keating government instituted a review of that act under Elizabeth Evatt. Her report is currently being considered, and amendments and any strengthening that is so desired of that act will be a matter for this parliament when the government responds to that Evatt report, and any deficiencies in the Commonwealth heritage protection act can be dealt with at that time. All the states have heritage protection legislation. That is the appropriate place to deal with heritage protection matters.

SPEECH.PARA: These legislative instruments, like the Native Title Act, are legal documents with legal effect. They are not simply vehicles for expressions of good intent. Everything put in them has a significant legal effect. Because it is Commonwealth it completely overrides any inconsistent state legislation with often unintended consequences, as I say. We believe, as a fundamental matter of principle, that the very important issue of heritage protection should be dealt with in heritage protection legislation and native title matters should be dealt with in the Native Title Act. That is something that we believe quite strongly.

To the extent that anyone thinks current heritage protection legislation is inadequate, the place to deal with that is in the parliament in its dealings with such legislation and not to further encumber and complicate matters by introducing potential elements of uncertainty into the operation of the Native Title Act which, as I say, is an act which effectively governs all land management activity across not only 79 per cent of Australia but potentially 100 per cent offshore.

It is an act with enormous consequences—one of the most dramatic pieces of federal legislation ever—and we should be very careful about what is in it and what are its consequences. We obviously support heritage protection. Many Liberal governments have enacted heritage legislation. We believe the right place for that is in the Commonwealth heritage protection act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick
