SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does have some concerns here and does also raise a new concept in respect of compensation. We have a concern with the government's proposal because, as was reflected by evidence given to the parliamentary committee on the constitutionality of the native title bill, there are legiti mate reasons to have concern as to whether the government is providing under this legislation for just terms in the provision of compensation. I will go to the particular area that is of concern in just a few moments.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area of concern is that the government seems to be signing a blank cheque on behalf of Australian taxpayers when it comes to the range of matters that it is extinguishing and the amount that it may consequently cost taxpayers by bucket loads of gratuitous extinguishment. Unfortunately for the taxpayers, the Senate has already adopted many of those areas. Hopefully, we will not adopt others as the debate continues over the next few days.

In terms of just terms compensation, the law is somewhat clear. Section 51(xxxi) of the constitution provides that parliament has the power to make laws with respect to the acquisition of property on just terms from any state or person for any purpose which the parliament has the power to make the laws. In terms of such property, Mabo made it quite clear, as did Mr Justice McHugh in Waanyi, that native title rights are property rights. Justice McHugh said in the Waanyi case:

Parliament has laid down the law. It has attached valuable rights to an accepted claim, rights that are exercisable by a claimant before the validity of the claim is judicially determined. The Act has given claims of native title an economic as well as a spiritual and physical dimension.
This follows on from Justices Deane and Gaudron in Mabo No. 2 when they said:

Our conclusion that rights under common law native title are true legal rights which are recognised and protected by the law, would, we think, have the consequence that any legislative extinguishment of those rights would constitute an appropriation of property, to the benefit of the underlying estate, for the purposes of 51(xxxi).

What are the concerns with the government's position? For a start we are extinguishing when we do not have to. In terms of criticism of the government's position, many people have put it to the parliamentary committees over recent months, but it was probably very well expressed by Messrs Fajgenbaum and Moshinsky in their submission attached to the ATSIC submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. What they said is worth putting on the record here. They said:

The provisions of the NTAB [relating to the validation of `intermediate period acts', the `confirmation' of extinguishment of native title by previous exclusive or non-exclusive possession acts and the future act amendments] . . . would constitute an acquisition of property within the meaning of s 51(xxxi)—
and they cite the Newcrest Mining and the Commonwealth case of just a few months ago—

Although most of the provisions of the NTAB provide for compensation to be payable, it is arguable that, as there is no procedure for notifying holders of native title of their right to claim compensation, the compensation is not on "just terms". Such an argument is suggested by a passage from the judgment of Deane J in the Tasmanian Dam Case at 291, where he held that the procedure for obtaining compensation under s 17 of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 (Cth) was intrinsically unfair and therefore did not amount to the provision of compensation on just terms. At present, however, there is little authority to support such an argument.

The concern, therefore, from our side is not only whether the value of the compensation has to be on just terms but also that there needs to be a process of notification and, as some judges have said, more contemporaneous compensation for the compensation to be valid as to just terms. If you compare this regime, for instance, with what this parliament did with the acquisition of the property of gun owners, in that particular instance we were very keen to ensure that the compensation was paid on just terms and in a just process. This particular case I think is quite arguable and will be argued before the High Court before not too long that what the government is doing here is not meeting those two legs of the just terms requirements of the constitution.

Despite the rhetoric—and we will get it from Senator Minchin again—that there is no extinguishment, I think the explanatory memorandum of the government sets out their position. It makes it refreshingly frank that provisions dealing with permanent extinguishment, for instance, are a matter of government policy not necessarily reflecting the common law. In that particular instance, hopefully, we will be able to get an amendment to suppress rather than to permanently extinguish.

But that is just one area where I think the government has been a bit loose with the facts. The other question of concern is: what will the just terms be? Much evidence before the parliamentary committees went to the question of value taking into account the fact that it should be assessed from the perspective of the value of the loss to the native title holders rather than the commercial value of the property in question. The Queensland Land Tribunal Commissioner and Native Title Tribunal member, Graeme Neate, observed:

It seems that conventional valuation principles are either irrelevant or inappropriate to the assessment of compensation for native title (or, at least, those native title rights and interests which have no real property equivalent) then it may be necessary to develop new principles or approaches.

The Royal Australian Planning Institute and the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists in their background paper said that the valuer needs to take into account the special nature of indigenous people's relationships to land and concludes that the connection to the land `may involve responsibilities and mutual obligations between land and the people connected to it in ways not envisaged by Western systems of land ownership'.
The Native Title Tribunal has already had to address this matter, but not extensively. In the Koara determinations it regarded:
. . . any attempt to make a comparison by way of a percentage between the incidents of a particular native title and the incidents of a freehold title as artificial and arbitrary.

We had the Dunghutti people and the New South Wales government coming to an agreement in respect of Crescent Head where the value agreed to was 150 per cent of the agreed market value of the land, and so on. These points indicate to us that the government should not have embarked upon as extensive a regime of extinguishment, both direct and indirect, as it has. But it has done that. What we are concerned with now is to make amendments to ensure that the constitutional requirements are met—in so far as we can provide that in this place.

BREAK.PARA: Proposed sections 50 and 51 ensure that compensation is payable whether the act affecting native title is valid or invalid. Proposed section 51A removes the proposed artificial cap which limits the amount of compensation to the freehold value of the land. As I have already indicated, that is an inappropriate test; it needs to be more than that. The government says, `Oh well, there is a catch‐all provision later on to ensure that the requirements of the constitution are met.' But what we are saying is let us just have one clause which makes it very clear right from the start that the constitutional definition of `just terms' is what is appropriate, not a two‐step approach which provides compensation to the level of freehold under 51A and that claimants will then have to argue anything else under the act or at common law. We do not think that is a recipe for certainty at all. Why not just do it in one step?

Our proposed section 52 reverses the government's proposal to give to those paying into a trust fund a veto on whether the registered native title body corporate can accept the trust moneys in lieu of their entitlements under the act—in section 52(1). We are also concerned about this concept of a process to ensure that there is a contemporaneous payment of compensation, or as contemporaneous as possible.

We have a simplified claims process which is reflected in our new section 53A. Here we add a simplified procedure for claiming compensation where the costs incurred in making the claim are likely to be more than 20 per cent of the compensation that the claimant may receive, or the compensation is likely to exceed $50,000.

Proposed section 239 ensures that compensation for pastoral activity which extinguishes or impairs native title is payable by the government and not by individual pastoralists. We do so by amending the definition of `act attributable to the Commonwealth, a state or a territory'.

We think it is important to provide a fast‐track process. In doing so, we also think that it is important to have mechanisms in place to protect people. Our mechanisms for fast‐track determinations also allow for a capacity for governments to dispute such determination in the Federal Court, and to do so in circumstances where, if such a dispute is made, the government party which is disputing it is to pay the costs of the application of both sides.

We think it is a fair balance because, on the one hand, it provides a ready determination; on the other hand, we do not want those determinations to be frustrated by the process. We want governments to think seriously about trying to reverse them, particularly given that we are talking, in essence, of a small claims regime for the assessment and determination of the smaller claims in the system. If we get those out of the way, we can concentrate on the bigger ones.

We say it is balanced; we say it provides a degree of expedition which is quite necessary. It also provides one of those important beneficial aspects that is going to be quite necessary to this government's legislation being sustained against High Court challenges. They are the provisions we have put up. We think they are necessary because of not only the constitutional requirements but also fairness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain Democrat‐Greens (WA) amendments Nos 152, 153 and 154. Section 44H ensures that any valid activity authorised under the general law prevails over native title. However, this section of the bill is loosely drafted and requires tightening so that it will not overreach its purpose. We want to ensure that compensation available to native title holders is for activity under non‐exclusive pastoral or agricultural leases which may affect native title, but that the owner of the lease is not liable to pay the compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 155 is a minor consequential amendment. Amendment No. 156 provides clarification that compensation is payable whether the act affecting native title is valid or invalid. Amendment No. 157 will remove the proposed artificial cap on the amount of compensation.

Amendment No. 159 reverses the government's proposal to give the payers to trust funds a veto on whether the registered native title body corporate can accept the trust moneys in lieu of their compensation entitlements under the act. The trust funds would typically be paid by mining companies or governments under an agreement reached with registered native title claimants in the right to negotiate procedure prior to a determination being made. Under the current act, once a determination confirms that the native title party is indeed the native title holder, the registered native title body corporate can request the trust amount in lieu of its compensation entitlements under the act without needing the agreement of the body that paid the amount into the trust.

Amendment 158 is a consequential amendment. Amendments 160 and 191 are to simplify procedure for claiming compensation where the cost of the claim outweighs the likely compensation and make consequential changes to section 31(2) so that a determination is not required to be made if the compensation claim can use the simplified procedure. Amendment 179 ensures that compensation for pastoral activity which extinguishes or impairs native title is payable by the government not by individual pastoralists by amending the definition of `act attributable to the Commonwealth, the state or territory'.

Amendment 221 requires the government party to pay the native title party's costs of all reasonable compensation applications and deals with the power of the Federal Court to deal with compensation where there is no determination of native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments put by the Greens and Democrats in relation to compensation go along the same lines and in many cases are identical to those put up by the ALP. It is just a matter of wording or title in relation to amendments 192 and 160, even though they are supposedly in conflict. It matters not a great deal which of those are put.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me speak to either opposition amendment 192 or Greens‐Democrat amendment 160. This is an attempt to deal with a situation were the legal process itself acts as a deterrent to fairness. We are dealing with what can be called a small claim or a non- viable claim. We do not want a situation where the cost of obtaining justice becomes so prohibitive that justice becomes unavailable. It is a means of dealing with these issues quickly and inexpensively.

I urge the Senate to consider these amendments. The rest of the amendments in this section deal with the issue of fair compensation and just terms, not just the terms the government is prepared to provide for convenience. In particular I urge that those sections dealing with the ability to settle claims quickly and expeditiously are dealt with as well by the Senate as a fair and reasonable thing for reaching outcomes within the community processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask Senator Bolkus a question relating to his amendment? It is not so much in relation to his amendment, but in relation to the proposal that item 19 be deleted from schedule 1. It is a cap on total compensation under this division. Are you really saying that there is no need for these provisions in the legislation? Who are you suggesting will take matters into account and what are those matters?

SPEECH.PARA: You mentioned that, in the judgment, His Honour saying that there are other aspects which need to be taken into account and there may need to be a whole new way of looking at compensation. Yes, there are property rights, but there are also other interests that attach to native title rights. What are you really saying? Who makes those particular decisions? How is that to be determined? Are you going to leave it to the courts or what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are saying, Senator Harradine, is that, no matter what intention people may have, the constitution makes it very clear that you have to pay on just terms. Just terms has two aspects. One is the procedural aspect, and I put that aside for the purposes of this debate. It also has the aspect of what the actual monetary value will be.

SPEECH.PARA: What we say is that, in so far as the law has developed—it has not developed too far—and in so far as there are pointers from the courts, the tribunals, the Queensland Land Tribunal commissioners, the Royal Australian Planning Institute and the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists, the indication is quite substantially there that, when it comes to native title, just terms needs to take into account the mutual obligations, to quote the Royal Australian Planning Institute and the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists, between the land and the people connected to it. Because of the fact that the connection is in many respects much deeper, land is of different value to indigenous people and their connection to it is something that needs to be taken into account.

That is the view of the experts in the area. It is the view of the tribunal to the extent that it has been able to make a determination. The tribunal regarded `any attempt to make a comparison by way of a percentage between the incidence of a particular native title and the incidence of a freehold title as artificial and arbitrary.' Two points we can draw from the established legal principles and practices are, firstly, to tie it to freehold is inflexible and, secondly, to try to reflect it in another form of words is also not possible.

When one looks at western systems of valuation of freehold, for instance, one will see that they also take into account the personal interaction between a person and the land. In respect of compensation for indigenous rights, both domestically and internationally, there has been an acceptance that just terms means more than freehold value. There is a basket of considerations to be taken into account in respect of western land systems as well. As I say, you cannot quantify it and you cannot tie it to a benchmark. It has to be up to the system to make the determination.

What we are saying is that that system has to meet the benchmark that is in the constitution. That benchmark is just terms in terms of, in this case, value. We say that the tribunal and the court system should do that. Tribunals and court systems do that for any other Australian. To the extent that you provide an alternative system for indigenous people to get just terms compensation under the constitution which is different from your rights and my rights to get just terms compensation, then not only is it discriminatory, but also it does not meet the just terms provisions of the constitution.

We say that the government in its proposal is being a bit tricky and a bit devious. What they say in one of their clauses is that there is a freehold cap. What they also say further down in the act—don't hold me precisely to this but I think it is 53(a), but I am sure the minister will be able to tell us in a few moments—is that we have to meet those just terms provisions of the constitution.

What this two‐leg approach does is something that is hard to fathom. Why don't they, for instance, in that initial provision, provide that the just terms compensation is to be just terms as provided by the constitution? Why do they say freehold? My suspicion is that, from pursuing this particular clause, they can go out to the public and say, `We wanted to give them freehold but the other parties wanted to give them something more.' That is not honest in law; it is not honest in politics either.

There is absolutely no reason why the process has to have, as is provided in 51A, a freehold cap. What it must have is a just terms cap under the constitution. That is what we say should happen. Let the processes that the government suggests determine the compensation, but let that be an honest reflection of the constitutional requirement. Let there not be two steps in making that assessment. That is where the difference is, Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the ALP amendments and particularly in relation to Senator Harradine's question. I indicate that, in relation to these amendments, we do not think amendment No. 184 is necessary or adds anything, but we will not object to that amendment.
—Which one?
—Amendment No. 184.
—Gone soft?

—No, in the spirit of generosity. In relation to amendment No. 188, again, we are not quite sure what these things add, particularly the third part about entitlement to compensation arising where the loss results from a valid or invalid act. We would have thought that, as a matter of law, if damage flowed from the doing of an invalid act, compensation would be claimable as a matter of general law, and I guess Ernest Henry is an example of that right now. We think that, as a matter of general law, compensation can be claimed for the doing of invalid acts. But, on legal advice, we will not oppose amendment No. 188.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally, in relation to compensation, the act and the bill provide just terms compensation as is required by the constitution. The Solicitor‐General has given us clear advice that the bill meets all the constitutional requirements relating to just terms compensation. We have responded to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's suggestions in relation to notification and there are amendments to be moved throughout the bill in relation to notification for compensable acts. We have no doubt that we have in place a very comprehensive scheme in relation to compensation.
In relation, specifically, to other ALP amendments, we have some concern about 186 because of the potential problems there. It says to add (f) at the bottom of page 117:

(f) native title holders are entitled to compensation under this Act for the doing of any such activity payable by the Government party responsible for the grant, issue or creation of the lease, licence, permit or authority.

This is a bit difficult. Our understanding of the law is that the compensation right arises from the grant—the act being the grant of the right to do the thing—and that is what gives rise to the compensation. In respect of this provision, proposed section 44H, after (e), we have added:
Note: Any compensation to which the native title holders may be entitled under this Act for the grant of the lease, licence, permit or authority may take into account the doing of the activity.

We think that we are, in effect, ensuring that the compensation that flows from the grant should take account of the nature of the grant, and what activities will be engaged in as a result of the grant of the right to do the act, but this provision could have the consequence that compensation is claimable and payable every time someone does something under the grant. If you have a right, for example, to grow wheat every year, then every year the native title holders can come back and seek compensation for the doing of the act. At least it is not being sought from the farmer, but it is being sought from the government party.

We think that would be a hopeless legal mess and that what is appropriate is that, when the right to do the activity is granted and a compensation claim arises, the question of compensation is dealt with then. As we say, the issue of compensation, when it is dealt with, can take account of the nature of the rights granted and the doing of the activity. But to introduce a provision which could result in ongoing compensation claims and cases resulting from the doing of an activity forever, we think, is a very dangerous matter to contemplate and one we could not support.

Amendment 187, I think, revolves around the confirmation regime. We disagree and it is not acceptable. I have talked about amendment 188. Amendment 189 is the matter of the cap which Senator Bolkus has just referred to. This is, of course, a prima facie matter. It is a matter of prima facie law that the compensation payable should not exceed the amount that would be payable if the act were, instead, a compulsory acquisition of a freehold estate and the land or waters. We consider that the highest estate in our law is freehold. The sort of underlying premise of the Native Title Act is to equate native title with freehold for the purposes of dealing with native title and freehold is the appropriate estate to compare it with. It can amount to, ultimately, a freehold estate, which is the highest estate we recognise.

We think it is appropriate to set this cap in place in the legislation and that it should reflect the compensation payable if the native title amounted to freehold. Of course, it is not the market value of the freehold. As in the general law in relation to compulsory acquisitions, it can take account of not only the market value but also compensation for severance, injurious affection, disturbance, special value and solatium or other non‐economic loss. We are talking about the bundle of compensation payable for an acquisition of freehold.

Of course, as set out in 51A(2), the section has effect subject to section 53 of the current act, which deals with the requirement to provide just terms compensation. In other words, it is subject to that constitutional requirement to pay just terms compensation. So, to the extent that anyone bringing a claim for compensation believes that the compensation they would be paid if they instead held freehold does not amount to just terms compensation, or is less than what they believe to be just terms compensation, they have that right to pursue the additional compensation under the law. That is the catch‐all provision. We think it is appropriate to indicate in the act what we believe is the appropriate cap for compensation, but subject to the ultimate constitutional obligation to pay just terms if those just terms were argued to amount to more than the compensation payable if instead the native title holders held freehold.

Amendment 190 is just a change of definition in relation to moneys held on trust under the right to negotiate proceedings. It is currently referred to as negotiated compensation, which we think is not the correct terminology. This is moneys determined as payable by the arbitral body. In many cases it is held on trust pending a determination of native title when it is done through arbitration. Of course, the tribunal cannot make that ultimate determination.

So the government would simply change the name of that amount from `negotiated compensation' to `trust amount', because the money is held on trust pending a determination that the claimants hold native title. Of course, that is the scheme of the current act. We are simply changing the name of the amount to more properly reflect the nature of the moneys and the way in which they are held.

Amendment 191 opposes a change that we make which I will describe. The act currently provides in relation to that sort of money that, if there is a determination that native title exists, the holders can ask the trustee for the money to be paid to them, even if the person who paid it objects. Our bill amends this and provides that the money can only be paid directly to the determined native title holders if the person who paid it into trust agrees. Otherwise the court needs to determine whether this is in fact the proper amount of compensation. That, we think, is important to avoid any constitutional questions, and we think that provision should stand.

As for amendment 192—and I think Senator Bolkus referred to this before—it is again a well‐intentioned attempt to see if a small claims process can be put in place. But, again, I would have to say that, as with your fast-tracking propositions, we think this does not take full account of the full consequences of the Brandy decision and could be invalid under the Brandy principle because you are really providing for the tribunal to determine compensation. We do not see that is going to pass the Brandy test, or it certainly would have real difficulties in relation to that Brandy problem, of having an administrative body effectively determining compensation rights. While we are sympathetic to the notion that a small claims compensation process would be desirable, we are not sure how it could be done. These things must be handled judicially—and judiciously—and we do not believe there are sufficient guarantees in this that it would be free of the constitutional problems raised by Brandy for us to be able to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of points in reply. The first one is what Senator Minchin raises in respect of page 117—the question of whether compensation is to be paid for any activity. He raises one against the fear spectre of every time someone wants to grow wheat, they may have to pay compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: Our clause that he is concerned about is amendment 186 and I do not think he really understands it. What this clause is about is making sure the government party responsible for the issue or creation of the lease, licence or whatever is going to be responsible for making the payment. Senator Minchin says, `But they might be responsible for any such activity', but what we are doing here is putting (f) in after your (a) to (e), and the terminology we use for activities is the same as the one you use. It is not a matter of making annual payments; it is a matter of defining who is responsible for an activity. The government, for instance, in subclause 44H(c) says:
. . . the requirement or permission, and the doing of any activity—
The subsequent clause (d) reads:
. . . the doing of any activity—
And subsequent clause (e) reads:
. . . the doing of any activity—

What we say is that, in respect of the doing of any of those activities, it is the government that did those activities that should be responsible. If there are any flaws in our amendment, then you may have identified flaws in your proposal.

It is the activity that is compensatable. Whether it is the grant of the lease or whatever you say, we say it is the same activity that is compensatable. All amendment 186 does is make it clear that it is the issuing authority that is responsible for it and should pay the compensation for it. We often get diverted into minor matters here. In this case, I think if one were to look at the regime of the act, one would realise that we are probably wasting 10 minutes in respect of this particular provision. I ask you, Minister, to reconsider that while we are discussing the rest of your concerns.

A more fundamental concern is proposed sections 51A and 53. You say that the appropriate cap should be the freehold test. The constitution says that the appropriate cap should be the just terms requirement. Why don't you have just terms in 51A? No matter how often we say that, you say, `It is the government's position that people should be told that we believe the freehold test is the appropriate one.' As we have already indicat ed in this debate, the freehold test to date has not been seen to be the appropriate maximum level. All you are asking here is for this clause to be struck down. Why do that? There is absolutely no valid constitutional or moral reason for you to put a cap in this legislation which is not consistent with the constitutional requirement.

Another concern that we have—and this is the most fundamental—is what level of compensation under your legislation the states will have to pay if in fact there is an act of acquisition which is compensatable. Is proposed section 51A there to ensure that the only compensation the states have to pay is the maximum level of freehold? You can take that on notice. If that is not the case, can you tell us what level of compensation the states will have to pay? Another concern we have is that the states may have to pay up to a certain level and then the poor old applicant would have to seek the top up, so to speak, to get his or her constitutional rights from a second proceeding.

This is one of the most difficult areas of your legislation to understand. There is no need for it, and that is why we think you should come straight, take the constitutional requirement, and accept it. In terms of other amendments that you have concerns about, you said that amendment No. 184 is all right. We have discussed amendment No. 186. I think amendment No. 185 would be no problem to you. That amendment ensures that native title holders are not entitled to claim compensation from the owner of the lease.

If we really want to get this bill through by Christmas or the New Year, some of these provisions could easily be picked up. You have discussed amendment No. 188. You have not indicated whether you will support it, but I hope you do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has indicated that he supports it.

—Good. Amendment No. 189 is about the cap. Amendment No. 190 reverses the government's proposal to give the payers to trust funds a veto on whether the registered native title body corporate can accept the trust money in lieu of its compensation entitlements under the act. Such trust funds would typically be paid by mining companies or governments, under an agreement reached with the registered claimants in the right to negotiate procedure, prior to a determination of native title being made.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the current section 52, once a determination confirms that the native title party is indeed the native title holder, the registered native title body corporate can request the trust amount in lieu of the compensation entitlements under the act, without needing the agreement of the body that paid the amount into the trust. We are preserving requirements for just terms to be paid in respect to amendment No. 190. I would not have thought that was a problem.

You then go to the fast‐tracking compensation provision. You make the claim, again, that we do not satisfy the Brandy requirements, but you do so without evidence. Let me go to the opposition's amendment in respect of what we think is a pretty important proposal; one which will satisfy just terms in that it provides the compensation at an appropriate time, in a timely manner and with the least possible cost.

Your concern here is Brandy. If you look at page 21 of our amendments, you will find that we satisfy the Brandy requirements. We got advice from at least two Queen's Counsels that we satisfy the Brandy requirements. I would rather have the Senate take on trust the advice of Queen's Counsels Basten and Castan, than Senator Minchin saying, `Well, we think it is unconstitutional. It doesn't meet the Brandy test.'

The process embodied in clause 53A is that a claimant lodges a claim for compensation in respect of an act in the Federal Court—so there has to be a claim in the Federal Court. That is the first point. Our clause 53A(1)(b) says that a claimant must:
. . . seek from the Court an order that the matter be referred to the Tribunal for determination in accordance with such directions as the Court may think appropriate. . .

It is in the control of the Federal Court. The court then sends it off for someone to make a determination on what may be appropriate, and it then comes back to the court. The court must make the order sought if it is satisfied in respect of a number of matters.

That unequivocally satisfies Brandy, and your advice should be that it satisfies Brandy. I will not be diverted this time from the fact that we have the advice of eminent Queen's Counsels on this point. These Queen's Counsels have run and won these cases in superior jurisdictions. Under our amendments, it is in the control of the court, the court takes charge of it from the start, and it comes back to the court. The court may make all sorts of directions in respect to referral to the tribunal.

I suggest to the Senate that we are proceeding on good ground here. I also suggest that we are proceeding on better ground than we are in general as to the constitutionality of the government's legislation. The government does not have nine out of 11 QCs saying that this particular proposal is unconstitutional. Nine out of 11 QCs who appeared before the Senate committee said that your proposal in total was unconstitutional. I go back to my earlier point: with a bit of constructive thinking you should be able to pick this up if you really want to, but I do not think you really want to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If only predictions about which way the High Court would go could be so easily satisfied by mathematical equations of that kind—just saying that because nine out of 11 said this or that it means this. Most of them said that, if the High Court were to find that the races power of the constitution can only be used for benefit, then that might follow. It was a most extraordinarily hedged opinion—but I do not want to get into that. We have clear advice from the Solicitor‐General on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: You are the ones who keep saying when in doubt do not do it in relation to the constitution. We think there is doubt about this proposition. Your amendment No. 192, in the small compensation claims section, provides a direction to the court in 53A(2) which says that the court must make the order sought if it is satisfied of (a) to (e). That is a direction to the court. The legal advice I have is that there must be some doubt about that provision and whether it satisfies the Brandy requirements. On that ground alone, we are not prepared to accept that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you be prepared to accept a further amendment to leave it at the discretion of the court at that particular stage? If that is your only concern, we can very easily fix it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not prepared to support amendments being put into this act where we are not absolutely clear—and I am acting on legal advice that it is not absolutely clear—that these provisions would comply with the constitutional requirements in relation to judicial determinations. Given the doubt about it, I am not in a position to accept those amendments on behalf of the government because it still leaves the tribunal with what we regard as judicial determining capacity. We think there is sufficient doubt there.

SPEECH.PARA: We still think you have a problem. It is all right for you, Senator Bolkus, to just assure us that your provision in relation to the new F in section 44 does not have the effect you say. We are not satisfied. We think it leaves it at least open to doubt that compensation could be claimable every time there is doing of activity in giving effect to the requirement or permission. You have to read (e) where it says:
native title holders are not entitled to compensation under this Act for the doing of any activity in giving effect to the requirement or permission.

That is the nature of the doing of the activity. What we are saying is that it is the grant of the right to do it that is the thing that gives rise to the compensation—and that is payable by the government. We say that in determining the compensation you should take account of the doing of activity in determining the compensation settlement. But your provision does leave it open to argue that compensation can be payable every time something is done in giving effect to the requirement or permission. So we think there is again sufficient doubt about the legal effect of what you are proposing as to render it unable to be accepted by us.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to just terms, again you are not reading the provisions. The 51A limit on compensation makes it clear in (2) that this section has effect subject to section 53, which remains. That is the section in the act which deals with the requirement to provide just terms compensation, and that would apply to any compensation payable under this division, whether by a state, territory or the Commonwealth. So they are subject to that just terms compensation provision, but we do not think it unreasonable to indicate to the taxpayers of Australia, who pay the compensation, that their liability prima facie has a cap which should not exceed the total compensation payable if it were freehold. I think the taxpayers of Australia, who do pay all this out of their tax money, do have a right for this parliament to give an indication of what it believes is an appropriate level of compensation. But, as we are required to by the constitution, we do ensure that where a claimant believes that their right to compensation would exceed that they have recourse to the constitutional requirement to pay just terms compensation if they believe just terms is more than the total amount that would be payable if they instead held freehold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am responding to those three points. In respect of the last one, what you are really saying is that you want to mislead the public of Australia: you want to tell them you believe that only the freehold value will be paid when you know full well that just terms is more than freehold. If you want to embark on that campaign of dishonesty, go ahead. But the constitutional requirement on this place is to get the law right and to ensure just terms. You have absolutely no case in respect of that.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of your second point—the concerns you have about having to pay compensation for any grain of wheat that is grown in any year or whatever—our paragraph (f) refers to `any such activity'. `Any such activity' refers to the activities that your paragraphs (a) to (e) refer to. Our paragraph (f) follows on and is under your 44H. If this is the best legal advice you could get, maybe you need a bit more assistance. Our paragraph (f) follows on from (a) to (e). `Any such activity' there has got to be read in the context of the activities that you provide for in section 44H. It is a lot of legal bunkum, with no respect to the people putting it forward. In fact, my tolerance is actually worn out in respect of this issue because we have actually gone through it methodically. I do not think you have any case at all.

In respect of your other point in respect of the fast-track compensation I indicate that, at this particular stage, in moving amendment 192, page 21 of our amendments, 53A(2), instead of that section reading `The court must make the order', I seek leave to move that in an amended form to read `The court may make the order.' It is a change of one word. It picks up the concerns of the government. The government should have absolutely no problem in picking it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raised, as he always does, a very pertinent point about what forms of compensation there are. On the matter that Senator Bolkus has been dealing with: putting the cap on at a freehold level seems to indicate that it is the value of the property that must be taken into account. Yet, as I understand it, the government has made provisions for a solatium to be paid. Is it consistent with 51(29) to pay compensation, say, for people's psychological health being prejudiced? I know that the common law does not allow compensation for grief or sorrow, but it does allow compensation for psychological impairment arising from an act. If just terms included that, and if somebody with a great spiritual attachment to the land had a psychological reaction to the interference with that land and, as a result of that, had to take a period of time off work and had to have medication, would that be part of the just terms? If that is not so, why is it not so if the government is willing to pay a solatium in addition to the value of the property acquired?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, what we are saying is that it should not exceed the amount that would be payable if the act were instead a compulsory acquisi tion of a freehold estate. In other words, we are saying that if it were freehold that was being acquired, then obviously the acquisition freehold extends beyond simply the market value and takes account of the sort of factors you are describing in reaching a determination. So it is saying that if you are acquiring the native title rights and interests in a particular area then you take account of not only the market value at a freehold level of that land but also all the other factors which are regularly taken into account when a government compulsorily acquires freehold land.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the matters which I listed before, which are no doubt well known to you. We are saying that it is not simply the market value but all those other factors which a state would be required to take account of in determining the compensation payable for a compulsory acquisition. I repeat that this would be subject to section 51A(2)—the ultimate requirement to pay just terms. Any native title holder who felt that a payment in accordance with the cap on the amount payable, if it was a compulsory acquisition of freehold, did not meet just terms, would have that legal right to pursue the difference.

There has not been a contested native title compensation claim, as far as I am aware. The amount agreed to be paid in Crescent Head was essentially, as I understand it, paid on the basis that it was a compulsory acquisition of freehold, but that was by agreement, so we do not yet know what a contested claim for compensation in relation to native title might amount to in a court case. We leave that open to the courts ultimately to determine.

I appreciate Senator Bolkus's frustration that we have bogged down on this point, but these are important matters. We have a particular problem with paragraph (f). We think that does leave it open for compensation to be payable for the doing of the activity in giving effect to the requirement or permission. Sure, that is the point; you do have to read (f) in the context of (a) to (e). Paragraph (e), to ensure that this does not become an issue, says:
(e) native title holders are not entitled to compensation under this Act for the doing of any activity in giving effect to the requirement or permission.
Then (f) contradicts that by saying:
(f) native title holders are entitled to compensation . . . for the doing of any such activity . . .
We think that is confusing, contradictory and gives rise to the notion that compensation may be payable by the government every time the activity is undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, your note at the bottom of page 117 of the bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: Any compensation to which the native title holders may be entitled under this Act for the grant of the lease, licence, permit or authority may take into account the doing of the activity.

You already provide for that to be taken into account by the process. We are proposing the insertion of paragraph (f) before that note, the purpose of which is to allocate responsibility for the compensation, not to give a new right of compensation. Paragraph (f) basically determines who is to pay for it—which state or federal authority. We are saying that the compensation that is to be payable is in respect of any of those activities listed in section 44H. It does not matter how many times you want to repeat it; it will not overcome that basic point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to keep adding to the matter, but we are not satisfied that you understand the consequences of what you are proposing. Yes, our note is there. We would have thought it was sufficient to meet the concerns of the opposition. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Any compensation to which the native title holders may be entitled under this Act for the grant—
I emphasise `for the grant'—
of the lease, licence, permit or authority may take into account the doing of the activity.

Your paragraph (f) entertains the dangerous proposition that compensation is payable directly for the doing of the activity, not as a consequence of the grant of the right to do it. There is a very big difference, and that is the fundamental problem with your paragraph (f). We will obviously agree to disagree and we will put it to a vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister clarify what he considers is the freehold value of a national park or nature reserve?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, every day there is a market value for land. A state, in reaching agreement or seeking settlement of a compensation matter, would say, `Let's treat that national park'—if this is your question—`as though it were freehold land and determine its current market value,' and then add, in respect of normal compulsory acquisition, as always occurs now, compensation for additional matters—severance, injurious affection, disturbance, special values, solatium and other non‐economic loss. So it is taking the land, determining, based on current market values, what it would be worth if it were freehold, adding appropriate compensation for those matters and proposing that that be the compensation payable.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that ordinary Australians would regard that as absolutely fair and appropriate. Otherwise, you are suggesting that in all respects native title is worth a lot more than freehold. In some cases it may be, and that is provided for by section 51A(2) which says that that provision is subject to the constitutional requirements to pay just terms compensation. We do not think it at all inappropriate to indicate in section 51A(1) the cap we propose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed section 51A(1) makes sense if what the compensation consists of is the value of the land. But as the government has just said, it includes all sorts of other things, including if somebody goes into a deep depression for three or four years, has four years loss of wages and all sorts of medical bills—and perhaps, on top of that, an allowance for pain and suffering. Then you have the situation where the freehold value of the land might be $5,000, but as a result of that being acquired, a person has such a reaction that he or she loses $300,000 or $400,000.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that a psychological illness can be triggered off by a very minor event. It seems to me that the whole concept set out in section 51A does not miss the point. If you say, `What we really mean is only the value of the land,' you may well be looking at the phrase `just terms' in the wrong way. You might wonder from the information whether it is right. When you are measuring damages, you look at the special damages, which are loss of wages and medical bills, and then the general damages, which consist of an assessment of the loss of wages in the future plus the pain and suffering in the meantime and the pain and suffering in the future. It would all be done on medical evidence and could be worth hundreds of thousands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. If that is the case, it is the case for the native title holders as well. They can equally seek compensation in those terms. This is to enable some basis upon which, hopefully, agreements can be reached as to compensation, as agreement was reached in Crescent Head, where the basis for the agreement was the freehold value with the additional matters taken into account. Basically, they said that if it was freehold, they would pay in compensation. That was agreed to. To the extent that agreement cannot be reached on that basis, the native title holders have recourse to their constitutional right to just terms compensation if they believe that it exceeds the amount set down.
—Would it be reasonable to say that, under the constitution, the assessment of damages, particularly for the personal injuries that might follow, would have to be assessed by a jury?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a matter for the native title holders if they wish to contest the proposed compensation on the grounds that it did not comply with either the act or the constitution. That is their legal right.

—It seems that we are being asked to accept that native title rights equate to perhaps the lowest claim on land in relation, for instance, to freehold on pastoral leases, if such were to occur. Can the minister tell us what he knows of the average prices for pastoral leases in Western Australia? What estimates have been made of what the price per hectare of land would be on a freehold pastoral lease?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are simply asserting is that the compensation payable can amount to the highest estate we know, which is freehold. It is the highest estate in our system of law. The cap for compensation is equivalent to that. The whole Native Title Act is premised on the basis of how native title should be dealt with in our system of law and land management. The prima facie position is that you equate it to freehold. That is the whole basis of the freehold test. We are simply saying in relation to compensation that that is the appropriate cap, subject to the constitution.

—I understand, however, that in a case where it is a freehold pastoral area, if the calculations were made, basically you would be saying that it would be the value of this land for running sheep or cattle. The per hectare value of this land for running sheep or cattle would be the appropriate compensation mechanism for people's loss of their religious base, their life and their whole understanding of themselves. The appropriate compensation for the loss of that would be based on the freehold price of the land for, for instance, running sheep or cattle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are saying that the freehold value of the land, if the land were freehold, is the prima facie measure of compensation. The native title holders have every legal right to assert that their native title is worth considerably more than that. They have the legal right to have that proposition enforced by a court under these provisions and as a consequence of the constitution.

—Quite clearly, that is not actually part of the legislative process. It is something that people have to do separately. They have to go to the expense and risk of going to a court to fight for that because it is not provided for in process in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —But compensation claims are made to courts. Compensation is determined by a court. There is a requirement to pay compensation where an act is done. The government doing the act is then required to pay the compensation. In seeking compensation or an order in respect of compensation, where the amount proposed is, in the views of the recipients, inadequate, they have recourse to the courts. That is the way that compensation matters work. If you believe that the compensation paid does not represent just terms or in other respects does not meet the requirements of the legislation, you have recourse to the courts to enforce your legal right to just terms compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand and can accept the minister's response relating to amendment No. 186. Amendment No. 188, as I understand it, is agreed to, so I will not go into it. On amendment No. 189, could I just raise this point: it has been stated repeatedly in this debate that just terms compensation involves procedural questions as well as the entitlement to particular compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: When I saw this originally I thought it was not a bad start. The government is saying that the compensation will be as though the act was a compulsory acquisition of a freehold estate in the land or waters. Interestingly enough, last night when we were dealing with the procedural questions on opposition amendment No. 100 we did agree that, when it came to procedural rights in relation to services to the public on particular native title land, those procedural rights should be as though the land were ordinary title. That was actually adopted by the committee. I was interested to see that the government was using freehold estate in land in this particular provision.

I hope that the minister could indicate to us in respect of 51A whether he is saying that the government is not closing off the ability of persons who believe that there are other principles of compensation than for the value of the land and that these then, pursuant to section 53, can be dealt with in another way. I suppose he means through the courts.

I am somewhat attracted to the opposition's amendment relating to small compensation claims. What I would like to ask the minister, in respect of new clause 53A as proposed by the opposition is: if small compensation claims were absolutely not to be regarded as invalid by the application of the Brandy test, is the proposal attractive to the minister? Is the proposal attractive to the government? If it is not attractive to the government, then could the government please advise the committee why it is not? I thought the minister indicated that the government was interested in such a scheme as this. If it is, why not at least go along with this? If there is some reason other than the Brandy reason, why not just go along with it? Isn't it an advance if it is valid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of 51A, we are saying that the cap should be the amount that would be payable if it were instead a compulsory acquisition of a freehold estate. That typically means more than the market value of the freehold as the cap but that claimants have a legal right to pursue greater compensation if they believe the compensation payable to them should exceed that under section 53, which is an entitlement to just terms compensation in accordance with the constitution. Their legal rights are preserved in that provision.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the small compensation claims, based on legal advice—I am not trying to be churlish—we are not satisfied that this process that is set down here, which intimately involves the tribunal, does escape entirely the Brandy problems. It is a matter of policy as to how this might be dealt with in the future. Perhaps that is something that could be looked at down the track. We are not prepared to accommodate a provision on the run which could well have potential constitutional problems. I would have thought the opposition would be the first to suggest that should be the case.

There has been discussion in the past in Australia from both sides about a lower level Federal Court. It is one of the problems with the ever expanding range of laws coming through this place. With the load on the Federal Court structure, I am not sure how federal judges do cope. All 670 native title cases are about to land on their desk as well as everything else. I would hope in a bipartisan way that a lower court structure at the federal level could be developed. That would be an obvious mechanism by which matters of this kind can be dealt with.

The fact is that, in relation to the Brandy decision, we believe that decisions as to the existence of native title and compensation for impact or extinguishment on native title is a judicial function and can be performed only by a court. There is real doubt about this mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of points. I probably do not need to restate it but the advice for the last point has come from the people who actually ran the pioneering Mabo and Wik cases in the courts. Their track record, matched against others, I am sure would be recognised as being enormously successful. The first question you were asked was: in respect of what level of compensation payable are you leaving the door open for more than freehold? If anyone were to pursue any claim for compensation over and above freehold, where would they make that claim?
—In the Federal Court.

—So they would not be able to exercise the claim for just terms compensation, in the first instance, in the same way that they would be able to claim for up to the freehold value? In terms of the freehold value compensation, your 51A, where can they seek a claim for that determination? They seek a claim under the act for that determination, but they would have to start new proceedings, wouldn't they, to seek the just terms compensation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to a court proceeding seeking compensation, they can claim whatever they believe they are entitled to. If they believe that they are entitled to more than the value, or the compensation they would receive if it was a compulsory acquisition of freehold, then that can be their statement of claim. The obligation is on parties to pay compensation where they do things that affect native title or extinguish native title. So the obligation to pay resides with the government. If the native title holders believe that their compensation should be greater than the compensation would amount to if it was a compulsory acquisition of freehold, then they have the right to pursue that.

—I suppose we can anticipate a constitutional case there, can we? You could maybe take that as the first question. Can you tell me which part of your legislation provides that states have to pay just terms compensation for any act that they perform as opposed to the freehold value?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —All the provisions in the act in relation to just terms compensation apply to both state and federal governments, who are ultimately obliged to pay just terms compensation.

—I was going to ask a similar question. What is the point of having in your legislation a provision that it should be based on the price of freehold land if what you are suggesting will have no effect and people can claim for other values?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did speak to that subject when speaking to the opposition amendments. We do believe it is appropriate to include in the act an indication of what we believe is the appropriate prima facie cap on native title. The taxpayers of Australia who are responsible for paying from their salaries the taxes that will ultimately meet this compensation, as and when it arises, have a right to know what the parliament presumes to be an appropriate level of compensation. I do not think that is unreasonable at all. I think we have an obligation to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a constitution, of course, which overrides anything that we say here. It does provide that just terms compensation is payable. To the extent that native title holders are entitled to compensation, and it is their assertion as a matter of law that just terms for them amounts to more than they would be paid if instead they hold freehold land, then they have that legal right.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it is now appropriate that we deal with the amendments. Senator Bolkus, could you move amendments 184 and 188.

Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
(192) Schedule 1, page 120 (after line 9), after item 26, insert:

TAB.TAB: Insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) If a claimant lodges a claim for compensation in respect of an act in the Federal Court, the claimant may:

TAB.TAB: (a) place before the Court such material as he or she thinks fit for the purpose of establishing to the requisite degree of satisfaction that, unless alternative procedures are directed, it would not be reasonable for the claimant to pursue the claim, given the likely amount of compensation available; and
(b) seek from the Court an order that the matter be referred to the Tribunal for determination in accordance with such directions as the Court may think appropriate, and
(c) seek such directions as the claimant considers appropriate.

PARA.TAB: (2) The Court may make the order sought if it is satisfied that:

TAB.TAB: (a) there is available to the applicant prima facie evidence of the existence of the native title rights and interests in relation to which compensation is sought; and
(b) there is prima facie evidence that the applicant or at least some of the native title group have a connection by their traditional laws and customs with the land or waters in question, and
(c) there is not unequivocal evidence that all of those native title rights and interests have been extinguished, and
(d) either:
(i) the likely amount of the compensation is not expected to exceed the likely cost of maintaining and prosecuting the claim in the Court by more than 50%, or
(ii) the likely amount of that compensation available to the native title group is unlikely to exceed $50,000 (or a greater prescribed amount); and
(e) the claim can be dealt with more efficiently, cost effectively and expeditiously by the Tribunal than by the Court.

PARA.TAB: (3) If the Court directs that the claim be referred to the Tribunal, the Tribunal may:

TAB.TAB: (a) make a finding that native title rights and interests exist or existed for the purposes of determining compensation where the Tribunal is so satisfied, on a prima facie basis; and

(b) adopt such procedures as it wishes in relation to the determination of value of compensation payable, including obtaining evidence at its own expense and limiting the extent to which expert evidence may be tendered and may be the subject of challenge by parties other than the claimants; and
(c) determine the compensation payable.

PARA.TAB: (4) The Tribunal must not make a determination of the kind mentioned in paragraph (3)(c) if the party that would be responsible for paying the compensation proves that the native title rights and interests did not exist.
(5) If a claim is referred to the Tribunal by the Court in accordance with this section, the Tribunal:

TAB.TAB: (a) is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence; and
(b) must formulate its own procedures so as to minimise any legal expenses involved for the parties; and
(c) may direct the Government party to meet any reasonable costs of the claimants as seem appropriate, including the costs of obtaining expert evidence as to value; and
(d) must take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, and
(e) may include in the compensation payable any reasonable costs incurred by the claimants.

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee
SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 179 is to schedule 1, page 131, and says:
. . . (after line 10), after item 45, insert:

SPEECH.PARA: Also at the end of section 239 it adds:

TAB.TAB: or
(d) any person pursuant to a grant, licence, permission or authority made or given under a law of the Commonwealth, the State or the Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: My original explanation was not very clear, so I will attempt to give my understanding of it. Part of the concern that has been presented is that there are acts that have occurred that are not simply by the Commonwealth, the state or the territory. Remember that, when we talked about the ability of people to make claims, we talked about the fact that some of those acts occurred which were not just simply provisions of states or Commonwealth or even the granter of a lease.

So on my understanding this is spreading the net a little wider so that, when we have a situation of compensation, we are not just talking about compensation for acts that were performed or enacted by governments; we are talking about where individuals undertook acts which were allowed by governments and still created that situation where compensation should reasonably be expected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have those words in front of me, but in responding to what was just put, we think it absolutely fundamental to this whole process—and this is reflected in the current act itself now—that compensation is payable by governments which authorise activities which impact on native title. To move quite dramatically to a completely different situation where individuals, not governments, are liable for compensation for lawfully doing things permitted by governments is a completely unacceptable departure from the whole scheme of the act and the whole relationship between governments authorising activities which affect native title.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought this is taking us into a whole new realm where individuals going about their lawful business are liable to compensation in respect of native title. That responsibility must and should lie with governments. I put to you in a sort of philosophical or social sense that any departure from that would have quite adverse and significant ramifications.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why the opposition did not propose or accept this amendment—we initially considered it—was that it was a bit broad. That is still our view at the moment.
