TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environ ment, Senator Hill. Can you confirm the report you would no doubt have heard on radio Triple J this morning that Australia is now the only developed country not to have spelt out a greenhouse reduction target? Why is this so? Doesn't parliament and the Australian public have a right to know what position the government is taking on such an important international issue? Have you got a position? If so, when do you propose to reveal it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I was listening to FM classic this morning. I missed that story, although I did read it in some of the press. I guess that the press probably reflects what was on the ABC. Our position is, of course, as I have said before on a number of occasions, that we want to be part of a good Kyoto outcome. That is one that takes significant steps towards stabilising greenhouse gases in the atmosphere at the 1990 levels, and hopefully in the future to go even beyond that. We are prepared to accept a fair share of the burden in doing that.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable senator is probably aware, the projected business as usual graph from 1990 onwards had Australian emissions at something over 40 per cent. Through initiatives that have been taken—some of them started by the previous government and built upon by us, and to some extent by the community picking up the challenge—there have now been significant reductions to that business as usual graph. On the basis of a comprehensive test less land use, they are now projected to be about 28 per cent by the year 2010. So it is a significant reduction of emissions from what had been anticipated.

The Prime Minister has announced a package of initiatives which will have the effect of further reducing that emission load—a reduction down to about 18 per cent. If, of course, we are successful in getting land use taken into account in Kyoto we can do significantly better than that, because land use made up a significant proportion—I think some 24 per cent—of our 1990 figure and gives us great scope at reasonable cost to improve our performance. Land clearing in Australia is slowing and is anticipated to slow further. So emissions of greenhouse gas to the atmosphere can show very major improvement.

We are seeking a formula which we think is not only fair but best represents the environmental picture, that is, one that includes the six primary greenhouse creating gases which are not agreed by some states—the Europeans will only have three and Japan will only have three, because it suits their circumstances. We can do very substantially better if we can get the full list of gases; if we can get a proper accounting for sinks—and we are planning to triple the size of our plantation forests in Australia by the year 2020; if we can get land use included in the terms I have just been talking about; if we can implement the Prime Minister's initiatives, which include going beyond no regrets of the previous government to reforms that will actually require an extra economic cost; and if we can include a willingness to go down a regulatory path that some of the other parties in this negotiation have not been prepared to take.

We have in mind what that bottom line figure is. It does depend on these varying circumstances and we will use that bottom line figure as we believe appropriate to best enable us to achieve our objectives. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the chairman of the Kyoto conference, Raoul Estrada, has stated that unless Australia agrees to a reduction target, we will be out of the climate change protocol? Is this a situation the government would seriously contemplate? Has the government undertaken an analysis of any political or economic costs such international isolation would entail?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Estrada did not say that at all. He said, `Let's assume the possibility is not compatible.' The senator should read what he says, not what the press says he said. In other words, he does not discount a resolution in Kyoto—a protocol that will accommodate us.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, he did not mention Australia, as was suggested in some of the press. He did refer to a figure of 18 per cent, so we know that he was not referring to Spain. He was not referring to Spain, because Spain is to get a 40 per cent increase. He was not referring to Greece, because Greece is to get a 30 per cent increase. He was not referring to Ireland, because Ireland is to get a 15 per cent increase—all of which the European Union says is legitimate.

I would commend the Russian initiative. Russia says, `Let's look at a bubble that includes all the annexe one states. Look at what should be the reduction for business as usual and get each state to pay a fair share.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. As the minister would be aware, the government has focused on resolving issues of major significance to indigenous people—health, education and housing—committing $1.6 billion to these disadvantaged communities. In the area of housing, what progress has been made in improving living conditions and health opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

—I thank Senator McGauran for an important question. This government has clearly identified its approach to Aboriginal reconciliation. It is based on our determination to address meaningfully the appalling and the unacceptable state which the Labor Party left Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, housing and education. We have maintained the current level of funding to indigenous housing at $91 million a year and that was quarantined from savings within the overall Commonwealth-state housing agreement. We are also providing $210 million a year to ATSIC for housing and infrastructure. We have negotiated successfully with the state and territory governments for an increase in their contributions to indigenous housing under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. For example, it was $2 million in 1994-95; it is now $40 million in 1996-97. That is what has happened under our government in cooperation with the states and territories.

BREAK.PARA: In Launceston in April I convened the first housing ministers' conference ever in Australia's history dedicated solely to indigenous housing issues. That meeting resulted in agreement from all housing ministers to give high priority to ensuring better health outcomes from housing. That included an enhanced focus on housing maintenance, which is badly needed; an agreement to a voluntary rent deduction scheme from social security payments which will enable indigenous housing organisations to improve rent collections and thereby the maintenance of housing; and the development of a national training strategy to provide support to indigenous housing organisations in housing management. We agreed with the states and territories to develop a building code which is suitable for indigenous housing in remote communities to ensure that the houses are built to be sustainable. We shifted the focus from build and forget to build, maintain and sustain to ensure that water, power and sewerage facilities are fully maintained.

The states have already advised me of their support for the Launceston agreement. For example, the Northern Territory minister wrote to me saying, `It's a very welcome change in Commonwealth policy.' He added, `Accordingly, I fully support the strategic directions that you have identified.' The Australian people can rest assured that we will focus on practical solutions which will deliver real and measurable improvements for indigenous people, unlike the Labor Party and Graham Richardson and his TV crew that pointed to the tap, and that was supposed to fix indigenous housing issues.

Under our government, with the efforts we are putting into place, I want to see that indigenous mothers are able to bath their children, wash their clothes, wash their utensils, have toilets that work, drains that drain and hot water services that are sturdy and reliable. If ever the honour of our country was at stake, it is in how we set about improving the health of our indigenous children and their parents. It is not a question of reminding the Senate of the indolence of the previous Labor government in these areas—all talk and no action. Our efforts in the housing area are dedicated to the goal of improving the health outcomes of indigenous families. We have set out on the track that was ignored for 13 years under Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The Senate was told during the November estimates that the government intended to respond to the stolen children report, Bringing them home , by the end of the year. Given that we are now in the final month of 1997 and given the Prime Minister's renewed commitment to reconciliation in his address to the nation, can you advise the Senate if it is still the government's intention to provide its formal response by the end of the year? If so, when? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator West for the question. Yes, I will be responding by the end of the year on behalf of the government. The reason for the little delay is that we the government are consulting Aboriginal people in the delivery of the outcome of that report. We have consulted with Aboriginal people in the delivery of that report and it will be good news for the Aboriginal people of this country. It will be an outstanding response. It will have input from many quarters. We are consulting with as many people as possible. I apologise that I have not been in touch with the churches yet, but I will be consulting with the churches as to their views.
—You have been in touch with Frank Brennan.

—Perhaps, as Senator Collins suggests, I might even ring Father Frank Brennan to ask what his contribution will be to the report. I can assure Senator West that, yes, we will be producing a good response to that report. It will be produced by the end of the year, but currently we are consulting with indigenous people for their input in relation to the delivery of the response.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that you have less than 30 days in which to do that, Minister, when will you be doing that? I take it that it is not true then that cabinet has approved the government's response to the report and that you have deliberately delayed the tabling of the response so as not to compound the problems caused by the government's handling of the native title debate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I refute that suggestion, but that is the usual knocking that we get from the other side. They were in government for 13 years while those shameful practices occurred and condoned them. Now they are questioning us about the government's response. It is the ultimate hypocrisy. I will be producing a good response as soon as possible before the end of the year.

—My question is addressed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the minister outline problems experienced by the mining industry as a result of the continuing uncertainty surrounding native title? What impact is the statutory right to negotiate having on the mining industry which contributes $36 billion in exports and wealth generation in Australia each year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for that question. There has been considerable discussion about the right to negotiate, which, to some degree, is based on misunderstanding about what it actually is. The so-called right to negotiate is a special statutory right given under Labor's failed 1993 Native Title Act to native title holders and to registered native title claimants—I might say, not necessarily valid native title holders. It is about mining and compulsory acquisitions that benefit third parties. It is not a native title right decided by the High Court. No other Australians have such a right, whether they be the holders of freehold or leasehold titles. I think that is worth repeating: no other Australians have this right.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Native Title Act was passed it was expected to apply mostly on vacant crown land and/or Aboriginal land. Now it affects around 79 per cent of Australia's land area, including pastoral lease land. The Australian minerals development industry's experience with the right to negotiate is that in practice it means delays and attempts to gain benefits above and beyond those available to other people in the community and which may not have anything whatsoever to do with native title.

What has happened in practice? Former Labor leader and Governor‐General, Bill Hayden, personally involved with the right to negotiate process in the Century mine, saw its practical operation very clearly. He used words like: `opportunities for outside manipulation', `measures which come perilously close to being extortion', `seemingly unlimited opportunities to register as claimants', and `rampant confusion and tension from factional and family disputes at the expense of the issues to be settled'. And the talking went on for over three years.

In Western Australia, some right to negotiate processes began up to 33 months ago and are still without resolution. There are as many as 13 overlapping claims over individual mineral titles. How can an industry grow and develop with this confusion and uncertainty? In Western Australia now there are over 9,000 land titles being delayed by this procedure. Major regional cities such as Kalgoorlie have had no new land released for residential or industrial purposes since March 1995—over two years ago. For the resource industries, the existing Native Title Act and its totally ineffective registration test mean that they must negotiate with unspecified groups and unspecified numbers of people about unspecified rights.

The industry is understandably reacting with its new exploration dollars. Exploration expenditure in Australia—which for mining companies is equivalent to R&D in other areas—by our leading companies rose by two per cent in 1995‐96, while their expenditure overseas rose by 12 per cent. Australia's leading mineral companies spent 41 per cent of their total exploration overseas in 1995‐96 compared with only 26 per cent in 1990‐91. The situation can only be made worse by the legal challenge and by the dubious claimants to the $310 million Ernest Henry mine. If the action is successful, it puts at risk more than 500 similar mining titles since the Wik decision, including I might say the $650 million Duchess phosphate project near Mount Isa. The Labor Party did enormous damage in government and they are continuing the process in opposition in the Senate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, have you spoken to IBM about their failure to lodge a bid for the cluster 3 outsourcing contract, and what reasons have they offered for their failure to bid? Isn't this a huge vote of no confidence by a major industry player in your government's outsourcing plans? Can you confirm that the value of cluster 3 has fallen from an estimated $250 million over five years to around $150 million following the withdrawal of the ASC and the former Department of Administrative Services? Given these developments, will you now conclusively state how many IT clusters there will be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Lundy's question, I do have a brief here from the Minister for Finance and Administration. I am sure he would like me to inform you, Senator, along the following lines. IBM has never been registered as a prime contractor for cluster 3; hence the media‐managed withdrawal is of no impact to the cluster as it was a non‐starter. The government notes that there are a number of serious bidders for cluster 3 and that a vigorous competitive process is assured. Cluster 3 is not the largest of the IT outsourcing deals. However, it is still a significant amount of business, as the bidders performing due diligence are establishing.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Finance and Administration goes on to say that intellectual property vested in government applications can be considered as part of an agency's decision to outsource applications. It is appropriate that agencies decide how they manage applications development relative to their strategic and business requirements. For the same reason, government has not included applications development within the mandatory scope of the IT outsourcing initiative. Cluster 3 agencies chose not to include the applications development and commercialisation of IT in the scope. That does not preclude them from choosing to outsource it at a later date or other cluster agencies from choosing to include it.

The government has developed a framework to build a sustainable platform and a global focus for the Australian IT industry. We are seeking to ensure that small and medium enterprises are given real opportunities to participate fully in the process. We make no apologies for making this requirement that companies must meet in order to get a share of the government's business. The Minister for Finance and Administration concludes: the size of the transactions still remains substantial and cluster 3 remains a viable cluster expected to deliver substantial savings to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, when will you release a timetable for IT outsourcing, and will you guarantee that any such timetable will detail the agencies to be included in each cluster? If you will not detail the agencies, why won't you?

—Senator, I don't think there is any need to be aggressive on this. I will draw your question to the attention of the Minister for Finance and Administration and see what information he is able to provide to you.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, in your review of the Commonwealth‐state disability agreement it was noted that between $324 million and $917 million is required to meet the huge unmet demand for disability services. When will your government meet the needs of 13,500 people in critical need of accommodation, support or respite services? When will your government address the needs of 7,700 people whose carers are over 65? When will your government provide funds for the 70,000 people who need access to day and recreation activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Allison for the question because she highlights the heritage we were left by the previ ous government. These are the problems we were faced with, and I am pleased to say that the government is working on that strategy. In the two years since the Commonwealth disability strategy first progress report was lodged in 1995, a number of significant organisational, structural and functional changes have taken place—such as a change of government policy and direction, which was of absolute importance, as you would gather.

ANSWER.PARA: There has also been an increase in the contracting out of services, a decrease in staffing available within organisations—particularly at the entry level—and the devolution of responsibility for key functions to individual portfolios. These factors have affected the capacity of a number of organisations to fully resource and implement the recommendations of the Commonwealth disability strategy. Responses indicate that substantial progress has continued to be made to ensure that physical access, for example, to government offices and facilities, meets the requirements as set out under the Australian standards in raising awareness of the needs of people with disabilities.

As with the last report, more limited progress has occurred in relation to the development of formal consultation mechanisms between government organisations and people with disabilities, peak disability organisations or national advisory bodies. Opportunities exist for organisations to establish mechanisms to allow people with disabilities greater participation and involvement in the planning and provision of programs and services, and therefore improve their appropriateness, quality and cost effectiveness. Significant benefits could accrue for the government as a consequence of improved coordination and cooperation between government organisations in the planning and implementation of services to meet the needs of people with disabilities, as Senator Allison has highlighted. In relation to the specific numbers that are involved in that, I will have to seek advice from the minister and I will get back to Senator Allison with the detail of the question she asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and his remarks about policy and direction change. But, Minister, how can you justify your budget cuts of three per cent in 1996, a further four per cent in 1997‐98 and a further five and six per cent in the following years, given those unmet needs? Minister, isn't it a sad joke that your extra $25 million over five years barely puts back those budget cuts and goes no way to providing adequate services for people with disabilities? When will your government stop its endless cost cutting reviews of disability services and advocacy groups and collect the data that is needed to assess the real needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The regrettable fact is that when we came into government we had a $10½ billion deficit. I, like Senator Allison, would love to increase funding to disability services, as I would to all the other social problems that exist in our community. The reality is that not only were we faced with a record overseas debt, we were faced with a $10½ billion deficit in our budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I have never heard a Democrat policy yet that has talked about wealth generation and increasing the ability of government to improve services. All we ever hear from the Democrats is taxation, more taxation and more taxation—never anything about wealth creation. We get a policy of death duties from them which is regressive and retrogressive. I share Senator Allison's concern, as the government does, but we are limited by funding. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, do you agree that the only fair and meaningful way to compare economic data in different years is to use constant dollar figures? What is your definition of constant dollars?

—There are many ways to compare data. One way which is often used is constant dollar figures—in other words, to make sure the dollar value is equal between the base year and the comparative year. As the budget papers show, there are a variety of ways in which we can compare. Sometimes we use nominal dollars. Sometimes we use so-called real dollars. Sometimes we use growth rates, which are important. There are quite a variety of ways in which you can measure data. Which measure you use really depends on what you are trying to say. As I said, the budget papers do use a variety of measures.

Minister, can you guarantee Tasmanian pig industry producers and their employees that the future of their industry will not be harmed by the government's decision to permit pig meat imports from Canada and Denmark?

The central plank of this strategy is to provide expenditure of $10 million over three years, taking effect immediately, which will be expended on the basis of recommendations from an industry‐government consultative forum to assist the industry to develop export markets, as well as to strengthen its international competitiveness.
—Don't put too much pork in that barrel.

—Ha, ha! You shouldn't have made that interjection, Senator. The assistance is once and for all. Among other things, measures will have to be consistent with our international negotiating strategy. These actions have been welcomed by the National Farmers Federation. The National Farmers Federation welcomed the fact that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service had finally announced a decision on the import of cooked pork.

BREAK.PARA: I notice that Mr Roger Fletcher, a major sheepmeat processor, whilst indicating that he had some sympathy with pork producers, went on to say, `Just get on with it.' When it comes to these sorts of processes—in other words, looking at the importing of food from overseas—the process must be quite transparent and it must be based on scientific principles.

If it is not done in that way, it is inevitable that we will be branded in this country as having erected non‐tariff barriers. To do that would be asking for repercussions from other countries, and it is in our interests and in the interests of all primary producers in Australia that that process be maintained. If it is not, it will be to the detriment of primary industries in Australia.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Special Minister of State. —Thank you, Madam President. Minister, can you confirm that on that on 5 April 1995 you wrote to state councillors of the South Australian Liberal Party confirming that although you were the State Director at the time of the Moriki Products donation you were not involved—

—Most of the question is not relevant to the minister's portfolio and the matters referred to did not occur at a time when he was minister. There was a part of the question relating to whether he intends to move any amendments to the act. He may make a comment about that if he wishes to do so; he should not comment on those matters that are not appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, for that ruling. If you want to talk to me about these sorts of things, John, you can come and chat to me any time you like. Yes, as a senator for South Australia of the Liberal Party I did write to the state council in 1995 about the matters about which you speak. As to the amendment of the Electoral Act, I have been a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters over the last few years. On that committee we have agreed on a range of reforms in a bipartisan fashion. Most of them are technical but were agreed through the 1993 report, the 1996 report and the recent redistributions report of 1995.

ANSWER.PARA: We are proposing legislation, to be debated in the parliament next year, which will deal with all those technical matters on which there is largely bipartisan support. There were some bipartisan recommendations relating to electoral funding and disclosure. As I say, they were bipartisan and they will be in the bill to be introduced. I look forward to the ALP's support for those amendments, given that those propositions in the reports were bipartisan.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Vanstone in her capacity as Minister representing the Attorney‐General. In recent days there have been a number of quite astounding comments regarding the finality of rulings by the High Court. Many in the opposition seem to regard a ruling by the High Court as final, with no prospect of change in the future. Is it true that the High Court has reversed its earlier rulings on occasion? If so, can the minister provide the Senate with examples of High Court rulings which the High Court itself has reversed? Is the government planning to overturn a High Court ruling in removing the so‐called drunks defence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for a very astute question. In debates over the last couple of weeks we have heard by interjection from the other side and we have constantly seen in the media references to a protestation that the High Court has decided something, as if that should be the beginning and end of a matter. Madam President, you and I know that is not the case. Yes, Senator Abetz, we will be introducing a bill this afternoon to overturn the High Court decision in O'Connor as it applies to Commonwealth law to ensure that the drunks defence is no longer available.

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court has a very important role in interpreting the constitution, statutes and common law. But we cannot and must not overlook the role of parliament. Parliament, by making new laws or changing existing ones, can, does and should overrule the High Court interpretation to ensure that the law reflects what the people, through its parliament, want the laws to be.

The Australian government, on behalf of the Australian people, is no longer prepared to accept the High Court decision in O'Connor. The commencement of the criminal code provisions relating to intoxication will overturn that decision as it applies to federal law, such that intoxication will no longer be available as a defence.

The O'Connor decision of the High Court gained some notoriety recently when Nadruku used that defence in a charge of assault. The government is determined to ensure that perpetrators of domestic violence are treated appropriately in the courts, and the so‐called drunks defence provided by the High Court in O'Connor is now recognised as making it all too easy for perpetrators of crime, including domestic violence. Let me repeat: the High Court's role is to interpret the constitution, statutes and common law. The parliament's role includes that of amending or making new statutes.The High Court is not a repository of certainty but an interpreter of laws and the constitution as they now are. Both of them can be changed in appropriate fashions.

Indeed, the High Court does not consider itself bound by its own decisions. What the High Court thinks on any particular issue can and does change. There are many examples that Senator Abetz may be interested in, including a well‐ known one, the engineers case in 1920, when a young Robert Menzies, at the age of 25, with his first High Court brief, representing the Amalgamated Society of Engineers, had a very famous exchange with the then Chief Justice Knox. Menzies had dared to question past decisions of the court and that led the court to overthrow the immunities principle, which created the circumstances for growth in Commonwealth powers.

A more recent example relates to the free speech cases, with which all of us might be very familiar, where the court extended the freedom of political communication and only three years later reinterpreted the basis for the earlier decision so that it no longer depended on the constitution but rather on common law. In other words, the High Court came to the same decision but established a completely different basis for that decision. We could add cases involving section 92, Cole and Whitfield; the overturning in 1995 of the Beaudesert principle, which had been in place since 1966; and the Davids securities case in 1992, overturning a series of cases that had in the past drawn a distinction between mistakes of fact and mistakes of law.

That only serves to highlight that this parliament has a role to make the laws as it thinks they should be. The High Court is not an arbiter of certainty and parliament has a role to change the laws in a fashion that the Australian people want them to be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, and I think he is anticipating it. Minister, last year I asked you if you would reconsider updating and republishing the book Rebutting the myths . You agreed to do so more than a year ago. You advised me two days ago that you were going to launch it yesterday and provided me with an advance copy of it. You told me yesterday that you were going to launch it today, and I said that if you did not I would ask you a question about why you had not. Minister, this is the question: why haven't you launched the book?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for the opportunity. I was hoping for a question without notice from my side of the chamber, but I am delighted that Senator Collins has done it from the other side of the chamber because of the importance of the question he has just posed to me.

ANSWER.PARA: Rebutting the myths is a very substantial document that we were in the process of reviewing when Senator Collins asked me the question during the estimates before last. It has taken us a long time to bring it to the standard that it is today, and I would recommend it to every senator when it becomes available. I did give Senator Collins an advance copy because I had given an undertaking to him that I would let him see the final draft before it went to the printer. But, such is the speed with which things occur, it landed on my desk before I saw the final draft. I couldn't do that so I apologise to him for that.

I am pleased to say that Rebutting the myths is a document of outstanding quality. It has only 24 pages. I am grateful to the cartoonist Bruce Petty for his cartoons. It is an excellent summary of the myths that exist in relation to Aboriginal affairs in this country. I will give you a foretaste of it so as to whet your appetite, Madam President. I hope that all people who get the opportunity to read it will do so. The first myth is that there is no accountability in Aboriginal affairs. The second myth is that Aboriginal affairs is awash with money. The third is that Aboriginal people have an alcohol problem. We hear that frequently. In fact, it is the white community that has the alcohol problem. Two-thirds of the Aboriginal community, for example, do not touch alcohol. One-third are total abstainers, in contrast to the white community, where only 12 per cent are. That gives you an example.

Another myth is that Aboriginal people get special treatment from the government. Another is that Aboriginal people are lazy and do not want to work. For 20 years, Aboriginal people have been working for the dole. There are 30,000 now in the community. Another myth is that backyards are not safe from an Aboriginal claim. Another is that Aboriginal people have special access to housing. Another myth is that special education programs for indigenous people are unfair. Another myth is that ATSIC is another bureaucracy. The final myth is that most Aborigines live in the bush. There are many other myths. This document will go a long way to dispelling these myths, provided that it gets into the community and is read by those who still believe these myths. I commend it to honourable senators.

Senator Collins asked why I have not delivered on my promise of yesterday. I discovered that only 50 copies of this valuable document are in existence at the moment, of which he and I are two of the privileged recipients. I cannot distribute it to honourable senators until I have enough copies. I thank Senator Collins for the question and the opportunity to recommend this small booklet to honourable senators and the media. It is in the hands of the media that these myths get dispelled. In many cases, reportage in the media is one of the reasons why these myths get through the community and incite people like those on the other side of the chamber, who now run with about four per cent support, I am pleased to say. I hoped that it would be zero, but it is running at about four per cent because those myths get promulgated by people of that ilk.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister. The Prime Minister and others have repeatedly refused to give unqualified assurance to Australians that their backyards are safe from native title claims. I thank you for mentioning that. Can you confirm that on page 16 of this document, under the heading `Myth: My backyard isn't safe from an Aboriginal claim', under the heading `The facts', you make this unqualified statement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the High Court of Australia . . . said that native title had been extinguished by inconsistent grants such as freehold. Most private houses and backyards are on freehold land where a native title claim cannot succeed.

Minister, if you can give such an unqualified assurance to Australians, why cannot the Prime Minister? Will you give the Prime Minister one of these 50 books to ensure that he sticks to the facts and does not continue to perpetuate the myths?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not clairvoyant, but I also knew that Senator Collins would ask this supplementary question. There was no collusion between us from that point of view. Knowing Senator Collins, I foresaw that he would ask this question. Also knowing that Senator Collins would have this view, I drafted it very carefully. That is quite consistent with the statement from the Prime Minister, me and Senator Minchin that no case has gone before the High Court to test the High Court's decision. That is the fact. The fact is that there has been no case.

ANSWER.PARA: Now that Senator Collins knows and understands that, he will see that the wording is quite correct:

In 1992, the High Court of Australia in the Mabo case found that a form of native title existed. However, it also said that native title had been extinguished by inconsistent grants such as freehold. Most private houses and backyards are on freehold land where a native title claim cannot succeed.

`Most private houses'—most. Senator Collins must note that it is not totally exclusive. More importantly, no case has been tested before the High Court. Mr Gareth Evans on the other side has attested to that. Nowhere has a case gone before the High Court where a decision has been made. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, once again, under standing order 72(2)(a), I seek leave to ask a question of the chairman of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee, Senator McKiernan.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Does it only require one voice in the chamber at any time to refuse leave for such a request?
—For any request for leave, one voice is sufficient.
—OK. Well, be prepared.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. The Prime Minister went to the last election with a promise to introduce the largest environmental restoration program in Australia's history. Will you please inform the Senate of the progress of the Natural Heritage Trust and how the trust is improving Australia's environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to do so, because this was an historic initiative, in fact. It is the largest investment program to restore the health of our natural environment and the history of this country. It is a promise that was made to the Australian people at the last election. It is another promise which has been honoured by the Howard government. An amount of $1.1 billion of capital will be expended over a period of five years towards the dual objectives of the more productive and natural use of our lands from a commercial perspective together with, at the same time, the protection of its conservation values and, in particular, its biodiversity values. Biodiversity is perhaps the area that is threatened the greatest by the inadvertent damage we have done over the last 200 years to our natural heritage.

ANSWER.PARA: The trust is up and running. Coincidentally, the umbrella advisory group that was established by this parliament is meeting in Canberra today. It will report to us on its assessment of the coordination of the various programs within the trust. The partnership agreements have been established between the states and the Commonwealth. Submissions have been called from the public for contributions to help the community to engage in the remedial task of its own environmental heritage. Moneys are now being expended, those processes having been assessed at the regional and state levels and now at the Commonwealth level, toward achieving the objective of a better environmental outcome.

Madam President, I can advise you that over 2,200 individual community groups Australia wide have already been helped by this trust and $130 million, for Senator O'Chee's benefit, has been expended through those community groups doing works on the ground—what has been so much called for in the past to produce a better environmental outcome. The fact that 70 per cent of the grants that have been made have been to community groups demonstrates also that we are getting the money to the community rather than just to government bureaucracy.

One of the concerns in the past has been that there has been too much planning, too much government and not enough support for the community. We have redressed that imbalance in terms of the trust. Money is going to the community. Money has been made available in all states, and I am pleased to say that I expect funding announcements to be made in respect of the Northern Territory in the next seven days, which will complete the Australian process for the first year.

There will be a rigorous assessment of effectiveness within the spirit of the Natural Heritage Trust. We will be evaluating to ensure that we are achieving the objectives that we set for ourselves. As Senator O'Chee knows, one of the criticisms of the past has been that there has not been sufficient effort to determine that money spent in these areas does achieve the outcomes for which it has been expended. It is easy to demonstrate whether or not the money has been spent. It is much more difficult in natural resource planning to demonstrate that the objectives of the fund are being met, but we will meet that challenge as well.

So the trust has been set up. All of the advisory groups are in place. I mentioned the umbrella group which is meeting in Canberra today. The committee advising us on our bush care program and our revegetation program is giving long overdue advice on appropriate incentives to encourage a mass revegetation of Australia. Some $300 million is being spent in the bush care program. It is also advising us on regional priorities. The Landcare advisory group is meeting and advising in that area. BDAC, the biodiversity group, is advising. That was one that the previous government was going to set up but did not get around to. So it is working well and that is good news for all Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has talked about environmental issues on the land, but a key part of the Natural Heritage Trust is the $100 million for the coasts and clean seas program. Can the minister advise or give an update on how the government is going in terms of implementing its national oceans policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true. The coasts and clean seas program is an important part of the Natural Heritage Trust. So we are not just talking about terrestrial Australia; we are addressing our coastal and marine problems as well. Of course the marine area has been under represented in Australia's protected areas environment and we are redressing that imbalance as well.

ANSWER.PARA: An important part of that program—apart from the well-known areas of coast care, fighting pollution from land based pollutant sources, better coordinating coastal planning, addressing ballast issues—is the delivery of Australia's first oceans policy. Very few countries in the world have developed a comprehensive oceans policy. We are well advanced. Coincidently, a forum of some 100‐odd people representing different groups met in Canberra today and yesterday to help the government produce a quality outcome again. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, has your attention been drawn to a survey conducted by Coopers & Lybrand which found that Commonwealth and local government agencies were lagging as much as six to 12 months behind the private sector in the race to safeguard computer systems in the lead up to the new millennium? Is it a fact that Coopers & Lybrand partner, Mr Mike Bridge, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: While most organisations in `high risk' areas, such as communications, banking and insurance, appear to be getting on top of the problem, the exception is Commonwealth and local government.

Are you aware that Mr Bridge has also stated that `there is a severe risk of disruption to government agencies and the public services' key recipients'? Given that a third of companies surveyed are already experiencing problems with the millennium bug, including issuing expiry dates for licences, credit cards and medication, what action is the government taking to address this issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has not been drawn to that specific survey. There is an issue, as you would be aware, of the millennium bug and it is one which the government is very conscious of. The relevant departments are working closely on that particular issue. I will draw your question to the attention of the Minister for Finance and Administration and get a response for you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, has the federal government revised its costings for dealing with the bug, having previously estimated the cost at between $1.5 billion and $3 billion? Would you seek that out as well, please?
—Yes. I will seek that information for you.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to a government publication relating to Aborigines.

Before I turn to the substantive question of this entire scaremongering campaign on freehold title, which I understand the Deputy Prime Minister raised once again in the House of Representatives, I want to clear up the absolutely absurd interpretation which the minister attempted to place on the statement in his own book on page 16. The sentence reads, and it is very clear:
Most private houses and backyards are on freehold land where a native title claim cannot succeed.

There is no qualification in this statement that native title cannot succeed on freehold land. The qualification `most' at the beginning of the sentence clearly refers to the obvious fact that not all private houses and backyards are on freehold land; some are on leasehold land, like the ones on farms. But what the sentence rightly says is that all of the houses and backyards that are on freehold title cannot be successfully claimed under native title. I welcome the publication of this booklet that puts this to rest.

I commend the authors of what I think was a prize winning letter to the editor in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. If there are prizes given for letters to the editor, then this one should get a prize. It was on the question of freehold title. The letter is signed by five leading counsel in Sydney. The lead signatory attracted my attention because I know him well. The letter is signed by Ian Barker QC, Ruth McColl SC, Anna Katzmann SC, Robert Toner SC and Virginia Bell SC. The letter simply says:
To suggest that native title can possibly attach to freehold land is simply a lie.

That is correct. I advise honourable senators who do not know that Ian Barker QC is one of the most experienced silks in this country. He was formerly Solicitor-General for the Northern Territory and an advocate for the Northern Territory government in some of the land cases. In the Pareroultja case, for example, he was the leading advocate for the Northern Territory government. He knows probably as much about land rights claims and freehold title as any barrister in this country. So this very to the point letter has got a great deal of authority attached to it.

I think it is worth quoting from a letter to the editor signed by Creed Lovegrove of Howard Springs that was recently published in the Northern Territory News. Creed Lovegrove, well known to the Northern Territory government and respected by all, was a public servant for decades, is held in high standing in the Northern Territory, has long experience in this particular area of land rights, is not a raging leftie I would think and was a prominent public advocate against the recent euthanasia case in the Northern Territory. He is a fourth generation Territorian. His great grandmother was on the very first passenger ship that ever arrived in the Northern Territory. He said:
Regarding the story (Northern Territory News 21/11/97) headed "Wik: PM defends blast at churches".

As a churchgoer I don't intend to boycott church. I am able to accept the teachings of churches in matters in which they are expert and reserve my position on the personal and often biased comment of some church people on matters in which I believe I am at least as well informed as they are. Perhaps the Prime Minister feels the same.

I believe there is a lot of brouhaha in the Wik debate. The Territory has had the equivalent of Wik for most of this century. It was called section 23 of the Crown Lands Ordinance and appeared on all titles to pastoral leases.

It gave Aborigines a right of entry on to, and occupation of, pastoral land for traditional purposes. Generally the pastoralists and the Aborigines concerned handled this situation fairly amicably. These reservations in the interests of Aborigines were greatly strengthened in 1976 by the Federal Government's Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act. They were further strengthened in 1978 by complementary NT legislation, especially the one relating to Aboriginal Sacred Sites.
Going on the NT experience, perhaps if the federal Act had applied throughout Australia we would have got over Wik by now.

Although many Territorians suffered trauma at the time, the situation by and large is accepted these days. There will always be those who are rabidly opposed to it but there is a lot of goodwill now on both sides by fair and reasonable Territorians.
I could not say it much better than that. All these predictions that the sky was going to fall in were there 20 years ago and it has not happened. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take advantage of this opportunity to rebut the scurrilous accusations made against me in relation to this whole issue. I think the behaviour of the press gallery, in particular, has been absolutely irresponsible and outrageous on this because of its complete and deliberate misrepresentation of what I said. On the 7.30 Report last Wednesday, which is the only time I have commented on this, I was asked about freehold. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: We now understand from the High Court that freehold extinguishes native title, but there hasn't been an actual test case on a claim on freehold . . . There are claims on freehold—
true—
You cannot say with absolute certainty that a court at some time in the future might not find that native title revives on freehold where the freehold lapses . . .

That is what I said and that is all I said. What did we find in the weekend Financial Review from Mr Gareth Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? We found a report from Lenore Taylor which states:

There is a `live legal question' about whether native title could exist or revive on `public freehold' land, the ALP said on Friday. The Deputy Leader of the Federal Opposition, Mr Gareth Evans, said this was one reason the ALP opposed the government's plan to confirm total extinguishment of native title on freehold. The complex legal question hangs over freehold land transferred from one arm of government to another, or freehold which has been `forfeited', according to the ALP.

You tell me where that is different from what I said. I was talking about the possibility of native title reviving on freehold where it lapses. You and your mates in the media completely and utterly distorted it. You talked about backyards, not me. You started this scare campaign, not us.

Mr Evans was exposed and he agreed with exactly what I had said. You did not come out and attack him for scaremongering. Your mates in the ABC and Fairfax did not attack him for saying exactly what I said. In terms of this very question, I draw your attention to a letter in the Canberra Times of Tuesday, 2 December 1997 from John Greenwood QC, who actually acted for Wik and the Thayorre people. He actually says on this question:

The present position seems to be that although Australians can be confident that a grant of freehold extinguishes native title, it is not a 100 per cent certainty and will not become a 100 per cent certainty until the reasoning in the US and some Canadian authorities on fiduciary duty is rejected by the High Court.
The distortion of our remarks on this question—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think in honesty for all the people listening to this debate—
—That is not a point of order.
—My point of order is that I think Senator Minchin should make it clear that the John Greenwood QC that he is quoting was a former minister in the Bjelke‐Petersen government of Queensland.
—There is no point of order.

—He also acted for the Wik and Thayorre people in the Wik case, all right? He certainly knows a lot more about this than you do and that is his view of the law. The point is we believe as a matter of common law that native title is extinguished on freehold. All we are trying to do is confirm that in the act. The question remains: why will the ALP not support us in confirming that freehold extinguishes native title? That is the question mark that hangs over you.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now this proposition from Mr Gareth Evans on that question. All he says is what I said. That is what I find most extraordinary. It is the only point I wish to make. We will no doubt have this debate in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were asked about backyards, Senator Minchin.

—I was asked about the question of freehold and I replied in those terms. I said that we understand that freehold extinguishes native title, but the question of revival remains open—and that is exactly what Mr Evans said. You cannot have it both ways. If I am scaremongering, so is Mr Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, has been quite misleading in contributing to this debate because I have in front of me the transcript of his comments. It started with a question from Eleanor Hall which went directly to the letter from the office of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) in which he warned that freehold title land in suburban Castlemaine could be thrown into doubt by the Wik decision. The comments by Senator Minchin flowed directly from that proposition put to him by Eleanor Hall about the letter from the Deputy Prime Minister. That is how this started. That is the context, not the context that Senator Minchin now seeks to use.

SPEECH.PARA: It really reflects that, last week when things were going badly for the government in terms of the public debate about Wik, they decided to revert to the tactic that Richard Court had used throughout 1994-95—that is, to try to gather some support in suburban Australia by threatening people who lived in the suburbs by saying that somehow their small block of freehold land would be affected by the Wik decision and that somehow, unless they supported the government, their private block of land would be at risk, their backyards would not be safe. It was kicked off by Tim Fischer and followed up by Senator Minchin. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the flotsam and jetsam of the backbench have all joined in in the last few days.

Members of the government tried to give us the technical argument today, but that is an absolute diversion. It was about the politics. They had not raised this issue for two or three years. It suddenly was the pre‐eminent issue when they were struggling in the debate about the future of the Wik legislation and they knew they were losing that debate. At the time they were blaming greedy black fellows and the church, but now it is the media's fault. They have been trailing through the list of those they wish to blame.

Members of the government will not accept that the real problem is that they have got the legislation wrong. They cannot accept the fact that they are losing the public debate. They are moving to quite desperate tactics. What we saw today was a quite comical performance by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). It would be very funny if it wasn't so terribly sad, because in his second reading speech on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 he came in here and ran the same lines about backyards being under threat. It is a disgrace.

This man is supposed to be the advocate for Aboriginal people in Australia. He is supposed to be doing things like he did today—releasing a booklet which helps dispel the myths, helps attack those prejudices in Australian society and helps put the correct position. What does he do? The book says one thing—that it is a myth that backyards are not safe from Aboriginal claim—and the book goes on to explain how that is a myth, that there is no basis in fact for that claim. But the minister comes in here in the second reading debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 and backs up the Prime Minister and backs up Senator Minchin because that is their political tactic.

He knows it is not true. He knows it is designed to spread fear of Aboriginal people and to build resentment against Aboriginal people in the community. His job is to work against that sort of development, but he comes in here in a most disgraceful performance and helps breed that sort of resentment and that sort of fear. He refused a couple of days ago to condemn the remarks of Mr Marek, the National Party backbencher from Queensland, about $20 and a box of Jatz. Did he condemn those remarks? No, he talked about what a great member Mr Marek is.

This is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in this country. He will not show any leadership in trying to rebut the myths, rebut the prejudices and deal with these problems that Aboriginal people face in our community. This is the man charged with that duty. This is the man the government has given the job of assisting Aboriginal people, but he will not do that. He cannot bring himself to break away from the prejudices that dominate the Liberal Party these days.

He had the audacity the other day to say that Mr Viner and Mr Chaney, two former Liberal ministers for Aboriginal affairs, needed re‐educating—the old Cambodian Pol Pot solution. What a disgraceful action. That is his way. I have never agreed with Mr Chaney or Mr Viner on anything else politically, but they have got some respect in this community for their commitment to seeking justice and fair play for Aboriginal people. But will Senator Herron have a good word about them? No. Again he seeks to denigrate their contributions and say he is going to re‐educate them. I know who knows something about Aboriginal affairs in this country and Senator Herron is not one of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue in relation to freehold title really became an issue of community debate when the Labor Party set down their amendments to our Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . One of their amendments was not to consolidate in legislation the fact that, allegedly, everybody is agreed upon—namely, that freehold title extinguishes native title. You have to ask why Labor moved an amendment to our legislation to specifically reject what they assert is the law.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to have speeches by Senator Chris Evans about re‐education, he might like to think about re‐educating his former Senate colleague from his own home state of Western Australia Peter Walsh, who has had a lot of illuminating things to say about this matter, or a former leader of the Labor Party, Bill Hayden, who similarly has made very critical comments about Labor's Native Title Act. Just as Senator Chris Evans can drag out a few Liberals on one side of the debate, so we can drag out a few Labor people on the other side of the debate. It does not get us any further, so let us have a look at the actual issues.

Just the other day I received on my desk a brochure from ANTaR, Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation. Do you know the illuminating comment they made in that? It was that the Mabo and Wik decisions are following in the tradition of the common law of the United States and Canada, but Australia was far behind.

What happened in the development of the common law in Canada just recently? In Canada, where a similar native title debate has been proceeding some years ahead of Australia's, the courts last year unexpectedly found in the Badger case that native title is not extinguished by freehold title, as previously thought. So that is the development of the common law in Canada. Exactly the same developments occurred in the United States.

If these people opposite were honest about their views of the common law and where all this tradition comes from, it stands to reason that Australia's common law may well develop in a similar vein to both the Canadian and United States common law. If that is the case, then it stands to reason that it may be beneficial to extinguish native title over freehold land through legislation.

It is very interesting to have a look back over the past three or four years at all the headlines in the newspapers when the Native Title Bill was being discussed in 1993; the National Party in particular were accused of scaremongering. All the headlines and newspaper articles told us that they were scaremongering. Why? Because they asserted that the legislation may not extinguish native title on pastoral leases. But, of course, Senator Gareth Evans—hand on his heart—along with Senator Bob Collins and others, said, `There's no need to put it in the legislation because we all know pastoral leases extinguish native title.'

Robert Tickner, the minister for Aboriginal affairs at the time, said the same thing. He accused us on this side of scaremongering. Three or four years later, guess what? To use that Canadian terminology, we got an unexpected decision from the High Court on a 4:3 majority—a very narrow majority—to say that native title is not extinguished in relation to pastoral leases.

If we are to follow the development of the common law, who wrote the native title decision in Mabo? None other than Justice Brennan. Who was the chief dissenter in the Wik decision? None other than Chief Justice Brennan. You would have thought he might have known what he meant in the Mabo decision. But not so, because, as the numbers on the High Court change, the personnel change. You get a different mix of people and therefore you are likely to get different decisions out of the High Court. If you want this uncertainty to continue within the community, then reject our amendments. But let me assure you of this: the Australian people, in turn, will reject you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion before the Senate to take note of the incredible answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) today. We have had both the minister for aboriginal affairs and the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) first of all blame the press for the misquoting. We know a government is in very serious trouble when senior ministers starting blaming the press for the bungling ineptitude of the government itself.

SPEECH.PARA: We also note that Eleanor Hall, last week when this issue was first raised in an interview, said that she had contacted the office of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). She said:
The Deputy Prime Minister's office today conceded that the analogy—
about freehold backyards being under threat—
could have been better made, but there was no such concession from the Special Minister for State, Senator Nick Minchin.
As Mike Seccombe from the Sydney Morning Herald recently pointed out:
This was a bungling mistake made by a senior adviser to Mr Fischer, subsequently conceded by the Minister's own office.

But then the government decided to turn the bungling mistake into a political attack to run this scaremongering campaign. They tried to make the best of a bungling effort. They let loose in the House of Representatives, particularly with the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, last week and again today in question time, reiterating that scaremongering campaign. I think that was best summed up by that wonderful Geoff Pryor cartoon in the Canberra Times last week when he had Mr Fischer and Mr Howard dressed up as Aboriginal people, putting up some sort of totem pole in a backyard in the middle of the night and being caught by the householder.

What we have really seen, and why this government is bungling its whole effort over Wik, is what Senator Bob Collins pointed out today is in this document Rebutting the myths. This document is issued under the authority of the minister. On the front page it says, `Office of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs'. On the first facing page, it again states that it is under the authority of the minister. If you then go to the foreword, there is a nice photograph of the minister under his printed signature: John Herron. He goes on to say in his foreword:
This publication addresses some of the disturbing myths and untruths being perpetrated about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Trying to overcome prejudices is part of the reconciliation process.

And on the minister goes. He paints some nice words about reconciliation in his foreword; I only wish he would say it publicly on the record when he speaks in this chamber or in the media. If we then go to page 16 headed `Native Title Claims', it says:
MYTH: My backyard isn't safe from an Aboriginal claim . . .
It goes on to say:

In 1992, the High Court of Australia in the Mabo case found that a form of native title existed. However, it also said that native title had been extinguished by inconsistent grants such as freehold. Most private houses and backyards are on freehold land where a native title claim cannot succeed.

That is what the minister has written and authorised. It completely contradicts what Mr Fischer and Senator Minchin have been saying in the last week. If we go to the back of this document, it lists the sources to rebut some of these myths and it says clearly that the source is `Rebutting Mabo myths , document prepared by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Canberra 1993'. That is true. That was Mr Tickner, the then Labor minister in the Keating government. But, again, Senator Herron has endorsed what Mr Tickner wrote in 1993 and quotes it as a source in his own document.

Now we have the minister, in a gobbledegook way, trying to get out from under his own document here today—again proving that this government is all at sea in trying to get any sort of consistent viewpoint together about how to handle the Wik issue and native title. The only strategy they can now put together is to conduct a scaremongering campaign against native title and try to scare urban and town dwellers in this country that their backyards and houses are under threat.

I congratulate the minister even in his own bumbling way for publishing this document which absolutely and clearly refutes that dreadful scaremongering myth that the Deputy Prime Minister and Senator Minchin tried to resurrect last week in a scandalous way and they have been caught out by the bumbling Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht has just been talking about myths, untruths, scandal and scaremongering and it might be useful to look at the situation in his home state of South Australia, which also happens to be the state that I represent in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned in this place last night, there are 27 claims registered over parts of South Australia—some of them overlapping claims—with the tribunal and to me it is absolutely striking and crucial that less than a dozen of those claimant applications explicitly exclude freehold tenure from the bounds of their claim. It is absolutely crucial. Only they explicitly exclude the freehold tenure from their claims.

I would like to name the claimant applications for the benefit of Senator Schacht. The Eringa, Kuyani, Dieri, Coultard, Yalata, Maralinga and Yankunytjatjara peoples do not explicitly exclude any freehold land that is situated within the boundaries of their claim area. What a tragedy that Senator Schacht prefers to leave the chamber than listen to information which is truthful about his own home state.
In fact many of the claims that I have just mentioned include a generic statement that says:
. . . the application excludes any areas which may have been the subject of extinguishing events or, to the extent of the impairment—
not extinguishment, please note—
the subject of events which may have impaired native title.

It is very important to note that the word `impairment' and not `extinguishment' has been used in these claims. It is consistent with a certain theory that contends that native title may revive after the expiry of a validly granted tenure, including grants of tenure over freehold land.

The majority of the South Australian native title claims therefore leave the door open to the possibility of claiming freehold. For example, the Nukunu people's claim covers extensive areas of freehold land in South Australia. This particular claim covers the South Australian cities and towns of Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Crystal Brook, Gladstone, Wilmington, Quorn and Jamestown—some of the most important grain growing areas of our state and the Iron Triangle.
The claimant application states that it is subject to the following:

With respect to any validly granted freehold land situated within the area of the land the subject of the application, the applicants do not claim any native title they or their predecessors in native title may have held which—
and this is the important part—
was extinguished by the valid grant of freehold title.
Or, in other words, they claim native title over all of the freehold land which is found not to have been extinguished.

It is absolutely fascinating that the wording is quite different from that in the documents lodged by many other native title claimants in South Australia. I notice that many of those opposite use Justice French as some sort of voice of reason and truth in this matter. I keep hearing from him uncannily familiar reassurances about native title on freehold land in the same way as I heard it in relation to pastoral lease land back in 1993. Of course, not only did Justice French make those comments after 1993, but so has the former leader of the now opposition in this place, Mr Gareth Evans. In fact, their statements are uncannily familiar.

It is very interesting that we now hear from the opposition accusations of misleading statements being made on this side of the House. Let us not forget this statement by Justice French, because this was a very recent statement made by him that is seminal to this discussion. He told the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, of which I am happy to be a member, that `no coherent theory of extinguishment has yet emerged from the various judicial decisions' and that the possibility of native title reviving on freehold land which reverts to the Crown is a live issue. What sort of duplicitous statements are we hearing from those opposite, when the man whom they hold up as the arbiter of truth in this matter has himself conceded that this issue is `a live issue'? (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this bill is to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995 to bring forward the commencement of provisions which relate to the proof of an offence where the person accused is intoxicated. The relevant provisions, subsections 4.2(6) and (7) and division 8 of the criminal code, provide that self-induced intoxication cannot be considered in determining intent or voluntariness in relation to basic offences like assault. Without the amendment, these provisions would not commence until March 2000.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, the common law applies in relation to Commonwealth offences and the accused can raise the argument that he or she was so grossly intoxicated that the offending conduct was not voluntary or intended. While the common law rule is rarely used, and then usually in relation to the state offence of assault, the government wishes to provide a lead to those states who have not enacted the model criminal code provisions on this topic. In 1995 all parties and Independents in the Commonwealth parliament supported the enactment of the criminal code rules in relation to intoxication. The Commonwealth has had these principles on intoxication in its statute since then. At the time, no doubt because the common law rules were not expected to be used in relation to Commonwealth offences, the parliament did not give priority to commencing the criminal code provisions early.

The Commonwealth government favours commencing them now because the common law rules are inconsistent with its commitment to stamp out domestic violence. While in practice it is a state and territory issue, I want to encourage those jurisdictions who still have the common law rule to bring their law in line with the model criminal code provisions which were endorsed by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in November 1993. I believe, and the Commonwealth government believes, that common law rules are unacceptable to most Australians. With those remarks, I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of the autumn sittings in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.
