PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vanstone) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon its amendments Nos 1, 4 to 22, 24 to 27, 29 to 34, 36, 38, 39, 47, 49 and 54 made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes the government's request and does so for a number of very good reasons. First of all, I express my disappointment at the fact that the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 is back here today and of course in the manner in which it is back before us today. In terms of its broad thrust, the bill is not a contentious one for it is in many ways identical to the bill that the Labor government introduced into the previous parliament. Its enactment is a common goal of just about everybody in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: However, when we last debated the issues arising out of this bill the Senate made what I and I am sure all non-government members considered as some highly constructive amendments, amendments designed to enhance both parliamentary scrutiny of the process of making legislative instruments and the transparency of such scrutiny.

Legislative instruments are, it goes without saying, an exercise of the legislative power of the Commonwealth. It follows that it must be the parliament, not the executive, that has the ultimate say and control over the making of these instruments. However, this government is refusing to accept the Senate's amendments on the basis that it, the executive, has the right to determine these matters. This is the height of arrogance and this sort of approach is simply unacceptable.

Senators will note, and I am sure they have noted, that the government has failed to pick up one single amendment moved by non-government senators. Let me repeat: not one of the amendments moved by non‐government senators has been accepted. This includes what I would have thought were the most inoffensive of the amendments which required legislative instruments not to use sexist language. The bottom line is that the government really has not treated this process seriously.

BREAK.PARA: As senators will remember, during the debate on the bill we all indicated to the government in respect of a number of its amendments, for instance, those dealing with sunsetting, that we were prepared to consider alternative solutions to the same problem. Nonetheless, we expressed our grave and genuine concern at the models proposed by the government. In particular, we were concerned and we noted how the model of the government could be abused by the government of the day to vacate the field of regulation in any particular area. In further discussions between my office and that of the Attorney, the government indicated that it may be possible to modify the legislation by way of accommodating the Senate's concerns. However, we have seen no proposal of the government to adopt any alternative.

My office also went to the extent of indicating a willingness on our part to further discuss a range of other matters with the government in the hope of reaching a compromise. Those offers have been ignored. The result is that we have to consider a message in the Senate today. For some reason, it is an important matter that needs to be dealt with before we go home for Christmas. I still cannot understand why the government would not take a bit more time to get serious about this particular piece of legislation. It is amazing to even contemplate that the government may want to go to the Governor‐General and have a double dissolution on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 . This could turn out to be another one of those triggers. It would be great fun trying to explain to the public night after night what the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 amounts to.

You have to ask: why has the government not treated this seriously, why have they brought it back today, why have they not taken more time to consider it? The message we received today is essentially a bald insult to the Senate and totally contrary to the spirit of cooperative legislative practice that I am not sure the government believes is desirable but that the rest of us believe is desirable. Rather than constructively respond to our concerns, they have simply thrown our concerns back at us. They have not even pro posed to consider the message in parts as it applies to different subject headings and amendments.

We now have the situation where if we reject this message from the House on a bill that is in essence non‐contentious and that the electorate knows very little about we will have created the first precondition for a double dissolution election. Why is the government approaching this in such an unconstructive way? It could very well be that they want to build up as many triggers as possible. Maybe they feel that the Wik legislation passing this parliament with minor amendment in itself may not be sufficient so they want to build up the repository.

Who is to blame for this? Some would say that you should blame the Attorney‐General totally. Others would say you should blame the cabinet. Others would say that you should blame the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I do not blame any one of them individually, but I blame them collectively. It has to have been a combination of those three different elements in the process. For this particular exercise, I do not include the Attorney‐General's Department.

The Attorney should have fought harder for a compromise. The responsibility does start with him in this particular process. He could have shown a bit of goodwill. We were prepared, for instance, to defer a couple of issues and to put the government on notice that we wanted the government to come up with alternatives because we were of a view that although what they were proposing was not good enough the alternatives proposed by the Greens, the Democrats and Senator Harradine had problems also. The Attorney could have spent a bit of time constructively looking at the thoughts and the views of senators and see whether he could steer a course through it. But he has not.

The other concern I have with the Attorney is that, once again, we find he has glossed over the truth and, in this particular instance, has lied about something in a speech to the House. I do make that assertion lightly, but let us look at the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I think I heard Senator Bolkus suggest that a colleague had lied in the House. That is not an appropriate remark and he knows it.
—Senator Bolkus, if that was the case, I suggest you withdraw that remark.

—I will withdraw. Let me point you to the facts. The Attorney is on the record as saying in the House that he did not know of the Labor Party's position on this bill before the bill was debated in the Senate. Firstly, let me say that this is factually incorrect as we delivered to the government our amendments to the bill some days before the bill was debated. How on earth could they have actually made a considered assessment of our 23 amendments and presented it to the Senate had they not known about our position before the bill was debated. They knew about it. We had provided it to them.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, his assertion ignores the fact that his previous adviser on this matter had been approached by my office on a number of occasions prior to the debate to discuss the Labor Party's concerns. Unfortunately, the adviser chose not to avail himself of those opportunities. That, I suppose, best summarises the approach the government has taken in respect of this issue. They have not been interested in the Senate's responses and they have dismissed them without any constructive dialogue or application to what we are putting up. The Attorney could not have rightly said to the House of Representatives that he did not know of our position on this bill before the bill was debated in the Senate. He did know and the invitation was there for him and his office to find out more.

We now have to confront the government's response. Let me say that I do not think the response is anywhere near good enough. I could try to encourage Senator Vanstone to suspend debate on this matter and give the Attorney a bit more time to consider it. This is an Attorney who takes a lot of time to consider most things. In fact, you could say that he takes a lot of time to consider everything, but this particular proposal. When it comes to appointments, decisions he has to take, chasing Christopher Skase, chasing `Dolly' Dunn, the Attorney is somewhere lost behind the pack wondering what is going on. He is a slow mover.

In this particular case someone has said to him, `You had better respond to this before Christmas because we might be short of a trigger.' We actually think that the Senate deserves a bit more recognition of its views than that. We also think that this response is premature, inadequate and one that we cannot live with. Unfortunately, Senator Vanstone the opposition cannot live with your request and I hope the Senate cannot either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 , the Australian Democrats emphasised that the key component of the rule of law is accessibility to those rules, consistency in their application, and transparency and control over their development. We also believe that a strong obligation integral to a fair and democratic society is that people should not be disfranchised by the language we use in the laws that we enact.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus began his remarks by drawing attention to the gender issue. Despite the attempt by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in his `get on with it' speech concerning the present native title debate, implicit in his message was the negating of the important role that the Senate has in reviewing and improving the legislative process in this country. It is also important for the maintenance of public confidence in our public institutions to ensure that law making is legitimate and accountable.

I would like to concur with what Senator Bolkus has said in the chamber. If the Senate rejects this bill, we will be in the extraordinary position of having as part of a double dissolution trigger a bill that has multiparty support. Imagine a double dissolution over legislative instruments. Whilst some people are quite rightly concerned at the prospect of a race election, an election over paper would be preposterous. But that is not what is really going on.

Along with the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 —otherwise known as the unfair dismissals or the right to sack workers unfairly bill—I believe that the gov ernment is developing a cache of bills to mask its real intent in this matter; that is, to have a race election in this country. Is the government attempting to provide a legislative shield to provide an excuse for its real agenda—an election over Wik? Is it trying to have a whole series of bills it can claim it was having a double dissolution over? I do not know. I get lost with its strategies.

It is clear from the message sent to us from the House of Representatives that the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has not accepted the amendments made by the non-government parties in the Senate. I want to have a closer look at what he has rejected. Among the amendments either sponsored or supported by the Australian Democrats was the removal of gender biased language. I want to draw attention to a pattern that is developing with the Attorney-General in dealing with the Senate.

Senator Harradine, who is not known for pillorying members of the government, said quite strongly the other day that he felt that the Attorney-General had misled the Senate with regard to matters that Senator Harradine felt strongly about. I have had occasion to write to the Attorney-General and have not received timely replies when it was necessary. I have had occasion to remark upon that in the Senate. Here we have a situation where the Senate has advised the Attorney-General of its opinion and the Attorney-General has just dismissed it.

This is the nature of the amendments which went through on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 . There were 18 government amendments passed—you will note that there are 18 amendments approved by the House. There were 26 opposition amendments passed, five Democrat amendments passed, three Greens (WA) amendments passed and one amendment from Senator Harradine passed. There were four government amendments negatived, two government amendments withdrawn, five Democrat amendments withdrawn, one part negatived and one clause negatived. The point I want to make is that, out of 53 amendments, the government could accept only 18, and those are their 18.

BREAK.PARA: The government is so wise and so clever in everything that, when it comes into a house where it has not got the numbers, where people are able to express a differing point of view, it is incapable of accepting any—not even one—of the amendments put to it in this very important matter. Maybe it reflects a type of mind—an adversarial, aggressively obstinate mind—of the government. Maybe it reflects an inability to take a dispassionate and considerate kind of approach. Maybe it even reflects incompetence. I thought this was extraordinary.

Let us talk about the gender issues. The very same gender amendments were passed in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1997. In that bill, 83 Democrat amendments were passed, all relating to the gender issue. The same government which is rejecting those gender amendments in the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 not only accepted them and assented to them in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1997 but also asked the Governor-General to put them into law. So the gender amendments it will not accept in its legislative instruments have been accepted under the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1997, which amended numerous acts, including the Acts Interpretation Act.

What is going on here? Have we got a right and a left wing of the government? Have we got right and left factions? Don't you each know what you are doing? The Acts Interpretation Act says as a result of the Democrat amendments that there will be no sexist language used in the drafting and the carriage of government legislation. In this legislation, you are turning it down. I think it is embarrassing.

The Attorney-General has also rejected the reviewability of Attorney‐General certificates exempting some procedures from parliamentary scrutiny. In the House of Representatives he said that the amendments to this bill appear to have been generated in an ad hoc and unprepared way. That is a comment I suggest is both unworthy and untruthful.

It is true, as the minister well knows—and, Senator Vanstone, you stand here in his place—that at times the Senate is not an all seeing and all wise body. But that particular debate on legislative instruments—and I have been involved in many debates now in this house—was one of the best and most informed debates that I have been a party to in the Senate. The government representative of the day conducted himself particularly well. I think the remarks made by the Attorney-General are gratuitous and do not do him credit.

The policies in the amendments moved and supported were the result of great consideration. The assertion by the Attorney that there was no coordination in the work that was done by the Labor Party, the Greens (WA), the Democrats and Senator Harradine is most unfortunate. Some of the amendments which were pursued were recommendations of the National Party whip and the committee chair on those matters, Senator O'Chee, who is particularly capable and well informed in this area of regulations, ordinances and legislative instruments. All amendments were circulated according to Senate procedure and the matters, in my view, were fully considered.

I am not annoyed, Minister, because the government does not see fit to accept all the Senate's amendments but I am astonished that it cannot accept any but its own amendments. It will only accept 18 of the 53 amendments. I am astonished that it cannot accept amendments which have already been accepted in other bills. And I am astonished that the Attorney-General would have the view that this was less than an informed debate. If he or his adviser had been through Hansard, he would have seen that the parties, at large, complimented the government for bringing the bill forward and for the bill's general intent. It was, after all, only 53 amendments to a very significant bill.

In my view, this is one of the most significant bills you have produced in your two years in government. Minister Vanstone, I appreciate that you are standing here in someone's else's stead in this instance, but I must advise you that the Democrats will insist on all the amendments to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a number of comments in response to the remarks made by Senator Bolkus and by Senator Murray on behalf of the Democrats. Can I first turn to some of the remarks that Senator Murray made because he may need to leave the chamber. Just as a courtesy, I will make them while he is here. Senator Murray made the suggestion on a number of occasions that he has divined, by whatever process he chooses, that the government is determined to go to a double dissolution election, which he defines as being on race. Senator Murray, it has been my assessment—it is only a personal assessment which does not count for much, because there are so many of us here; we each have different assessments that we make—that on no other occasion have I heard you reduce yourself to what I regard to be cheap political point scoring. But, on this matter, I have to point out with regret that that is my assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: If the native title legislation were to be the subject of a double dissolution and were there to be discussion of the legislation during an election, it would be the government's intention that the discussion be focused on what the bill is about, and that is, land title in Australia. It is a matter of great regret to me that, over the 13 years I have been in parliament, the only people who have up until this occasion—except former Senator Kernot perhaps—sought to play what is lightly referred to as `the race card' were members of the Labor Party—and now the Democrats have joined them.

Since we are offering political views that relate to whether the government is genuine—I think that is Senator Murray's assertion in response to this bill. Senator Murray seems to be implying that the government is not genuine and is almost asking for the bill to be rejected, he says, to disguise a covert plan. I think that merits an appropriate response. I invite him to look through whatever records he chooses—I could be wrong; perhaps someone else has—because it seems to me that, rather than dealing with the substance of bills which I accept is more often the case in this chamber than in the other, on this occa sion the Labor Party has sought to define the public debate as being one of race.

It is a very easy thing to do. You just march outside and you say, `This is a racist bill. Those people are racists.' You define the political question as to whether the party to whom you are pointing is a racist party. Don't go to the details of the bill, don't go to the question of native title and don't go to the mess of the native title legislation—that your predecessors supported, Senator Murray—which needs to be cleaned up, just win the public debate by a little 16-second grab that will easily fit on the news by saying, `These people are racists.' It is not my view that that level of debate does politics in Australia at large any merit, nor this chamber, nor you—but that is for you to choose.

Your contribution, Senator Murray, invites a response that, just as you may find it unusual that the government wants to accept its own amendments and not yours, it is a simple fact that debate in this place is to persuade and cajole. I understand it was a very useful debate. I think I recall under the previous government participating on this bill in an earlier format.

We all agree this is a very important move. But it does not follow that, because someone does not like your views, they are adversarial, obstinate and have an inability to be dispassionate about things. If you are seriously convinced that people who reject your views in total must be adversarial, obstinate or lack some capacity to be dispassionate, you might need help from someone whose professional skills I do not have.

Much has been made in the limited debate we have had in relation to the suggested gender amendments. If I were a normal citizen at home listening to Senator Bolkus and listening to you, I might think that this government was determined to have gender specific legislation. I might have been led to believe that because, as you know, one can deceive by omission just as one can deceive by an overt misstatement of the truth.

Senator Murray, I therefore choose to put on the record that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and the Office of Legislative Drafting have both had a confirmed policy since 1984, which has not been changed by this government, to have gender neutral legislation unless the specific circumstance warrants gender specifics being used. There is no suggestion of that being changed. It has, as I am advised, been in place since 1984, and remarks of previous senators, therefore, need to be considered in that respect. This government supports that policy. It was introduced by the previous government and it is supported by this one.

Senator Murray, you referred to Senator Harradine's expressed views on the Attorney, which I have had the opportunity to hear before from Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine basically thinks he was misled. I just invite you to consider this: as I understood your contribution, you were saying to the chamber, in relation to the gender amendments, words almost like `exactly the same amendments in relation to the Acts Interpretation Act'. I think that is what you said. As I am advised, they are quite different. They both relate to gender, but they are in fact different. They are not the same amendments at all. As minor a point as that is, it does highlight how careful we have to be if we want to assert that someone else is not telling the truth. It is the old case of people in glass houses, I suppose.

I come back to what I think we all agree on. Most of us here understand that it is substantive legislation that, generally speaking, sets a policy direction, and it is delegated legislation which is more likely than not going to be what affects most Australians—other than criminal law. Most Australians will be caught, to the extent that they are, or inconvenienced or put out, by some delegated legislation that comes from the primary legislation. That does not, perhaps, get the attention and publicity it deserves because it is a net to trap citizens, if you like, a risk they run if they do not know the law, just as much as the primary legislation is.

For that reason, there is substantial agreement here and in the other place that this bill will be a marked improvement for parliament's control of that subordinate legislation. That agreement, fortunately, transcends party politics. The bill, and its forerunner by the previous government—that I think, as I said, I did contribute to the debate on—has been considered by a number of parliamentary committees and reflects a large number of suggestions for improvement made by those committees. That is important to mention so as to clarify for people that the Attorney has not taken this matter lightly. No‐one has.

This bill has been a very long time in the making and has had a very wide canvassing, with an enormous range of people having the opportunity to put their views in. There is a little bit of foot stamping at the moment because some final amendments sought by the Democrats and the opposition are not going to be accepted. But let us not for one minute let the refusal to accept those amendments cast an incorrect shade over the entire bill, which has been a long time in the making on both sides of this chamber. It is agreed that our control of delegated legislation and a citizen's capacity to understand what laws are there affecting them would be greatly enhanced if the bill was passed.

The registration provisions in the bill ensure that persons and bodies that would be affected by delegated legislation have the capacity to access that legislation before it applies to them. The tying of enforceability to registration of the instruments—so that an instrument cannot be made by someone, slipped in the bottom of a drawer and Joe or Josephine Citizen not know that this regulation has been made that is going to affect them—will greatly enhance a citizen's opportunity to understand what laws would be affecting them.

We believe the requirement for mandatory consultation for instruments will ensure that any future delegated legislation is both necessary and relevant. There has been an exponential increase, an explosion, of this delegated legislation that hardly ever sees the media light shone upon it and, therefore, hardly ever comes to the attention of citizens until they are affected by it.

The sunset provisions in here will ensure that unnecessary delegated legislation is removed from the need for compliance at the earliest possible time. The consultation pro cess is now uniform. Everybody will know what is required, and the public will have a proper chance of making their views known. To date, the multiplicity of different procedures has bred public confusion and a reluctance by many of the public to comment on the proposals. They are locked out of the opportunity to participate in, and comment on, delegated legislation that will affect them.

The procedures adopted are those that were agreed several years ago by COAG. They are used for intergovernmental schemes and by many of the states for their own domestic purposes. The changes suggested by the Senate would create difficulties for intergovernmental schemes and would require reconsideration by COAG of their processes. That issue, of course, will arise in the review of the policy and operation of the bill pursuant to clause 72.

The parliament's power to scrutinise delegated legislation has now been considerably enhanced. Instruments are being lodged with parliament sooner. The explanatory statement to be lodged with every instrument will provide a vast amount of additional material that has not previously been made available for consideration by parliament. Instead of relying on undertakings to amend provisions, which parliament finds unsatisfactory, and which are frequently not promptly satisfied, the bill provides for a short deferral of disallowance of an unsatisfactory instrument to enable the rule maker to correct an identified deficiency. The government says that the drafting concerns raised in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report Clearer Commonwealth law are met by this bill. Can I conclude by coming back briefly to the remarks made by Senator Murray, at the commmencement of his contribution, basically seeking to impute to the government a motive in relation to this bill that the government was somehow determined to ensure that this bill would not be passed to give it a second or third trigger for a double dissolution. So the government, in Senator Murray's view, could hide a covert determination to have a double dissolution on native title legislation, which Senator Murray chose to describe as being `an election on race'.

It does bear repeating that, in the 13 years I have been here, the only parties that have raised the issue of race, called someone else racist, played the racist card, have been the Labor Party and the Democrats. They are the ones that have inflamed issues and sought, in my view, to set one citizen against another—in other words, to capture a particular vote for themselves. They have mercilessly done it on every possible occasion they could. I take the opportunity to say that it does not reflect well on debate in this parliament, in this chamber or on Senator Murray himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, for your response. I am aware of your own political leanings and your stance on moral matters. I am glad you have stated it is not your intention to have an election based on race. I would expect nothing less from you personally. I would also remind you for the record that I did not use the word `racist'. I am of the opinion that it is probable that, amongst the 224 parliamentarians here, there may well be racists, but I do not believe that your government is a racist government. I certainly do not believe that you, Minister, are racist. I know you to be very much not so. But what I and many others in this country are concerned about is that the native title debate, if it went to a double dissolution, could degenerate into an election about race. Let me make it clear that neither you nor your government are characterised by me or my party as racist.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the gender amendments you draw attention to, I point out that Democrats amendments Nos 5, 22 and 25 require the Principal Legislative Counsel to ensure that legislative instruments are not drafted with gender specific language, as defined by amendment No. 1, unless there is a specific need to identify persons by their sex. You will appreciate that that amendment is putting into law the draftsperson's instructions. Your government's opinion is that that is unnecessary, and that is what your rejection is saying, but your government's opinion is not that it is wrong, because you yourself just said that it is correct. All we have sought to do is put it into law because your government and your particular opinion may not prevail at some future time. That is our intention. So I make it clear that we are in agreement with the instructions to the parliamentary draftspersons.

The strength of my remarks really relate to the response of the government. I want to draw your attention again to the fact that 35 amendments came through from all the other parties. Only five of ours were passed. Of the remaining 30, 26 were submitted by the opposition, three by the Greens (WA) and one by Senator Harradine. You heard me say that we would insist on all of them, so it is not just that we were determined that ours go through. We felt that the whole package of amendments were well considered, well debated and well argued at length. We do find it extraordinary—I do find it extraordinary—that the government cannot see fit to accept any of those. It is not possible that we are wrong on every single one. You think so, obviously, but it does seem an extraordinary response.

What I am searching for here is a way of dealing with the matter, which does not seem capable of parliamentary compromise, especially where the issues are not absolutely fundamental to issues of philosophy or ideology or policy on your part. For you simply to say that it is unnecessary is not good enough if it does not harm the bill and in fact advances the bill in the opinion of the Senate. That informs my remarks. Minister, I appreciate the strength and nature of your response. I appreciate your remarks. I thank you for your very firm statement as to the intentions of the government with regard to the nature of any coming election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —We might set up a mutual thanking society, Senator Murray, because I thank you for your response and for putting your remarks on the record. I think that is very helpful in the context of the political climate—shall I say—at the moment that some would let themselves fall into.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the gender amendments, what you say is right. You want to put into law something that has been government policy under the previous government and is still policy under this government. You say that if it does no harm, then we're churlish, obstinate and refusing to be dispassionate in saying, `Yes, okay, if that's what you would prefer.' But I could equally say to you, `Why don't we save the charges of churlishness, obstinance and refusal to be dispassionate for something where we actually disagree,' because, in substance, we do agree. The policy that you want followed is being followed.

Many a long argument has been had by parliamentarians, lawyers and interested parties in law reform as to when you should put something in a statute and when you should not and the sorts of ways you should put things in statutes. You would be familiar with the questions many people ask lawyers: are you a black‐letter law person or legislator? Do you think everything should be spelt out in black and white or should there be a return to embodying principles and allowing law courts to interpret them? Another question up is: should laws be passed even though you might have enormous hesitation about the capacity to implement them? Some people would say that the law should be passed anyway because it serves an educative purpose. It makes a statement about what the parliament thinks, and that is important.

Then you have other people who say, `We like you people, you do a good job for us as politicians, generally speaking, but have a look at what you are doing: you must judge your merits by sticking another law on the statute books.' They do not want this proliferation of legislation and delegation mounting up and up so that people here can go home and say, `Oh, I had a bill passed today,' and then stick a clause in here and another clause in there. Some people would say, `Don't do that unless you are going to change something for the better.' If you accept that point of view, it is not churlish, obstinate or refusing to be dispassionate to say that there is no need for that; it's happening. We do not need to put in legislation that requires us to do what we have been doing for over a decade. We can leave that piece out. In a sense, it is not worth fighting over something that you agree about, Senator Murray, and I think that is the situation that we now find ourselves in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, it would be helpful to the debate if you were able to indicate which of these amendments you reject, which amendments the government feels particularly strongly about. It is apparent from the discussion that you do not feel particularly strongly about the gender matters because you agree with us. You just disagree as to whether it should be in the bill. But there are other areas of discussion here which I think you regard as really attacking the intent of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the key matters was the sunset clause. The sunset clause matter had its attractions, as you know, because it gave the opportunity to clean up a lot of outdated regulations that had been on the books for a long time. But it was the opinion of the Senate, after a very considerable debate, that it also posed the danger of the government of the day turfing out a series of regulations which were very helpful on social and employment matters, for instance, or community or environment matters, which the community as a whole valued and the government of the day might not.

I think it was that fear that could not be allayed in the debate—and the government did not have a mechanism for dealing with the fear that the five‐year sunset clause would just allow a lot of stuff to be turfed out that we could never see again. I wonder if, in bringing the bill back to the Senate, the government has found a means of expressing an opinion in that area and will inform us of how to deal with that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, I was actually seeking some advice while you were speaking, so I may have only got a proportion of what you said and I hope I have not got it wrong. If I understood your contribution in respect of sunset clauses, you were concerned that at the expiration of that time there might be a sort of vacating of the field. There are two things that come to mind now to say in respect of that; there are probably many more. One is that there are many who adopt a very strong view that there ought to be sunset clauses in all delegated legislation—and some would even say in primary legislation—because it forces parliament to reconsider whether things are necessary. Many would argue that is why we have got the multiplicity of laws that we have got that need updating, because in the past people put another bill on the pile and never went back and had another look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: One mechanism to ensure that parliament does its job and cleans up the legislation and delegated legislation is to have sunset clauses to make us do our job; one that does not give us the opportunity to do it when there is a politically convenient environment in which we choose at our discretion and indulgence, but which actually says to parliament, `You are going to have to do these things in an ordered and considered way and you are going to have to turn your collective mind to this matter again on this date.' There are other arguments—I understand. But it is obviously the responsibility of parliament, when something is still needed, to put it back in its existing form. When it needs to be, or could benefit from being revamped, revamp it and put it back. When it is no longer necessary, get it off the books and keep our legislation clean.

Can I briefly indicate that, in relation to one set of amendments, there were some remarks that Senator Bolkus made in relation to the government's desire to retain power in the executive and to not listen to parliament. If you were listening to Senator Bolkus, you would have perhaps got that impression. There are currently some areas of instruments which are exempted from parliamentary disallowance. Some examples include quarantine proclamations, some migration instruments and some specific instruments under the Public Service Act relating to terms and conditions of employment. All of these matters have not, either now or for a considerable time, been subject to disallowance. For a long time they have been matters for the executive. You elect a government to govern and its new policy proposals and legislation, in that sense, of course need to be considered, but there is a balance to be found between having a government that governs and a parliament that keeps a check on it and allowing a government to govern. We say that the status quo—the one Labor has used for a long time and that has been in place—is the proper balance. If, in the end, ministers cannot make decisions without coming back to parliament on everything, why would you bother having ministers? Why don't we just have a collective talkfest?
Senator Murray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray laughs. He might think that is a good idea since the Democrats are a long way off winning a large enough number of seats in the lower house to win government. We have this system where there are checks and balances. We have departments who serve the government of the day. We have ministers who are paid to take the flak, if you like, and make decisions. Some of those decisions, they are not free to make without parliament approving.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments you want, Senator Murray, seek to make subject to parliamentary disallowance decisions that have not for a long time been in that position, and they would make it very difficult to govern in relation to those areas if they were. Senator Murray, you would have been here on occasions when the political climate hots up either in the nation at large or in this chamber. As we head towards the end of a session, quite often this happens, and I think the colloquial expression is that a bit of dummy spitting goes on. When you have things like quarantine proclamations and migration instruments, it is not appropriate that you take them away from the executive and say, `We the parliament—the people who have not been elected to govern—will take over that role and tell the ministers what they can and can't do.'

It is a fine balance. I am not suggesting for one minute—and I am sure you understand this—that because a government is elected to govern, it should be able to do what it likes and you should pass every bill we want. It is not a clear-cut matter to simply say, `Parliament would like to disallow that so ministers will not be able to make that decision.' If you keep going on, as I say, you will have no decision making capacity to give to a minis ter. You will just have people who sit there and get paid more, which is a ludicrous situation to be in. It is a balance to be found and we argue in that case that the existing situation—the status quo that you want to change—is the appropriate balance.

Labor found it to be the appropriate balance when it was in government. While I am not a betting person, I am prepared to bet this. This bill will eventually be passed without the amendments you want—so that migration instruments, quarantine proclamations, certain matters under the Public Service Act, et cetera, are not subject to disallowance. If you manage to stay here long enough and I manage to stay here long enough—and I think it will be a fair while—eventually Labor will get back into government. I am almost prepared to let you nominate your prize if you then move an amendment to have these adopted under the Legislative Instruments Bill and a then Labor government accepts it, because it will not.

While I accept the bona fides of your position, Senator Murray, and of the Democrats, we have seen all too often from the people who are now in opposition that the things they said they believed in when in government, they now say they do not believe in. When they were in government, this practice was a suitable balance. Now they are not in government, they do not think it is. Years and years ago, they thought privatisation was a shocking thing. Then when they were in government, they sold the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and the Australian National Line. They were not going to sell the rest of the Commonwealth Bank, as I recall, and then decided they would anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whenever you're ready, Minister.
—Sorry, Senator Carr? You are waving at me in an obtuse fashion over there. Are you okay? You don't need a first aid assistant? Good.
—He is waving goodbye.
—Good, that is fine. Thank you for that kind and friendly Christmas wave. If you just bottle it up for a minute, I will finish.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Murray, these people are opportunists. They were not going to support work for the dole, then they did. They put a finger to the wind and checked the polls. Senator Crowley is reported to have said, `What do we stand for now?' when they did the big 100 per cent backflip and decided to support work for the dole.

As you might recall, Senator Murray, according to the Labor Party, we were a shocking government for wanting to introduce a work for the dole scheme. The opposition think New Labour is fabulous, without recognising that New Labour in the United Kingdom supports a similar arrangement, as does the Clinton Administration in the United States which they would seek to align themselves with. If I ever saw Senator Crowley wandering the corridors as a lost ghost saying, `What does the Labor Party stand for now?' I would not be able to tell her. PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION BILL 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 and the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amend ments) Bill 1996, as reported by the committee of the whole on 3 September 1997. The question is that the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 as amended be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to my remarks I circulated to the Senate sheet 684 which is marked `revised 2'. Like other members of the Senate I feel that this debate has been sprung on me. We had thought that native title would be proceeding, so I ask in advance for your forbearance as we proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: We come back to this bill with a need for a decision on the issue of whether we are to retain Labor's Industry Commission unchanged or whether we are to have the coalition's Productivity Commission as considerably changed by the Senate. As you will recall, the second reading and the entire debate—and, Senator Cook, you were not the main Labor exponent on that day in that debate—were well informed, because the varying philosophies and positions of the various parties in the Senate were exceptionally well expressed. But there was a great deal of agreement, despite our different philosophies and opinions. There were very real concerns that the Greens (WA) and the Democrats in particular had about the Industry Commission.

There was agreement by all non‐government parties for substantial amendments to the government's bill. I must say that the government was remarkably obliging in according agreement to or in facilitating a number of those amendments and a number of those intentions—which was appreciated by the Senate at the time and recorded as such. It caused the Democrats to move away from their position of seeking to reject the bill outright, because in its form then we believed it merely substituted bad for bad to a position where we could see that it was a markedly improved institution, albeit still sitting within the framework of what people on the progressive side of politics would refer to as economic fundamentalism.

Accordingly, knowing that the alternative to change would be that we would be stuck with Labor's Industry Commission, which—with the greatest of respect, Senator Cook—has seen its use‐by date, we would hope that the Productivity Commission in terms of the very heavily amended bill would in fact be an improvement.

The improvements had been made primarily in terms of management and control. First, no longer would the chair have almost authoritarian control over the other 11 members. Second, the members of that commission would be drawn from what we considered a more balanced and a wider grouping. Third, the commission in its terms of reference would be required to review industry matters but with specific regard as well to social, community, environmental and other matters which are very much in the hearts of many members of the Senate.

As the Democrats we then went to government and said, `Look. If you would consider the possibilities of a few other changes, we would be prepared to support giving your new Productivity Commission a go, even though we do not like its politics or its ideology or its management—not in their persons but in the execution of their duties. The outcome is that we would prefer an improved body.' The government's reaction was that it would be prepared to reopen the debate. In consequence we have the Productivity Commission Bill back before us.

I then went away with my adviser and developed an approach that I put before you in terms of sheet 684, revised 2. Because this debate was sprung upon us I had no chance to discuss with the clerks the appropriate running sheet or how this should be dealt with. I would take advice from the main parties in the Senate. I can move the entire package together, if it is your wish, or I can deal with them separately or in parcels. Perhaps I should stop there and ask if there is any indication. (Time expired)

It is interesting that our theme should be taken on board, although not in the detail that we would like to apply it. Mr Temporary Chairman, I make those explanations at this stage and indicate that I am seeking guidance.

I appreciate very much the remarks of my colleague Senator Murray from the Australian Democrats about the elevated nature and considered tone of the debate when this matter was last before the chamber. Indeed, he is right; at the time I was not the shadow minister with carriage of this matter. But I think my colleague the former shadow minister would endorse what I am about to say.

The Productivity Commission is not something that is a direct substitute for what has been called here a moment ago Labor's Industry Commission. The Productivity Commission is not a swap. The Productivity Commission is a Howard government affectation which combines the Industry Commission, the Bureau of Industry Economics and the old EPAC—the Economic Planning Advisory Commission. That is, it is a combination of three different sources of economic analysis and advice to the government. In the first instance, by combining them to create one monolithic provider of economic advice for consideration to the government, you deny public sector advice to a government that is fearless, that contests the orthodoxy that some institutions hold as profoundly theirs. Speaking as a former minister in this place with carriage of industry policy for a number of years—

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good one, too.

—Thank you very much, Senator—can I say, having read Industry Commission reports, reports of the Bureau of Industry Economics and reports of EPAC, that the responsibilities of each of those three organisations were distinctly different, the quality and depth of the reporting varied, and the fact that they did not agree with each other was absolutely significant. When you are having to make government decisions, you need to know not just what the orthodox view is but what the other views are too. You need some sense of contest between those views in order to make reasoned and sensible decisions. By combining three contending organisations into one monolith, you produce a single stream of orthodoxy which does not have those variations, does not have that sense of contest and does not have, therefore, the institutional underpinning which a government needs in order to make sensible economic decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about governance of a nation in just one small, insignificant area of the country. We are talking here about the centrality of the Australian economy and decisions that relate to the management of that economy. Being a non‐economist, I guess I can observe that economists themselves say that the distinctive feature of the profession of economics is that you can put all the economists in the world end on end and you will still never arrive at a conclusion. In other words, this is not a precise science; it is a science or a profession that involves different shades of meaning and originates from various value premises as to what the outcomes might be.

It is a retrograde step to do what is being proposed here. I conclude my intervention at this point by re‐emphasising a point that I am sure my colleague the former shadow minister would have made abundantly clear. We are opposed to this piece of legislation. We are opposed to the concept of it. We believe that it is wrong. It weakens government and the right of Australians to know what the various differences of opinion are among economic institutions. It is not a matter of simply swapping the Productivity Commission with the Industry Commission.

On the subject of the Industry Commission, we have particular views about what might be necessary to reform it to make it a more effective organisation. The other organisations, EPAC and the BIE, have a particular advantage too. I wanted to make that point now so that, when we contend with the various amendments, it cannot be said that somehow we are supporting the Productivity Commission Bill; we are not. But since the bill will exist, we are trying to make the best of a bad job in trying to improve it. That is the purpose of our interventions in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since you have sought my advice, my advice to the committee would be that Senator Murray put his amendments seriatim so that at each stage you have a chance to comment on them.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman MacGibbon. I appreciate your advice. As always, Senator Cook's remarks were apposite, to the point and helpful. I will deal with his last point first concerning the three institutions he mentioned, which are EPAC, the Industry Commission and the BIE. The government has now pretty well folded down the other two. They remain naught but a shell, and we now have to deal with that fact. They do not have the resources and the people. Frankly, the government has done what it was capable of doing, which was simply starve them. We have to accept the government's right and intention to put those three institutions together. I, like Senator Cook, prefer a multiplicity of advice and models and all sorts of things, including political parties, but it is not to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be helpful to remind the committee that amendment 334 relates to fast tracking and adds provisions for a streamlined procedure for the recognition of native title on Aboriginal reserves and other categories of land. It involves the identification of native title holders by rep bodies; the registration of the rep bodies finding in the Federal Court as a determination after notification and appeals; the protection of the interests of residents who are not native title holders and the protection of non‐indigenous interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 334 specifically includes fast track determinations, requirement for notification and the ability to appeal against findings. It actually gives a series of functions for fast tracking. It also includes areas which constitute a national park or reserve for conservation purposes and vacant crown land. Basically, 334 is a reworked provision and is quite detailed. It includes all of these areas which the National Indigenous Working Group agrees with the Democrats and the Greens should be included in the provisions of fast tracking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to what I understand to be the revised ALP fast tracking amendment, which I think will pick up the arguments that relate to the Democrat amendment. So we are dealing with opposition amendment 359 and Democrat amendment 334.

SPEECH.PARA: From the government's point of view, the problems I presented before about this fast tracking process remain. We still are concerned in a general sense about the considerable elevation of the role of representative bodies in this process, which is a delicate matter. While our amendments, generally speaking, do give greater authority, powers and functions to representative bodies, we believe the proposition entailed here potentially involves them in quasi‐determinations of native title which would be inappropriate.

As I read it, it is saying that if the representative body fulfils its fast tracking functions with no appeal within three months, the registrar must enter that certification conferring native title rights and, indeed, conferring exclusive possession. So we effectively have an administrative body—a representative body—by this process granting exclusive possession, which we believe not only is wrong in principle but remains a problem in the light of the Brandy decision. It is effectively a determination of the existence of native title. It is an exercise of judicial power and, on our reading of Brandy, cannot be performed by the representative body through the registrar in this way.

On another level, we believe that granting this sort of role to representative bodies is wrong in principle. Rep bodies are there as an advocate for their clients—for native title holders. They cannot be advocate and judge, which is what this fast tracking proposition involves.

We have addressed this issue of so‐called fast tracking by the whole tenor of our amendments, by our agreements provisions, by the amendments we have prepared in relation to 47A and 47B about disregarding previous extinguishing acts where Aboriginal people are occupying vacant Crown land or Aboriginal reserves. We seek to facilitate this process, but we do not believe that we can support these amendments basically on two grounds: the conflict of interest involved in relation to the role of representative bodies, and the very dubious constitutional basis for this proposal, because we are effectively endowing rep bodies with a judicial function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The importance of these amendments is manifold. I want to say that very firmly. They provide a mechanism whereby native title holders can obtain recognition of their native title via a streamlined process and avoid the protracted, drawn out procedures of disputed claims. These amendments are to facilitate non-controversial native title applications. Application for fast track recognition may occur on Aboriginal land and other categories of land such as vacant crown land, national parks and conservation reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Native Title Act 1993 makes provision for land already controlled and/or owned by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be effectively converted into native title land. Section 70 of the present Native Title Act 1993 permits the tribunal to make a determination of native title where such an application is unopposed. I note specifically that, due to the Brandy case, the tribunal will no longer be able to make such determinations. This will now be required to be done by the Federal Court. This is uncontroversial, but I mention it for the sake of completeness in this debate.

It is important to note that the fast tracking provisions are not about bypassing procedures in the Native Title Act; they are about cutting through red tape where there is no controversy about a particular group's claim. Examples that come to mind are peoples who presently live in old missions who have been granted a form of title under state or territory legislation, such as the deed of grant in trust lands in Queensland, and now want to convert that land to native title. There is of course no right to negotiate under the fast tracking provisions and little reason for there to be.

Another example, and something I have been involved with personally a number of times, is old mission reserves on the outskirts of country towns in Queensland. I was involved in the handover of one of those reserves some years ago at Mitchell in south‐west Queensland where the old Aboriginal reserve known as the Yumba was handed over to the people of Mitchell for reconstitution as a centre for cultural exchange and for teaching young Aboriginal people and other young people about the culture of that area. It has become a very important place for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in that area. It is important that we do not surround handovers like that particular handover with more red tape if we are simply to convert them under the Native Title Act.

The fast tracking provisions improve on the processes in the current act in a number of ways. In the first instance, native title representative bodies play an expanded and important role in assisting the tribunal to identify and facilitate the selection of claims which should be fast tracked. Secondly, fast tracked applications will only be available to claimants who have regular physical connection with the area under claim. Where land such as vacant crown land, national parks or a conservation reserve is currently owned or under the control of indigenous people, it should be relatively easier for native title holders to be granted their native title rights. I say `relatively' because some governments, most notably the Queensland and Western Australian state governments, have been found not to have acted in good faith when dealing with native title applicants. I am happy to spend a couple of hours putting on the record some examples in relation to the Queensland government, but I am sure you do not want me to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us one!

—The John Koowarta case is a prime example. That was not a native title claim but simply the handover of a pastoral lease to an Aboriginal group. It was opposed by the state government. It finally ended up in the High Court where the Queensland government challenged the Racial Discrimination Act. The Queensland government was defeated. In order to thwart both the High Court and native title people obtaining some justice, the Queensland government then converted the pastoral lease to a national park. They are the lengths to which the Queensland government will go to prevent Aboriginal people getting title.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, these fast tracking provisions ensure that indigenous people who are not native title holders retain occupancy rights over the land claimed. It should be noted that any objections to the fast tracked processes which are registered within the three-month notification period will mean that these provisions will not apply. Last night the government indicated that they supported the fast tracking provisions. Senator Minchin said that the only problem he had with the amendments was with their form in relation to the Brandy decision and the manifest inability of the tribunal to make determinations of native title. On this basis, that consideration of the provision was deferred. I note that the possible difficulties from the Brandy decision have now been effectively dealt with.

Will the government now be supporting the amendment? I think we have had an indication from the minister. However, I would urge the government to support these provisions as a way of facilitating a just outcome as they pertain to claims that are not controversial. Finally, these fast tracking provisions ensure that indigenous people who are not native title holders retain occupancy rights over the land claimed. I think the Senate would be aware of a number of problems in that area. It should be noted that any objections to the fast track process which are registered within the three-month notification period will mean, as I said before, that these provisions will not apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are talking about here is nothing out of the ordinary; nothing that should cause too many people concern. We are actually talking about a capacity to fast track recognition of native title on Aboriginal lands or other categories of lands where the character of the tenure granted was clearly intended to benefit Aboriginal people. We are actually trying to facilitate and help Aboriginal people to be able to have recognition of native title, in essence, on their own land. Senator Margetts is moving an extension to include associated lands as well. It is not as if we are really going to be affecting too many other people here. I do ask the Senate to look upon this with that beneficial backdrop.

SPEECH.PARA: When were here yesterday the government expressed concern that our amendments did not satisfy the Brandy test. We have gone back to what I suppose we can call the full bench of Bastan QC and Castan QC and we have asked them to have another look at it. I will tell you what, Senator Minchin, you might laugh at them, but they have a pretty good strike rate in the court system. In fact, if it was not for them, we would probably not even be here discussing Mabo or Wik. And, of course, there are other people with them. What we have come back with is a proposal which picks up some of the concerns that you had yesterday, particularly as to language. It is a proposal which is probably worth going through for a few moments now. It is embodied in our R359, section 191.

In essence, the system will work in such a way that the rep body will be able to give certifications to the registrar. What the rep body will be doing is what a tax agent does, or what a facilitator does, in terms of settling a claim. The rep body will be able to get the people together and through its inquiries be able to settle the claim. That is, in essence, what we are talking about. Instead of using the word `determination', the advice to us is that we use the word `certification'. That is, in essence, what we are asking the rep bodies to do: to certify, as a tax agent would, all aspects of the claim. If you are a lawyer, you would be settling the claim. A lawyer settles a claim and puts it into court. In this case the rep bodies settle the claim. We say they `certify' it. In many legal processes you also say that lawyers certify affidavits and so on. The rep body has got that particular role and no more.

The next step is that it goes to the registrar. The registrar has an administrative function. If there is no appeal with in three months, the registrar enters the certification on the register. That is what the registrar does normally anyway, so there is nothing new in terms of the functions of the registrar in that step. By the very title of the person, that is their role; they put items on the register. So what we are asking to happen there is also nothing extraordinary. In fact there is already precedent in existing native title legislation for that role of the registrar.

In terms of being concerned with Brandy again, what we are saying the registrar will do is to enter certifications. Like a clerk of court, the registrar will put those on the court file or on the register. If, however, there is a dispute as to the register and how that register should stand, then under 191A(4) we provide that any such dispute and any exercise of judicial power goes directly to the Federal Court. In (4) we provide a list of the people who have standing, as against the certifications, by way of an appeal, and they are indigenous people and people who have regular physical connection, although maybe not native title claimants. We also, of course, list the Commonwealth, a state or a territory, or a person having an interest in the land comprising the area.

In essence, once you have got the admin work done, the register is there, as in the Family Court, as in the local courts, as in supreme courts, as in the High Court. If someone wants to appeal against that, then they can take, under 191A(5), an application to the Federal Court. That application to the Federal Court goes as to whether the certifications should be entered and whether they should be varied. They can dispute whether that particular person or persons had the required connection and so on. There is no Brandy problem at all, and no matter how much you want to bite your fingernails and try to find it, it is just not there.

` As I said earlier in the day, the model that we accepted before lunchtime, in terms of fast tracking for small claims, is the model that we are applying here. We have made some amendments to it, as suggested in the debate yesterday, to clarify the language. Our amendments do provide consistency in terms of recognising the process as a certification process and recognising that any judicial exercise is going to be conducted in the Federal Court. As I say, we are not asking for much to happen here. What we are saying is: let there be a way that indigenous Australians can actually, in a fast track process, claim title to their own land, and at the same time protect anyone who may have a valid interest. You might have had some problems with the reading yesterday, but there should be no problems with either the wording or the substance this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Bolkus has gone to some trouble to try to address the concerns of the Senate in relation to some of the issues that have come up. There are only really a couple of areas where there is a difference between the ALP's amendment and those put forward by the National Indigenous Working Group supported by the Greens and the Democrats. They are sections involved with part 4(d) and (e) on page 46 of the Greens‐Democrats amendments:

PARA.TAB: (d) areas which constitute a national park or reserve for conservation purposes; and
(e) vacant Crown land.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that the substance of the rest of the amendment is fairly much the same. I was just seeking guidance from Senator Bolkus as to whether, when he puts his amendment, he would include those two lines that are on the bottom of Greens‐Democrat amendment 334.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Margetts is right. We indicated last night that we were happy with those two further areas of land to be included as being capable of having a fast track process over them. I do not know how we can approach the wording of this, but I would accept that as an amendment to our fast tracking proposal.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We need Senator Margetts to seek leave to withdraw her amendment and Senator Bolkus to move his amendment with the inclusion of the two lines mentioned by Senator Margetts.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(359) Page 347 (after line 10), at the end of the Bill, add:
Add:

TAB.TAB: (c) an entry made in the National Native Title Register following a certification to the Registrar by a representative body in accordance with its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA).

INTERJECT.PARA: Insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) This section also applies in relation to land or waters the subject of certifications given by a representative body under subsection 191A(1).

INTERJECT.PARA: Insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) If a representative body has fulfilled its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA) in relation to an area of land or waters, it must give details of its certifications to the Registrar.

(2) The Registrar must notify the public in the determined way of the certifications, and stating that the persons referred to in subsection (4) in relation to the area may appeal against the certifications within 3 months after the notification.
(3) If there is no appeal within the 3 months, the Registrar must:

TAB.TAB: (a) enter the certifications on the National Native Title Register of native title stating that, subject to any notification under paragraph (b), the native title rights and interests confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the area concerned on the relevant people to the exclusion of all others; and
(b) include a notification in the registered certifications identifying any indigenous people found to have a regular physical connection with the land or waters and their recognised rights.

PARA.TAB: (4) These people have standing to appeal against the certifications:

TAB.TAB: (a) indigenous people who claim that they are the native title holders and that the group identified in the certifications is not;
(b) indigenous people who claim that they should be included in the native title group identified in the certifications;
(c) indigenous people who claim to have a regular physical connection with the land or waters and who seek to have their recognised rights noted in the certifications;
(d) the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or a person having an interest in the land comprised in the area.

PARA.TAB: (5) An application may be made to the Federal Court for:

TAB.TAB: (a) an order that the person or persons be included in the native title group; or
(b) a declaration that the person or persons has a regular physical connection with the land or waters and is entitled to continue to exercise recognised rights; or
(c) a declaration that the certifications should not be entered on the Register; or
(d) a declaration that the certifications should be varied and entered on the Register as so varied.

PARA.TAB: (6) On an application being made under paragraph (5)(c) or (d), the Commonwealth, the State or the Territory, or the person having the interest, bears the onus of establishing that the certifications of the representative body should not be entered on the Register, or should be entered in respect of some parts of the area and not others.

INTERJECT.PARA: After "High Court", insert ", or certifications made following the performance by a representative body of its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA)".
Insert:

TAB.TAB: (ea) the fast tracking functions referred to in section 203BHA;

INTERJECT.PARA: Insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) The fast tracking functions of a representative body are to be performed in relation to areas of land or waters of a kind referred to in subsection (4).
(2) The fast tracking functions of a representative body are, for such an area:

TAB.TAB: (a) to take all reasonable steps to identify as the native title holders of the area the group of people who, by acknowledgment of traditional law and custom, have a traditional connection with the area; and
(b) to ascertain whether the native title holders wish to have their connection recognised by certifications of the body; and
(c) to if they do, ascertain whether the native title holders wish:
(i) that the native title be held on trust by a prescribed body corporate; or
(ii) to hold the native title themselves; and
(d) to consult other indigenous people particularly concerned with the area; and

(e) to identify any such indigenous people who have a regular physical connection with the area and identify the rights or interests (the recognised rights ) they enjoy (such as occupation, access, fishing, hunting or gathering); and

(f) to facilitate the mediation and negotiation of issues relating to the fast track recognition of native title for the area between the native title holders and other indigenous people particularly concerned with the area; and
(g) to satisfy itself that appropriate arrangements have been made to protect the interests of those other people.

PARA.TAB: (3) If such a representative body is satisfied that the native title holders wish to have certifications registered in relation to such an area, it must:

TAB.TAB: (a) certify to that effect; and
(b) certify as to the identity of the people (if any) who are not native title holders for the area but who have a regular physical connection with the area and as to their recognised rights.

PARA.TAB: (4) The areas of land or waters to which the fast tracking functions of a representative body apply are:

TAB.TAB: (a) Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander land or waters; and
(b) areas referred to in paragraph 47(1)(b); and
(c) areas that are subject to a trust or reserve in favour of, or a lease for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do so. I seek leave to withdraw Greens‐Democrat amendment 334 on the basis that Senator Bolkus's amendment be moved accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: At end of motion add:

TAB.TAB: (d) areas which constitute a national park or reserve for conservation purposes; and
(e) vacant Crown land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what is happening here and I have the amendment that is being moved. I have listened to what the government has said in response to this. Obviously, the concern of the government is that it falls foul of the Brandy test. I suppose we have to take account of the government's view in respect of that matter because, if we proceed with amending legislation to its ultimate conclusion, then against the advice obtained by the government, that does impose rather a substantial weight of responsibility on senators.
—We did it this morning.

—Yes, we did it this morning. I was just going to come to that. We did it this morning and I did ask the minister a question about the merits of the provisions for small claims this morning. Leaving aside the question of whether it did or did not fail the Brandy test, I asked whether the proposal advanced by Senator Bolkus this morning on small claims was an attractive one.

SPEECH.PARA: In the ultimate, I adjudged that there was not a very strong opposing view by the government to my question. Indeed, I thought Senator Minchin in respect of that matter had previously indicated that it was a desirable thing to have mechanisms to efficiently, effectively and with alacrity deal with small claims. Ultimately, one will have to see what the government does with that amendment and what it does having regard to further opinion that it might obtain on the validity in its view of what we did this morning. I suppose that same thing applies with the amendments that are put forward by the opposition as amended by the Greens today.

I would like to hear the government's response to this sort of proposal that is currently before us. It just seems to me that it is attempting to deal with issues in an efficient, inexpensive and rapid fashion. What I would like to know from the government is, leaving aside the question of whether it is valid or not, does the proposal appeal on merit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to say on balance that it does not appeal on merit and I can only restate my arguments. We do have considerable concern about the conflict of interest involved with representative bodies and the quite significant elevation of the role of representative bodies. They are being given quasi judicial functions through this process. If you read the fast tracking functions of a rep body that are set down in 203BHA(2), you would see that they really are quasi judicial.

SPEECH.PARA: Representative bodies are there as advocates for native title clients. We have real concerns about the merits of this proposal with regard to rep bodies, but we also have concerns about its constitutionality. Effectively, you are conferring on the rep body the right to confer common law rights of exclusive possession on a particular group of people. We are talking about common law rights with native title. They are legal rights, with considerable consequences. It is wrong in principle and wrong constitutionally to confer such a power on a representative body, which is the net effect of these provisions, so we have concerns about them both on merit and in principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how long we are going for, but I want to put a few things on the record about this. We are going to give rep bodies the role of a post office or a tax agent—nothing more than that. Their role is to certify the facts as they have been able to work them through with their members and claimants. Once they certify that, in the same way that a tax agent may certify facts and claims on behalf of a client, in the same way that a lawyer may produce and settle documents on behalf of a client, that is what the rep bodies do.
