SPEECH.PARA: No legal force comes into play until the matter finally goes on the register. Before it goes on the register, there is capacity for appeal to the Federal Court. You may not like rep bodies, but the role of rep bodies has absolutely nothing to do with, for instance, Brandy for a start. The Brandy problem that you are talking about might have something to do with the registrar, but the rep body is not a judicial or administrative authority, it is a representative body. All it is going to do—and you know very well that that is all it is going to do—is what a tax agent normally does in respect of a tax claim.

To then say that the rep body confers rights is a distortion of what this proposal is about. Senator Minchin, if you want to finish this before Christmas, try to focus on what is before us. The process is that the rep body settles a claim. That is all it does. We use the word `certifies', but if you want to use the word `settles', we will use the word `settles'. The process is no different no matter what you call it. The process is acceptable.

It is not a question of giving the rep body the status of God in this process. The rep body will have the function of basically crossing the t's and dotting the i's, working out who is who, and saying, `This is how we see it.' They put that up to the registrar, in the same way as a tax agent does it. We are not saying that a tax agent has the call of omnipotence either when it plays that role.

It then goes to the registrar and then, in that process, before anyone's rights are affected, all parties with an interest have a capacity to take the matter to the Federal Court. Nothing could be fairer than that, and any distortion you might be using here to try to influence this debate—quite unfairly and quite improperly—should be bounced out of court.

Read 191A(4). Read 191A(5). Clause 191A(4) says that people have `standing to appeal against the certifications' and 191A(5) says that people may `make applications to the Federal Court'. The rep body certifies, it goes on the register for the whole world to see—particularly that part of the world that might have an interest in this area. Once the part of the world that has an interest sees this off the register, then it has a right of action. Nothing could be fairer than that.

You say that we have given the rep bodies extra roles, but it is the government that says the rep bodies have a very valid role to play and should be playing it. As you keep saying, you give them $40 million to conduct these roles. Part of the role could be to act as a post office, a facilitator, a lawyer, a settler of documents, a tax agent. For you to distort that and blow it up into a position where you claim that the rep bodies basically have the capacity of a High Court judge or a parliament is a totally unfair distortion.

If you are really interested in streamlining the process of recognition of native title in this country, you have no real option but to agree with a proposal like this. Native title rights are out there now—they currently exist. This proposal prevents the useless waste of public resources in drawn‐out situations where they are not necessary. If they are necessary, then there is a capacity to move them.

However, what we do here—and I would have thought this would also be attractive to the government—is that you have a tribunal with 667 claims to determine, potentially taking a lot of claims out of its workload is going to be of use to them, of benefit to the public purse, and of benefit to people who might be in the queue waiting for claims to be determined. Please do not distort the facts. We have actually got a reasonable proposal before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not the case that rep bodies already have the power of certification under section 190C of your legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The certification procedures we have put in place are in relation to agreements and the right to negotiate. It is not a certification procedure conferring common law rights upon—
—It is still a certification procedure.

—It is not a certification that you hold native title. You are the one who is trying to distort what is being proposed here. The rep bodies have been given the power to determine who the native title holders are. Once they have issued the certificate, then the registrar must enter that, and that entry confers the common law right of exclusive possession to the exclusion of all others. You could cloud this by changing the word `determination' to `certification' and saying that it is like a tax agent. Tax agents do not award common law rights to exclusive possession to anybody—not my tax agent anyway—and that is what you are involving the rep bodies in in this process.

SPEECH.PARA: While you have couched it and changed the wording and all that sort of stuff, this proposition still boils down to the rep bodies being given the authority to identify native title holders and effectively confer on them exclusive possession at common law. Native title is a common law right; it is not a statutory right. The world would have gone mad if we had tried to convert it to a statutory right. That is what Western Australia tried to do. This is a quasi attempt to convert it to some sort of statutory right. It remains a common law right which, as a consequence of Brandy, everybody agrees can be determined only by a court. The right of appeal to the Federal Court means nothing in the context of Brandy, because that was exactly the situation in Brandy and with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. So we have real problems with this from the point of view of merit in terms of what is being conferred upon rep bodies and from the point of view of the constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, Senator Minchin either does not understand or does not want to understand the process here. It is similar to the process we adopted this morning. As Senator Harradine says, there are two bundles of problems: Brandy related or policy desirability. In terms of Brandy related problems, as I said, this follows the process we adopted this morning. Basically, the process allows for something to be put on the public register, people get notice of it and people can contest it before any conferring of exclusive or whatever possession you might want to tell people has been conferred takes place. It is a process. So I do not think the Brandy argument holds much water.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to policy, you do not like it, but you have not really convinced me as to why you do not like it. There are benefits involved here, and we have discussed them already. It is just that maybe you do not want to embrace this sort of proposal. But as Senator Margetts says, your legislation already gives the rep bodies a role to certify certain things. And the `certain things' are not much different from the things that are certified here.

Your concern is not with actual certification; your concern is with the impact of such certification. And we are saying that the impact will not place if anyone disagrees with it and, in those circumstances, it takes place only after the Federal Court makes a determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are talking about the impact of certification, doesn't the impact mean that one particular applicant is actually given a head start? Yes, other persons can appeal against the certification, and those are listed in 191A(4)(a),(b),(c) and (d). Notwithstanding that, those people are given a head start. The question is: on the Brandy test, why would that not fall foul? That does give one particular applicant a head start over all the rest, and that could be quite significant in the ultimate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, two sorts of situations arise here. One is where there is no dispute. Obviously, there is no head start if there turns out to be no dispute—and in many circumstances there will be no dispute. In the case of where there may be a dispute, the actual fact that someone is under certification does not give anyone a head start, because there is no presumption to be drawn from that certification. It is not as if, because you are under certification, someone has to disprove that you should be there or prove that they have to be there over and above the proof that you show. So basically the certification does not in any way verify or validate or confirm any particular right; it only happens through the court process. In that court process the normal rules of evidence would apply. So the court would not, for instance, treat the certification as something that is certain until proven otherwise; the court would look at the whole bundle of competing interests and apply the normal rules of court and the normal burdens of evidentiary proof that are required here.

SPEECH.PARA: So the answer is clearly found in the processes of the court and the fact that a certification is basically a notification. It is as if you are saying, `If someone appears on a court register as making certain claims, does that give that person a head start?' The answer is no, because the normal rules of evidence would apply. In these circumstances the normal rules of evidence would apply in the Federal Court and the certification would not apply in cases of dispute. The real benefit of such certification is in those areas where there are no disputes. As I say, given the fact that we are talking about areas that are Aboriginal reserves or areas that are substantially granted for the benefit of Aboriginals, that is where the advantage here is. The advantage is clear: no dispute—Aboriginal land; where there is dispute, no‐one gets a head start, because the normal court rules apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to point out that there is already a process of registration which the Senate has voted for. I believe Senator Harradine supported the Senate in that in relation to the registration test. I think that was 190A and 190B. The Senate has already agreed that part of this bill could provide that kind of process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make the point that the certification responsibilities of rep bodies under our provisions relate to just agreements about the doing of future acts or parties to the right to negotiate. There is no certification that confers common law rights to exclusive possession on anybody. That is a most extraordinary authority to grant to a representative body. That remains our principal problem, and you cannot equate it to the other certification functions which our provisions provide for representative bodies. They are considerable powers, but they do not confer common law rights of exclusive possession, which is what is proposed here.

BREAK.PARA: If it is just a matter of the representative body identifying the native title holders and giving that certification to the registrar, then if nobody appeals within the three months, the registrar must enter that on the register and the effect of that is to confer exclusive possession on those people whom the rep body deems to be the native title holders. We believe this has fundamental legal problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Minchin basically let it out of the bag just then. You said that what the rep body does is confirm existing native title holders.
—No.

—No, that is what you said—it lists existing native title holders. That is our point: it does not confirm a right; it identifies people with currently existing rights, and that is what this section is all about. Shake your head all you like, make all the noise you like in the process, but that is what it is all about. It is about confirming who those currently existing native title holders are. That is what you do in proposed sections 190A and 190B as well. That is what this process does. I appeal to Senator Harradine to focus on that. The rep body's function is to certify the identification of people with currently existing native title rights.

SPEECH.PARA: There needs to be a capacity for appeal against that in case some people are left out. But they do not determine that someone will have a right; they do not determine that someone will have a right to the exclusion of others. They confirm their assessment of who those people are. It is not the role of the rep bodies to grant title rights to anyone. That is the process that we are providing for through the whole body of the amendment, from proposed subsections 1 to 6. They have put it on the register. They certify who those people are. If there is no appeal, if people are happy with it, then obviously it goes on to have effect, but it cannot have effect in the case of dispute. They do not confirm to the exclusion of all others, because if any others did have an interest, then they have a right to pursue this matter in the general court sense, in which circumstance anyone on or off the certificate—each group individually or each claimant individually—would have to prove their right to be there. There is no conferring of title rights. It is reflecting what is currently in existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a complete misrepresentation of what I said or of the facts. There are, as a matter of law, no determined native title holders until that determination is made by the Federal Court. If what you said was true, you would not need to go through all this process. If they were determined native title holders, meaning that the Federal Court had determined that they held native title, we would not be doing all of this. The point is that you have not had a determination as to who holds native title.

SPEECH.PARA: This process grants to the representative bodies this function of, firstly, `taking all reasonable steps to identify as native title holders'—in other words, they are the ones who decide who they will be—then it is certified to that effect, given to the registrar and, there being no appeal within three months, the registrar must enter that certification. Immediately, the effect is to grant common law rights to exclusive possession upon the people whom the rep body has decided shall be the native title holders. It is completely inappropriate and quite wrong to confer upon a rep body such a judicial function.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out a little bit of history to the minister. The Senate in 1993 did not give native title rights. The High Court in 1992 did not give native title rights. They recognised them. They recognised that they had always existed. So we are not conferring; nor is the court conferring. All they are doing is recognising what exists and what has always existed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, it would really help this debate if you recognised something like that and if you recognised that the Native Title Act was to actually confirm those native title rights. People do have native title rights. They do not have to go through a court process to get them. They may have to go through a court process to prove them if there is a dispute, but those rights, as Senator Margetts said, were recognised by the High Court and were confirmed through the Native Title Act. You do not have to go through a formal court process to get them, as you said a few minutes ago.

SPEECH.PARA: That is your essential misunderstanding of our provision here. If you recognise that starting point, if you recognise that rep bodies are only identifying people with currently existing rights, you would not be putting forward this fallacious argument about rep bodies having a judicial role.

No‐one is giving the rep bodies a judicial role. They basically have an admin role, as has the registrar. It would really help if you just gave one inch. We are talking about providing a fast‐track process for Aboriginals' indigenous interests over what is essentially their land. It is not too much to ask for some honesty in the debate in respect of that or some decency in terms of the legal advice you are providing to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is a long debate, Senator Bolkus, but calm down. Your proposed section 191A(3) says that if there is no appeal, the registrar must enter the certification, stating that the native title rights and interests confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the area concerned on the relevant people to the exclusion of all others. That is a conferral by the rep body on the people it identifies—and it alone—and the grant to them of exclusive possession of the area of land.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not quibble about what is being done here. That is an extraordinary power to bestow upon a rep body. What the High Court said as to native title is that our common law recognises the traditional law and custom and recognises that native title right where the court is satisfied that the native title claimants have maintained their traditional connection to the area and there has been no extinguishing act by government. That is what native title is about.

We are recognising the quite legitimate interest in Aboriginal people who already occupy land having the addition of native title. That occurs through our sections 47A and 47B, where we ensure that no regard should be paid to any previous extinguishment act. It takes that whole issue out of the equation. This proposition is made worse by the Greens (WA) proposition that national parks in the area concerned be included. As I say, we would be conferring exclusive possession over national parks if the Greens (WA) amendment were incorporated. I would have thought that would pose extraordinary legal consequences and difficulties.

Senator Woodley has made accusations against the Queensland government. The Queensland government, of all Australian governments, has concluded an agreement in Hopevale. After the Federal Court makes the appropriate determination, it will result in, for the first time on the Australian mainland, a group of people exercising determined native title rights. As this government and I have said, we applaud the Queensland government for negotiating that agreement in quite difficult circumstances, even though it is a DOGIT land. So there are processes in place and it can be achieved. Our amendments will facilitate it. We believe that this proposition simply goes too far. It has constitutional problems. It confers too great a responsibility and power on the representative body and puts it into a conflict of interest situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to stress a final point. There is no determination about any right of exclusion of another party without that other interested party having the right, within that three-month period, to take the matter to the Federal Court. We are talking about the confirmation of existing native title claimants. We are not talking about the exclusion of anyone else. There is a fair process involved here. I just wish the process was as fair to indigenous Australians when their interest in land is being affected in so many ways by your pernicious piece of legislation.

—We would like to get along with this legislation, but the minister is being very provocative. It is entirely appropriate for indigenous Australians to be involved in the management of national parks. It is entirely appropriate for indigenous Australians to be involved in management decisions. There is nothing wrong with that. It means that there is the ability for traditional lifestyle values to be incorporated into the values of the national park. There is nothing wrong with that. You very well know that exclusive possession has so many riders—you have put them in yourself a lot of the time—that there are many qualifications and it does not block anyone out. You use those terms to make people think other people are blocked out. You know that that is not the case. From the Greens' point of view, it is very important that indigenous Australians be involved and fully part of the decision making process and the management of national parks and nature reserves and, obviously, vacant crown land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Margetts. These are not my words; these are the words of the ALP amendment. It states that native title rights and interests confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the area concerned on the relevant people to the exclusion of all others. They are the words of the ALP amendment. We agree with the involvement of Aboriginal people in the management of national parks, and our amendments facilitate that. You are conferring a right of exclusive possession here. They are not my words; they are the ALP's words. As I say, our amendments facilitate Aboriginal involvement in the management of national parks, but not to the exclusion of all others.

—I must reply to the minister. I hope that he did not intentionally mix up what I said before. I was referring to a case that occurred in the late 1970s and early 1980s. It took years before the Queensland government finally, in a last act of pique, prevented in a High Court decision John Koowarta and the people who were with him from obtaining any kind of justice. That has been the history of the Queensland government for many years. If you like, I can put the rest of the story on the record and take hours doing it.

BREAK.PARA: We compliment the Queensland government that at long last it has agreed to the native title process and has worked to achieve an agreement with the Hopevale mission. That is great—I am glad that they have done it—but that does not take away from the record of 30 years of injustice that is part of my experience. So although with the minister I want to applaud the Queensland government for its very late‐in‐time conversion, it does not overcome what I put on the record about the appalling history of that government and its association with Aboriginal people. If you like, I can give you a whole lot more examples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —For about three days in a row now, I have heard a history lesson on how the Queensland government has treated Aboriginals. I thought I should come in and retell a story about an event that happened slightly after the war. It will not take long, but I think it has to be told. Let me relate the story. It happened after the war. During the war or slightly after the war started, the people at Hopevale were rounded up and put in an Aboriginal community at Woorabinda. There was a Lutheran mission there, and the Lutherans were German pastors. While the war lasted, an epidemic swept through Woorabinda. Something like two-thirds of the Hopevale people died through this epidemic. After the war, the people at Woorabinda who came from Hopevale decided to ask someone to take them back to Hopevale. This person was told that if the Aboriginal people wanted to go back to Hopevale and he could accommodate it, that it was all right. But he could not just take them and put them back in the bush with no hospital, schools or houses.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular person, with his own money, flew in his own plane with an Aboriginal person called Rosendale to establish where a community could be set up. He then got on a horse and rode out for three days to establish where the community could be. He laid out plans for a community centre. After all this was done he went to Woorabinda and took the people back to Hopevale where the community had been set up. That particular person was the then Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen.

When I hear Senator Woodley continue to criticise what the government did I am reminded of former Senator McMullan. Mr McMullan came with Senator Collins and me on an ATSIC committee and we flew to the communities. The then Senator McMullan said to me, `I have never seen anything like the conditions that the Queensland Aboriginal people have. They are very, very high standard.' He said, `They are the highest standard I have ever seen in communities.' I am also reminded of the time that we were going around with then Senator Bjelke-Petersen and we met an Aboriginal person who worked for the Bjelke‐Petersens during the war. He said to her, `Flo, I was always welcomed at your table. I ate with you, and I was always welcomed in the house.' He never forgot it.

Let us not hear any more about this. Let us get on with the game. We have a lot of work to do. Let us not go back into history because for every story you can tell against them I will tell one for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Look—
—Just apologise.
—No. What Senator Boswell has said is quite true.
—Is this relevant to the amendment before the chair, Senator?
—Was that? If you did not call him out of order, you should not call him out of order.
—Are you going to call me out of order, Mr Temporary Chairman?
—No. I just asked you a question.

—Of course it is relevant to the debate we are having. I have no problem with the example that Senator Boswell has given, but it does not interfere with my putting on the record the legislative and practical action taken by the Queensland government over many years to the great disadvantage of Aboriginal people. Joh Bjelke-Petersen in his personal dealings with people was a very kind man. There is no doubt about that. Joh Bjelke‐Petersen had a Lutheran doctrine of the two kingdoms. That doctrine of the two kingdoms allowed him in his personal dealings with people to be a very kind person.
—You are a fruitcake.
—You are not in the pulpit now, for God's sake.
—Order! Senator Woodley has the call.

—But it allowed him in his actions as Premier to separate that entirely from his actions as a person. That was the whole problem. Often as a law maker he did some appalling things, whereas as a person he very often did some kind things. So I can add to Senator Boswell's story, but the problem is that legislatively and as the premier of a government very often his actions were to the very grave detriment of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Margetts's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Bolkus's), as amended, not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to revised sheet 9, government amendment No. 70.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have moved amendment No. 70. It was deferred. I have said everything that needs to be said about it. I am happy to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that we did have an amendment No. 275. As I said last night, I was not going to pursue that. But I do have an amendment which has been circulated further to 275, picking up on some of the themes of it and doing what I was concerned we would not do last night. That is amendment 253A, 253B, 253C and 253D. 253B, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the operation of section 207B—
which is the one that is before us at the moment—

BREAK.PARA: where a recognised State or Territory body has been determined by the Commonwealth Minister under section 207A, the Federal Court must refer every application under section 61 to the relevant State or Territory body unless any party to the application objects.

Essentially, what this provides is that in those processes matters are referred back to state or territory bodies. But if there is an objection in the Federal Court process and either of the parties would prefer to have the matter dealt with by the National Native Title Tribunal, then there is capacity for the Federal Court to so order.

That is an important amendment. It will ensure that in cases where there is concern about consistency, concern about the operation of the tribunal or concern that the tribunal is not reaching national benchmarks in operation, fairness or whatever there is a capacity for the Federal Court to refer matters to a national tribunal for its determination. The amendments on page 826 all go to that particular issue.

This is important because quite often you find that some states do not take their obligation in respect of native title as seriously as they should. I think that that has probably been the sad history of the last few years in respect of the Native Title Act. It would have been operating much more efficiently had there been a bit of cooperation from the states. We are concerned that this situation is not allowed to grow, develop, continue—whatever you want to call it. The best way to do that is to guarantee a capacity for matters to be heard by the national tribunal where they are before the court.
Amendment (Senator Minchin's) agreed to.
Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(253A) Schedule 2, item 20, page 168 (line 28), after "mediation", insert "or subsection (1A) applies".
(253B) Schedule 2, item 20, page 168 (after line 31), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) Notwithstanding the operation of section 207B, where a recognised State or Territory body has been determined by the Commonwealth Minister under section 207A, the Federal Court must refer every application under section 61 to the relevant State or Territory body unless any party to the application objects.

BREAK.PARA: (253C) Schedule 2, item 20, page 170 (line 4), after "proceeding", insert "(but subject to subsection (6))".
(253D) Schedule 2, item 20, Page 170 (after line 8), at the end of section 86B, add:

PARA.TAB: (6) Notwithstanding the operation of section 207B, where a recognised State or Territory body has been determined by the Commonwealth Minister under section 207A and the Federal Court, at any time in a proceeding, considers that the parties will be able to reach agreement on, or on facts relevant to, any of the matters set out in subsection 86A(1) or (2), the Court must refer the whole or part of the proceeding to the relevant recognised State or Territory body unless any party to the proceeding objects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that these amendments were dealt with previously, but a little bit of water has flowed under the bridge. I would be grateful if Senator Bolkus could remind the committee of the purport of these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, the reason we are concerned to move amendments like this is that when you are dealing with a national regime such as native title and when you are dealing with an area which does need national consistency, you need to ensure that there are mechanisms to provide that consistency. That consistency is important for all stakeholders. For indigenous Australians it would be very divisive if in some states they had access to certain review or arbitral processes and had rights of procedure and they were different in other states. There could be nothing more divisive for the community than if you had a situation where the states and territories, in setting up their own processes, could totally deviate from the national benchmarks. The legislation does allow for a degree of deviation from the national benchmarks. That would be of concern to indigenous Australians but also of concern to stakeholders.

SPEECH.PARA: If you were a mining company, for instance, operating in more than one state, the last thing you would want would be claims in this area to be handled differently state by state. We already have those sorts of problems, for instances, in the consumer law area where nationally operating companies have to have in place six or seven different regimes to handle consumer protection, to handle building regulations, to handle all sorts of other planning and environmental regulations. That sort of inconsistency is not in the national economic interest. It is very divisive. If you have groups of people with different rights in different states then it will not be all that long before the tension between claimants in each state and the tensions on industry in each state will start to play a very divisive role.

You could also look at pastoralists, for instance. There would be problems if their rights were different from one state to another. Procedural rights are extremely important in this regime. To the extent that there is any inconsistency, the national economic good is not advanced and the system can be very easily discredited. Given a situation where you might have a potentially good state authority that may not get up to speed, the capacity for a national tribunal to play a part in that process continually is also important.

That is why we think there needs to be a capacity for access to a national tribunal. I know that Senator Harradine's amendment yesterday, which I think was accepted, to have a national member on a state based tribunal gives some degree of cross‐fertilisation. It does not give you the national benchmarks that you might need. We say it is important to have a capacity for claims to go from the Federal Court to the national tribunal. We also say that the Federal Court should be to send those off to the national tribunal where the court deems it appropriate. I suppose that is the genesis of the need to raise these amendments and that is what these amendments try to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I understand what the opposition is trying to achieve, but I suspect that is not achieved by this amendment. Section 207A will incorporate or repeat 251, which is about recognised state or territory bodies in the current act. They are the bodies that can exercise the judicial function of making determinations of native title. They do not have exclusive jurisdiction and our amendments do not seek to give them exclusive jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: That whole provision in the current act continues. For example, my state of South Australia does have a recognised state or territory body which operates under these provisions, but it is not exclusive. Native title claims can be brought in either the state jurisdiction or the federal jurisdiction.

We are establishing as a consequence of Brandy that, for the purposes of mediation and arbitration in respect of the right to negotiate, a separate equivalent state body mechanism—that is, an equivalent state body to the tribunal—in the performance of the functions performed by the tribunal which are not judicial but which are administrative; that is, the mediation service and the arbitration in relation to the right to negotiate.

So you have got two things operating here. You have got the court system through 207A and the capacity to recognise state bodies there, but there is no exclusivity to that. Then at the next level you have got the tribunal. We propose in 207B that there be the capacity to establish equivalent state bodies to the tribunal but only if the criteria are satisfied. Those criteria are set out repeating the words used in subsection 251(2)—`In order to ensure that there is a nationally consistent approach to the recognition and protection of native title . . . '

We are saying that 207B would ensure that a state body operates under the auspices of the Federal Court performing the functions otherwise performed by the NNTT, but to the standards of the Native Title Act as amended. So it is standing in the place of but performing the functions of and to the standards of the Native Title Tribunal. That seems from our point of view to make eminent sense, if states are prepared to set up these bodies, pay for them and have them established under state law but performing functions ordained under the Commonwealth act and to standards set by the Commonwealth act, and at all times with the actions or the claims under the auspices of the Federal Court, at all times the parties having recourse to the Federal Court and their claims being, ultimately, determined by the Federal Court.

Certainly from the government's point of view, we think it is an important policy proposition. I think the ALP is attempting to provide the opportunity for a party to opt to go to the national tribunal rather than the state tribunal if one is set up under 207B. The problem with that is that it will not provide much incentive for any state to set up an equivalent state body under 207B if claimants can opt to have their matter dealt with in the national tribunal.

We believe that sort of provision would effectively kill 207B. We do think it is an important provision. We do think that, because land management remains the responsibility of the states and because these and the mediation functions do involve a whole lot of interested parties essentially operating under state law at the state level and in the bounds of a state, it does make sense to have this mechanism.

Once a body is set up in a state and recognised, then the Federal Court refers the matter to that state body for mediation and the application of the right to negotiate provisions but according to the standards set in the Commonwealth act. I understand the amendment proposed, but I think it needs to be reworked.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think—and we thank the government and its advisers for this—207A should read 207B. To an extent you are right, Senator Minchin. We think there needs to be a capacity for a matter to be determined by the Federal Court as to whether it can go to the national tribunal. You might find, for instance, matters which are of general application and they might be setting precedents. In those circumstances it is quite desirable that the Federal Court send those matters off to the national tribunal rather than back to the state. If they are dealing with pioneering determinations or if it is a matter that does have a broader general impact rather than a state one, it is important for the Federal Court to have a discretion.

BREAK.PARA: As I said at the start, the only change I think we need to make after Senator Minchin's contribution is to pick up the advice from him and the government advisers and change 207A to 207B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you seek leave to do that, Senator Bolkus?
—Yes, I seek leave.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obviously supportive of the view that has been expressed around the chamber that it is desirable for the state bodies to be ad idem with the federal body. It is desirable to have a consistent application of the provisions of this legislation irrespective of whether that application is performed by the national body or by state and territory bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned last night, I noted that the new native title mediation regime will require that all native title applications be filed in the Federal Court, and the court will then refer registered applications for mediation either to the National Native Title Tribunal or to the equivalent state or territory bodies. Under those circumstances, it is in the interest of national consistency that the mediation processes pursued by the state and territory bodies should be uniform. The government stated in its explanatory memorandum that the purpose of the criteria that it has proposed for the state and territory bodies:
. . . is to ensure that the powers and functions conferred by the determination on the equivalent body are exercised or performed in a `nationally' consistent manner.

Yesterday we did adopt—and Senator Bolkus referred to it—an amendment of mine to provide that equivalent bodies each have as a member one of the members of the national mediation authority; namely, the NNTT. Having considered the matter again, I am wondering whether that goes far enough—and maybe this was an oversight of mine—because there is nothing in the legislation to protect that person, who would be the common link between the NNTT and the state bodies, from being marginalised by the state bodies.

I am wondering whether the minister could bear that in mind and see whether or not, in the ultimate, something can be done to ensure that that marginalisation does not take place. I do not say that it would necessarily take place. I make no reflections upon the state or territory bodies at all. But I do raise that point. Having regard to all of those matters, I wonder whether the minister could take that on board. Could the minister also indicate to the committee the considered view of the government in respect of Senator Bolkus's amendments as now amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we will certainly take on board the point that Senator Harradine makes about tribunal members and ensuring that those who sit on the equivalent body are not marginalised. You make a fair point and I think we could accommodate that in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: We understand where the opposition is coming from on this but, given the strict criteria we are establishing here for the establishment of equivalent bodies, we do not believe any purpose is served by what is described as `the capacity for forum shopping'. Once you set up an equivalent state body `performing specified functions or exercising specified powers of the Native Title Tribunal', that should be an exclusive jurisdiction. Unless the state governments know that matters will be referred to their state bodies, we are just worried that 207B would be rendered absolutely useless, because there would be difficulty in making a decision to establish such a body, in seeking a federal determination that would be determined as an equivalent state or territory body under these provisions, if it remained the case that all claims could continue to be dealt with through the national tribunal.

So, from a policy point of view, we think it is a good idea to have these equivalent state bodies performing the powers and functions of the Native Title Tribunal according to the criteria laid down in the act—acting in the place of but according to the standards of the Native Title Tribunal. From the point of view of the Commonwealth government, that makes eminent sense. But it is not going to work if the opposition's amendment is accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, it is unfair to call this `forum shopping'—the discretions in the court as to a determination. It just gives flexibility to the process. That is why we are moving it.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice, also at the request of Senators Bourne, Brownhill, George Campbell, Coonan, Faulkner, Heffernan, Lundy, Sandy Macdonald, Neal, Payne, Reid, Tierney and West, that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) extends its condolences to the families, relatives, colleagues and friends of Mr Ted Hughes and Mr Col Eather who tragically lost their lives whilst courageously fighting bushfires near Lithgow on 2 December 1997;
(b) also extends its sympathy to those families whose homes have been destroyed by the bushfires;

(c) expresses its appreciation to the thousands of firefighters in New South Wales and from interstate who are involved in protecting the lives and possessions of the communities affected or threatened by these fires;
(d) also thanks the members of other services, organisations and local communities who are providing assistance and comfort to people affected; and

(e) supports the provision by federal and state governments of necessary financial and other assistance to the services engaged in fighting the fires and to emergency relief to the people who have been affected by these devastating events.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 8.00 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The process of reform in the Australian wheat industry has been both protracted and difficult. Governments, both Labor and coalition, the industry and the Wheat Board itself have worked to ensure that the structure of wheat marketing is able to meet the challenges of the future. In March, an in‐principle agreement on a new structure was reached: the single desk was to stay, grower ownership and control was to stay and self‐determination by the industry was to remain a central policy plank.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite this agreement, there were still some grass root concerns within the industry that these changes would not be for the better. Many of these concerns were articulated by the New South Wales Farmers Association, but they remained committed to the process. Association vice‐president, Xavier Martin, summed it up when he told the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee inquiry into the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill that growers in New South Wales feared that `what we are building is just another middleman'.

They were also concerned that they were being asked to support part 1 of a two‐part legislative package without seeing the second part. He went on to say, `Growers feel that there is very little incentive for them to pursue the process.' But the industry leadership in the form of the Grains Council of Australia and the state grower bodies persisted. They were rightly of the view that the structure was sound. It was now a matter of getting the detail right.

A key issue for the industry was how the tax laws would be applied to wheat industry funds once the new private Australian Wheat Board was in place. The industry quite rightly felt that it was doing its bit; it was progressing difficult issues on behalf of a sceptical constituency and expected the government to recognise that fact. Xavier Martin told the committee that the growers' expectation `is that they will get tax treatment that provides the incentive for them to take risks in this structure'. That recognition was expected in the form of some taxation concessions at best, but certainly not less than a fair hearing. The industry lodged its submission on the question of tax with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) in April. Mr Anderson repeatedly told the wheat industry that its concerns about tax and wheat industry funds would be given proper consideration. But he failed to progress the issue.

It was a threshold issue for many. Some in the industry saw it as compensation, if you like, for the end to the government guarantee. It was to help allay concerns about what the ACCC might find in 1999 when it inquired into the public interest, or lack of it, in the maintenance of the single desk for export wheat. That point was made time and again in the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee inquiry.

The opposition also pursued the government on the question of taxation and wheat industry funds. We moved a second reading amendment to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, seeking to have it deferred until the whole restructuring package was available and the tax matter finalised. That amendment was voted down. But we continued to pursue the taxation issue with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Troeth) in the Senate. On Monday, 24 November, the parliamentary secretary told the Senate:
The matter of taxation is under consideration by the minister at present.
Under further pressure, Senator Troeth advised:
The matter of taxation is something that will be dealt with in the second stage of this legislation.
Senator Troeth then said:

I am advised that, after the minister has consulted with Treasury, there will be a working party meeting in Melbourne on this coming Thursday to consider the taxation issues and there will be a discussion of these taxation issues in the context of the next tranche of legislation . . .

That is, the government told the Senate on Monday, 24 November that there would be further discussion with the industry about tax and the wheat industry fund on the following Thursday. However, the minister advised the industry by press release on Wednesday, 26 November that the government had made a decision on taxation and that that decision was final—no correspondence would be entered into. So we have a situation where the minister has clearly thumbed his nose at the consultation process, and Senator Troeth's statement misled both the Senate and the industry.

The question that needs to be asked is a simple one. Did the information supplied by Senator Troeth come from the minister? I think it is incumbent on Senator Troeth to clear this matter up. Clearly, if she was acting on information from the minister, and one can only assume she was, then the minister caused her to mislead the Senate. I regret that she has not considered the promises made by this government to growers to be of sufficient importance to have clarified the matter. We believe the commitment by the government for the Thursday discussion with the industry had a use‐by date. It was given simply to ensure the Senate passed the bill.

This episode is yet another example of a failure of leadership on the part of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The President of the Grains Council of Australia, Mr Brendan Stewart, told the Senate committee:

One of the disappointments of the process up to now is that we have been waiting for some months for a draft ruling from the government on the taxation arrangements . . . We have continually pressed the issue with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy . . . I am not sure of the workings or the internal mechanisms of government in that term. But he assures us that he is continuing to ask for that on a regular basis . . . It is absolutely crucial to the growers and the growers' support for the grower corporate model and the restructured organisation.

The internal mechanisms of the government are simple. The minister either supports the industry proposal or he does not. If he does, he argues the case with his cabinet colleagues and, if he is good enough, he wins the day. Mr Anderson told the industry he was arguing their case—he supported their claim. He told the industry that he kept asking the Treasurer (Mr Costello) but failed to get an answer, even though the Treasurer had advice on the matter sitting on his desk in August. It is now clear that the Treasurer simply ignored him.I understand Mr Anderson then took the matter to cabinet and was ignored again.

The wheat industry sought some one‐off tax concessions as part of a fundamental structuring of its export marketing arrangements. It did not even get a decent hearing from the Howard government. Mr Anderson could not even deliver that. When he finally received a response from the Treasurer, Mr Anderson simply put out a media release. Despite government assurances to the Senate that further consultations with the industry were scheduled, he told the industry it was doing very nicely—in other words, `Stop complaining.'

The wheat industry showed strong leadership in delivering to the government support for the Wheat Board privatisation strategy. Mr Anderson's failure to display similar leadership on the issue has now put the whole privatisation plan at risk. This minister is Deputy Leader of the National Party. He is No. 4 in the cabinet pecking order, only one step below the Treasurer. But he has little authority in the cabinet room and his constituency is paying dearly for his failures.
I finish this matter by quoting the President of the Grains Council of Australia, Mr Stewart. In response to the minister's press release, he said:

What have we got from this Government. A kick in the teeth and a clear message from John Howard that a $7 billion industry, vital to the economy of this nation, means absolutely nothing to him or his Government.

There is another issue I want to raise tonight. It relates to the government's decision to approve the importation of cooked Canadian pig meat. At the last estimates hearings I asked AQIS a number of questions about a new disease, post‐weaning multi‐systemic wasting syndrome, or PMWS, identified in Canadian pigs. I was advised that AQIS had only just become aware of the disease.

In fact, AQIS became aware of the disease a week before the minister approved the importation of cooked pig meat from that country. I asked whether there had been any contact with the Canadian authorities regarding the nature and extent of PMWS. The answer was no. Given that AQIS knew little of the disease, I asked if it would suspend approval for the Canadian product to enter Australia. The answer was no. The officer told the committee that AQIS would get information on the disease and see whether or not the protocol should be amended.

I asked AQIS to give the estimates committee an assurance that the existing protocol for Canadian imports would provide adequate protection from PMWS for Australian pig producers. The answer was no, the reason being that AQIS did not have sufficient information to give such an assurance. I pursued the matter further and found that AQIS had formed the view that the existing protocol was satisfactory. It argued that PMWS was a disease found in piglets and not slaughter‐aged pigs or pig meat. It argued that, in any case, the Canadians are required to export meat only from healthy pigs so that there will not be a problem. If that requirement provided adequate protection, we would not need any controls on any imported food.

I now have a copy of a letter from the Pig Research and Development Corporation. The letter details findings of a preliminary risk assessment of PMWS from Canadian pork products. The corporation found PMWS to be a very serious disease which is widespread in Canada. The letter states that `there is a possibility that the disease is carried in pork products'. The corporation found it significant that the Canadian Food Inspection Service is currently undertaking research into detection of the disease in pork products. The corporation rightly stated that `one must assume it is in the meat of slaughtered animals until proof to the contrary is found'. It said it did not know if the virus was denatured by the current protocol applying to Canadian products. It concluded:

In the light of the lack of knowledge about the behaviour of the virus thought to cause PMWS, PRDC has concluded that import of Canadian pork and pork products may indeed be putting the industry at risk of becoming infected with the disease.

The PRDC letter also addressed Australia's GATT obligations in such a situation and advised that, in such circumstances, Australia was entitled to suspend pig products imported from Canada pending a further risk assess ment of PMWS to the Australian pig industry. Given this assessment by an authoritative body, the minister has no choice but to immediately suspend the importation of pig meat products from Canada. He must then direct AQIS to establish an independent panel of experts to undertake a risk assessment of this disease. If he does not, he is putting the whole pig industry at risk.

POST‐WEANING MULTISYSTEMIC WASTING SYNDROME (PMWS)

Pork Council has requested that PRDC examine what is known about the newly‐described Post‐weaning Multisystemic Wasting Syndrome (PMWS); its incidence in Canada and possible risks to the Australian industry through entry via imported pork products. PCA has also requested a briefing on obligations under the Sanitary and Phytosanitary Agreement (the SPS agreement).
The preliminary risk assessment for PMWS resulting from the import of Canadian pork products is attached.
To summarise the current knowledge about PMWS:

PARA.TAB: PMWS as described in the Canadian outbreak, is a very serious disease, commonly leading to death of 5‐10% of weaned piglets, and up to 50%.
The syndrome is widespread in Canada. Over 100 piggeries are reported to have the syndrome, which is a high incidence given reporting is not compulsory and it may be undiagnosed in many cases.

There is a possibility that the disease is carried in pork products. This is perhaps the area of least knowledge at the moment. However, PRDC considers it significant that the Canadian Food Inspection service is undertaking a research project into detection of porcine circovirus in pork products. The virus is known to be present in many body systems and in pigs beyond slaughter age. One must assume it is in the meat of slaughter animals until proof to the contrary is found.

We do not know if the virus is denatured at the current cooking requirements for Canadian pork to enter Australia. We do, however, know that the virus is unusual in its structure, being more closely related to plant viruses than animal viruses.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of the lack of knowledge about the behaviour of the virus thought to cause PMWS, PRDC has concluded that import of Canadian pork and pork products may indeed be putting the Australian industry at risk of becoming infected with the disease.

Pork Council has also requested information on Australia's obligations under the Sanitary and Phytosanitary Agreement. The essential elements of the agreement are that member countries are entitled to protect their animal health status, but are not entitled to use such measures as a disguise for restricting trade.

In the case of PMWS, it is not yet possible to fully assess risk. In such cases, member countries are entitled to provisionally adopt measures on the basis of pertinent information, providing that they undertake to seek additional information and review the measure within a reasonable time frame (Article 5, section 7).
In light of our preliminary assessment of risk, PRDC believes the following course of action would be justified:
1. Immediate suspension of imports from Canada pending further assessment of the risk of PMWS to the Australian pig industry;
2. Commissioning of a review of the risk. It is vital and the review have access to research information from Canada, particularly those results related to detection of the virus in pork products.
3. Review following the outcomes of the risk assessment.

If this course of action is pursued, we believe it would be important for Pork Council to agree to the terms of reference for the independent review and undertake to accept the findings of the review.

PRDC believes that the above course of action could provide a means of overcoming the current impasse between Pork Council and government authorities. To this end, it is our intention to provide the same recommendations to the Director of Quarantine and to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
Yours sincerely

Preliminary risk assessment of the possibility of Post‐weaning Multisystemic Wasting Syndrome (PMWS) entering Australia via imported Canadian pigmeat.
Pig Research and Development Corporation
1 December 1997
Background

The Pork Council of Australia has requested information from the Pig Research and Development Corporation regarding the possibility of post‐weaning multi‐systemic wasting syndrome, a newly‐described condition of weaned piglets, becoming established in Australia due to imported Canadian pork and pork products.
PMWS

Post‐weaning multisystemic wasting syndrome has been diagnosed in 117 Canadian piggeries (AgriFood Canada, 1997) and has been reported in France, Spain and the USA. Commonly 5‐10% of weaned pigs are affected, although this may be up to 50%. Virtually all those pigs die or are put down. The syndrome tends to last in the piggery for a long time (possibly around a year).

No similar syndrome has been reported in Australia. To assess the possibility of PMWS entering Australia through Canadian pork, it is necessary to examine the possible causes of the syndrome, and possible routes of entry to the Australian pig herd. At present, PMWS has been associated with a strain of porcine circovirus (PCV); a virus only recently described and previously thought to be non‐pathogenic.

ROW.ENTRY: Is porcine circovirus (PCV) the causal agent of PMWS?

Unknown at this stage, but under active investigation in Canada. Early transmission trials seem to indicate that PCV was not pathogenic for experimentally infected pigs (Tischer et al, 1986, cited by Nayar et cetera al. 1997). However, the early work appears to have been done with PCV from infected cell culture lines (i.e. PCV that was not implicated in disease). The recent report by Nayar et al. (1997) indicates that the PCV from pigs with PMWS is genetically different to the PCV from the earlier work. The Canadian workers have drawn the conclusion that certain trains of the virus are pathogenic and associated with PMWS.
The strains of PCV present in Canada are likely to cause PMWS.
Does Australia already have PCV or PMWS?

PCV is found in almost any country that has looked for it (eg. antibodies in New Zealand, Horner). Australia may have the virus already. However, the finding that there may be strain differences is critical. Even if Australia has PCV, we do not appear to have PMWS.
PMWS has not been reported in Australia.
How extensive is the disease in Canada?

Over one hundred herds in Canada have been reported to have the disease (note that reporting is not compulsory and that Manitoba has the highest proportion of herds affected, where the provincial Department of Agriculture has introduced PMWS as part of its routine testing);
The disease is endemic in Canada.
Is the virus present in slaughter animals?

The mode of transmission is unknown at this stage. Firkins (1997) points out that all the Midwestern USA cases have been in herds that receive breeding or feeder stock from Canada. If this report is correct, PCV is likely to be present in animals of slaughter age.
Slaughter animals are likely to carry the virus.
Is the virus present in pork or pork products?

The virus is widespread through many organs, and more likely than not would be present in meat. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency is developing tests to identify the presence of the circovirus in pork products.
PCV is likely to be present in meat.
Is the current import protocol sufficient to denature PCV?

The current import protocol requires cooking of pigmeat to 56 degrees for 60 minutes (or equivalent). The protocol has been designed to ensure the PRRS virus is destroyed. The temperature required for denaturation of PCV is unknown at the moment. It is known that the virus' structure is unusual for an animal virus, being more akin to plant viruses. Each virus should be considered on its own, as the recent surprising result for Infectious Bursal Disease (IBD) has shown
The PCV virus may survive the current import protocol.

SPEECH.PARA: Information required for full assessment
It is not possible to fully assess the risk of PMWS entering Australia without further information. Information on the following issues is required:

PARA.TAB: Is PCV the causal agent of PMWS? If so, what strains?
Are the causal strains already present in Australia? If so, why do we not see the disease?
Is PCV present in imported pork products?
What cooking temperature is required to kill the virus?
What actions have other countries taken in response to the syndrome (eg., USA receiving Canadian pigs: Denmark receiving French pigs)?

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

The Australian industry may be at risk of PMWS through Canadian pigmeat. It has not yet been established whether PCV is causing the syndrome; whether PCV is present in the meat of slaughter pigs; or whether PCV withstands the cooking protocol imposed on Canadian meat entering Australia.

Research into many of these unanswered questions is proceeding in Canada, and presumably in other countries with the syndrome. There is no doubt that the syndrome causes very significant production problems, and its emergence in Australian herds could be devastating. Rigorous investigation is necessary.
